Dial 7 was great for car service. We ate at Lobster Place in Chelsea Market for lunch. definite must.

Central location. Easy when on business trip on Lexington Avenue. Attentive staff, very helpful. Comfortable rooms, American size = very spacious. Bathrooms have small baths and tend be rather 'compact'.

I arrived on January 14th and found that I had erred in making my reservation. Josh was the Front Desk person who greeted me. In spite of an oversold hotel, he was sympathetic and found a solution to accommodate me. His demeanor and level of service was just terrific. I have always enjoyed staying at this property, now it is even more special to me.

This hotel had an amazing view from the windows if you have the window view room. It is also very close to time square we walked around New York City and had a wonderful time looking at everything. We took pictures all over town walk past the today show and spent the whole morning just wondering this hotel is located very close to anything you want to do in New York City.

We checked into room 2906. the sheets we too small for the bed and the mattress padding was dirty. then after my shower i went for the bathrobe in the closet covered in plastic…it smelled like cigarettes and it was yellow. Gross. However, the breakfast was nice…I am trying to look for something nice to say, but if the room isn't clean, then we won't be back,
user_name:
Susan C
New York City, New York

review_body: We were in city to go to doctors. We arrived early as we had to be at doctor at 2pm I asked at desk if we could check our luggage and get car into garrage early. She was great then I asked if we could have a quiet room as my husband would want to rest she could not have been more helpful in fact she told us she had a room ready and we could check in early giving us time to wash up and leave our bags. The room again perfect a corner room very very quiet very clean. The door man was extremely helpful with our many questions about distance to doctor, getting a good sandwich..the second day there my husband was admitted to hospital, when I got back to hotel I had to figure how to drive my car to hospital in morning, get luggage etch, I was nervous I went to dust and talked to JOHN everyone was nice there but John took the extra few minutes to make me feel better about driving in the city and finding the hospital, he was just what I needed a..you hear all the time how new Yorkers are not nice, well we only met pleasant people and this Marriott has an excellent staff..
user_name:
Doreen B
Lockwood, New York, United States

review_body: I am a Marriott platiumn customer so I love Marriott but this Marriott is the worst ever with service. First in the lobby u will see all the so be workers chatting instead of working and if u need a taxi be prepared to flag it yourself because the door man is useless.

This Marriott was a great location for the NBA All-star weekend activities and shopping....Although the weather was bitter cold, the hotel staff was warm and nice, I enjoyed my nice comfortable bed every night...The hotel staff provided great service especially the lounge staff on the 2nd floor and I look forward to my next visit soon in the spring....Mike T

Stayed here while in town for the NBA All-Star game.....3/4 of a mile from Madison Square Garden and the price was what you have to pay in New York.....has everything you need from exercise room to restaurant and bar.....lots of workers to help you out......behind the counter and guys to get your luggage and snag you a cab.....would stay here again.

Stayed here whilst running the marathon and so was part of package. Was pleasantly surprised at size and quality of room, my previous NY stays had left a more negative impression of the overall standard vs. price you could expect. Pleasant staff and very bubbly concierge. We walked the city all over from this spot, although the proximity to the subway came in handy once or twice.

Platinum member who stayed at Marquis/Essex/East Side --- by far prefer East Side for quiet enough location yet close enough to be anywhere you want to be shortly. Staff is very welcoming and urgent with fulfilling your requests. Lounge is pretty decent compared to others mentioned.Would welcome meeting managers more, but understand if they are busy. Very pleased with stay and will be coming back often.

This marriott has a great location for work purposes. This time I was there 6 days and it was ok. Not great, but ok. Pros- great front desk, concierge and bellman. Cons- window was letting in a big draft in 611. I had to counter by putting the thermostat at 72 or 73. This was a daily battle with the cleaning staff who reset the room to 70 every single day. I actually prefer it cooler but the draft was pretty noticeable. So much that I put towels there to try to stop it. 611 is right at the corner of 49th and Lexington. It's noisy. But it's also New York so peace and solitude and quiet are not what you are expecting anyway. Great location however... Rooms we're clean and odor free, great beds and linens.

Typical because you do get the feeling of Marriott. The not so typical part includes the following:1), no room service.2), the room is kind of small, perhaps among the smallest Marriott standard rooms I have stayed. Sufficient for one or two people, though.3), the size of the bed in the room with two beds is full size.A good thing worth mentioning is that the wifi is free for elite members.The location is pretty good as well.

The concierge club, in particular, is very very nice. It's the nicest Marriott concierge club I've ever been to. It's huge - great options on coffee, newspapers and the breakfast during the week is very good. TVs throughout. We were there at Christmas and the lounge was beautifully decorated. Service, as typical of Marriott, was excellent. I would stay at this Marriott again just for the nice concierge lounge. The guest rooms look like they have been recently updated. Rooms & bathrooms are crazy clean. Bed is comfortable, AC is adequate. Nicely appointed & pretty standard for a Marriott business hotel (seemingly better, though, than a New York hotel). We are platinum with Marriott & asked for an upgrade when we checked in. We were with a conference & had their rate. The room we got was very small with a tiny bathroom. We requested a change & got a larger room and larger bathroom the next night. Both were nice & clean. Manager was very accommodating & friendly. Location is great... convenient to Rock Center, Grand Central, Bloomingdales and other midtown destinations. The only negative I would say is that the elevators are slow & small. It's a historic hotel, so I guess that's expected. It did seem like they were not all running all the time.

We stayed for a 5 night break over thanksgiving 2014. Being a Marriott hotel we were surprised to find that there were no minibar, no room service. I would have expected that in a courtyard hotel, but not this one, dissapointing.The room itself is ok with good beds, but it is old, and it shows I am afraid.Perfect location and pleaseant staff though.We had internet inclusive, that was a plus.

hotel is fine from what I can tell so far. I was very surprised that they were hesitant to give me a late check out despite being a lifetime platinum member. I also was very surprised that there were no menus in the room -- but for good reason -- NO ROOM SERVICE!! I had no idea. The W on the next block has 24 hr room service and has been less expensive the last few times I've stayed there.It was also more difficult than you would expect to get an answer to the question "is the concierge lounge open," It was open but with no food -- I was told if I went up quickly I could grab a water or soda....I bet all the people watching the superbowl were surprised -- maybe that's why there werent' as many people as I expected!

There was something very wrong with this hotel - the odour wafting up from the lower ground floor could only be described as au de sewerage. Our 6 night stay at $1000 US a night should have been memorable for other reasons than the shoe box of a room with brick wall views. On the plus side the bell captains and concierge and Norman a fabulous waiter we met really went the extra mile. Pity the reception staff did not have the same work ethic having to return for5 times trying to locate baseball tickets that had been sent from Australia. On each occasion we were told that they were not there which resulted in more phone calls & emails home. Surprise surprise when finally someone looked properly and found them only to show they had been there all the time. The most frustrating thing about this exercise was that we had rung the hotel to ask if it was ok to have the tickets sent to them. Whilst we won't be back to this hotel the Italian restaurant across the road does great food and watching the President's motorcade drive past bringing the city to a halt was fabulous.

Although staff were helpful, the hotel is dated and expensive ($200USD for breakfast for 4 people), and no internet access unless an exorbitant fee is paid. The room was very small in comparison to other Marriott hotels we've stayed at, but were clean. The positive thing was the location though.

We stayed here over Thanksgiving. Rooms were a decent size, for Manhattan. The staff was accommodating. The price was decent, for Manhattan. The rooms were very clean. Ideal location for anywhere you want to go in the Big Apple. Good choice for tourists.

My wife and I went to New York City to celebrate a milestone anniversary. We had tentatively selected the Algonquin (another Marriott property) closer to Times Square. But at over $500 a night we were a little trepidatious. After further research, we found this little gem located on Lexington Avenue literally across the street from the Waldorf Astoria. The price was much more competitive so we booked a room for 5 nights. The property has all the comfort and features one would expect from a full service Marriott with friendly staff and a helpful concierge. The rooms seem large by New York standards and well appointed. The elevators are a little slow and outdated, however. As for location, it is close enough to walk to Times Square, Grand Central station and the theater district (but far enough away that the crowds won't create a noise issue during your stay). Regardless, there is plenty of shopping and dining opportunities right out the hotel's front door on Lexington and surrounding neighborhood (I recommend Fabio's Cucina Italiano and Smith & Wollensky). We will be adding the Marriott East Side to our list of reliable "must stay" properties for any future visits.

Stayed 2 nights(Friday and Saturday) for a conference in NYC. I was upgraded to a King with a sofa-bed because of platinum status. Room was quite large and comfortable for NYC. Clean room, basic amenities, no free water bottles. Water in morning took a little while to get warm(32nd floor), but then was fine. Gym on 35th floor through different elevator, which was fine for me, but maybe inconvenient for others. Basic equipment in gym-was fine. I checked out early Saturday morning and my valet car was delivered quickly and woman at desk was very polite and professional in my departure. Location is fine.

As far as New York hotels go, this one was the most peaceful of the 3 I stayed in on my trip. The rooms were a good size, very comfortable and exceptionally clean. The staff were more than friendly, and very helpful. I thoroughly enjoyed my short stay in the East Side; I am yet to be disappointed by a Marriott hotel.

Our family visited the week of Christmas. We checked our bags the last day while we did some extra sightseeing. When we got to our next destination, we realized we were missing one of our suitcases. The Bell Captain located our bag , boxed it, and shipped it to us Fed ex.We were very appreciative of this exceptional service. The location is awesome, easy walk to Central Park and Times Square area. We felt safe walking around the area.

My wife and I visited New York on the 19th December 2015 for some bargain buying, sight seeing, lovely eating and just take in this enchanting city and what better base to have than the New York Marriott East Side.It is ideally located for shops, local sight seeing like the Empire State, Chrysler Building, Central Park etc.It has a comfortable and friendly bar and reception area. The staff were very helpful and assisted when ever they could.The executive room we had was spacious, warm, had everything you would desire.The bed was exceptionally comfortable and snug, ideal for a good nights rest.The only adverse comment I can make is for executive / Elite members who make use of the lounge in the evening. This is due to us arriving at 7.15pm and finding very little refreshments available, no free alcohol and no assistance, reassurance of understanding from the resident staff member.There is Free Wi-Fi but only in the reception area otherwise there was a charge,Overall though a very pleasant and relaxing stay.

The midtown Manhattan location and staff here are great. The hotel is a bit "older" so if you want the latest and greatest then you will be disappointed here. For me, I just want the killer location, a decent room (and mine surely was - big enough too!!), and to fall out my door and into the mid-town madness. Plus, everyone here was very nice. I don't think they have room services if that's something you require, but I don't care about that at all. I think it's a great place and would love to stay here again while in NYC.

Don't expect "Marriott" quality here. I usually like the Marriott brand because there aren't surprises. Not always the best in town, but you always know what you will get and its usually well above average. Not here. First, I don't know of any other Marriott that doesn't even offer room service. You are on your own to eat. The gym is compact and well undersized - had to wait on working equipment (some didn't ever work), and the elevators must be the slowest in NYC - count on 5 minute waits (seriously!) as a standard. There are too many better hotels in the area. Don't punish yourself.

Would recommend flying into LaGuardia as it's closer to the hotel; the fare was $38. There were 4 of us (2 Adults & 2 "young adults") and the Premier King room was big enough that we never felt cramped. No view, but we weren't there during the day anyway. The sofa bed was ok, but if you're young & tired it worked just fine. Great location. For breakfast, we'd go 2 blocks to The Metro Café, fast but surprisingly decent food (they cook made to order omelets, breakfast wraps as well as fresh fruit & muffins).

We changed rooms as night one was sooo loud all night long, woke in a bad mood and very tired. . We were in NY for only four nights so wanted to make the most of it. Night two, so tired, slept ok but night three was windy and had a wire hit a pipe all night really loudly, so no sleep really hacked off now and they did offer to change the room but we had so much luggage, we just couldnt face it. The windows are so thin, not double glazed and you hear everything going on outside. We stayed with Marriott points, a lot of points that we accrued over the year, so we were good customers. Be aware that only half the hotel has been renovated and theyput you inthe old rooms. The location was good and we ate something one night in the bar that was good, staff friendly enough.

this hotel should be better. The location is great, the staff is good, but they are overshadowed by the old of the hotel.My room this time had not temperature control. The heater either blew hot or cold air all the time. The carpets and such need an upgrade. The rooms are often old and loud. If you are stuck near the elevator, it's super loud. As in you can't sleep unless NO ONE is using the elevator.The lounge is OK. The staff need to be more present. Not on the computer in another room... The elevators are slower than slow. And stop randomly. Oh, and you have no idea if they will stop on your floor because many buttons don't light up.No room service. No idea why, but it sucks. The restaurant downstairs isn't worth your time. Order out if you want to stay in.I'm going to be staying at other Marriotts in NYC from now on, despite the great location of this one. Upgrade and improve and maybe I will come back.

Stayed here over new year with a few friends. The room was a great size - they upgraded us to a superior double with an extra bed. Very clean! I would agree with other reviewers that the WiFi was FAR too expensive, i think it was $16 a day (we went to starbucks in the mornings to get the free wifi). The location was great for working things out, 5 minute (or less) walk to 5th Avenue, right next to Saks and the Rockefeller Centre. The hotel booked us a car to take us to JFK on our departure and it was brilliant (cost us $65 in cash, but you would be paying $56 in a yellow taxi so the extra $9 is worth it for the comfort). Only thing I was gutted about was the lack of room service, as it would have been nice to have our dinner taken to us after a very long day of walking around Manhattan (you have to order at the bar and wait, or wait in your room and go down to pick it up).
user_name:
Lorna R
Aberdeen, Scotland, United Kingdom

review_body: Location is good. For NY, our corner room was nice size. Typical small bathroom. Elevators are small. Three go to lower floors and three to top floors. We were on lower floors. Had to take three elevators to get to gym. We did not have heat one night. Freezing. They came and changed the coil. They have a high tech lock that triggers easily. We couldn't close the door. They were nice and said it has been an issue. Again, it is a great location and clean. The M Club is very nice. Just an older property.

During Christmas we visited New York and stayed in the New York East Side Marriott hotel.According to us it was a good stay. We were located in a room on the 25th floor and different from what others wrote here we did not have to wait extremely long for the elevators, at least not more then 2 minutes which is reasonable in my opinion.The service was generally OK. Compared to European standards it was a little less then we are used to. For example we arrived in the night due to a delayed flight and we had some problems with the automatic door. There was a piccolo outside and although he apparently amused himself with us, he did not offer us to help nor he wished us a good evening. Inside the receptionist was hidden in a corner and he did not attend to us only after we greeted him.The rooms where great with a great view over the city. Weird enough the bathroom was a little cramped compared to he size of the room. The concierge was of great help and provided us a subway map and some information about the area. On the last day we were able to extend the checkout only till 2PM so we decided just to store the baggage downstairs instead because our flight left in the late evening. Due to its location this hotel is good option. The service should however be improved a bit to get to Marriott's standards.

We stayed for a weekend in December, and found this to be a great location for this time of year. Mid-way between most of what you want to see, and only a few blocks from Rockefeller Center, but a couple of blocks away from the crowds. We took advantage of a very good rate, so we weren't surprised to have an interior room with very little natural light, but it was a decent size and comfortable. There's not much of a lobby, but there were plenty of places nearby to pick up a good pastry for breakfast. We'd definitely consider returning.

Efficiently run New York hotel. Staff friendly enough. Central position for everything. Bar and restaurant not cheap and long waits for the lifts during peak times. Room sizes good. Times Square a 10 minute walk. Would have no problems staying again.

We read the reviews prior to our stay and not quite sure what to expect - the hotel surpassed our expectations - the location is perfect, within walking distance to lots of attractions and also close to Grand Central station which was ideal for us. The concierge are amazing, we asked them for restaurants, Jazz clubs, days out, directions and they were spot on with everything - our room was a little tired looking but perfectly fine. The only thing that I didn't like was the fact that you had to pay for wi fi in the rooms - its free in the lobby but thats it. The bar staff were attentive. We would have no hesitation in staying here again next time we visit New York - Great! Thank you.

The location of this hotel cannot be surpassed. Mobile check-in the day before arrival made picking up the keys so easy. The room was clean and comfortable. Bell staff is very courteous. Will stay again!!

Most hotels in NY have noisy locations, but this hotel doesn't make use of things like heavy drapes to muffle the noise. The Marriott "at your service" service was a bit of a joke. We had some problems with the TV and the safe and they remained problems throughout the stay. Finally you can grow old waiting for the elevators.

I don't believe I can applaud the staff (the ones I encountered) at this hotel enough.One week before arriving I called the hotel and spoke with both Cynthia and Candy requesting specific accommodations to help make the stay more enjoyable.Both of these individuals went past my expectations! I could not have asked for anything superior to what I received at this hotel.... all while using Marriott points for 5 free nights Christmas week!People at check in desk were both helpful and pleasant.... not something you always encounter in New York City. The concierge lounge staff (especially Margaret) were superb, constantly hustling to ensure all visitors were enjoying their stay here.Housekeeping always smiling and greeting with a friendly hello. Jenny (very pretty smile) dropped what she was doing to help us with a minor issue in our room.I want to thank all personnel I encountered for making the stay an exceptional NYC visit for my wife and me!Will absolutely come back here again!

I stayed here with my wife and three girls. The rooms were average. The hotel is very old and tired. It's an ok location. Service is very poor from the check in to the restaurant staff. The bar service is extremely poor. Specifically Jose. He was extremely lazy and treated not just us but others around us very rudely. The auto tipping is extremely upsetting.

have stayed there twice. Either ended up with a small room or a special needs room. Dingy hallways and rooms. A disappointment. Convenient to the Waldorf and other main areas including Times Square. Crazy crowds during holiday season. Very small lobby and no room service

We stayed on the 29th floor facing Lexington. I've stayed in a lot of hotels and this was one of the quietest hotel rooms I've ever stayed in. It was also very dark with the blinds shut so we slept like babies. The hotel room was clean and spacious and if we needed anything, the front desk responded quickly. Location was great, 15 minute walk to Times Square, close to loads of restaurants and taxis always at the ready. We preferred being away from the crowds. The lobby is pretty and small which I prefer. Zero wait at check in. The staff were all friendly. We didn't eat in the restaurant because we could find way more affordable places to eat but that didn't bother us because we were out and about all the time.

Check in and Check out were both easy; I did use the Marriott app to check in and check out. The room and bathroom are both small just like a typical New York Hotel. There is no room service, you order and go down to the bar for your food which is presented in a food container within a plastic bag.It felt more like a Courtyard than a Marriott. The rooms on the lower floor are noisy. You hear everything from the street, if you are a light sleeper, don't plan on getting any sleep. The breakfast was buffet and I don't like was worth the price, the food was ok but not great

I'll begin by saying that my friend booked this room for this trip, if I had known there was no room service - I NEVER would've stayed there. I'm an avid coffee drinker and whenever I travel I order coffee from the hotel via room service. The rooms are very small and the lobby is equally small. The shower was not draining properly, which is all sorts of gross to me. After calling twice, it was fixed. The floor in the room had not been vacuumed upon arrival, another turnoff. I paid $7.43 for a soda at the bar....ridiculous! The coffee at the bar, that I had to retrieve each morning was a 2 on a scale of 10. Again, I would not stay in this hotel ever again and I will resume booking hotels for my friends and I.

We paid extra $$$$ for the upgrade to a corner room suite. Unfortunately the room was so disappointing that we will never do it again. We did asked to be moved but they were unable to accommodate us so we overpaid again and again for a room that was not worth the price. While the view was great the bathroom looked like something from a poorly designed and executed Home Depot project. There was no counter space on either side of the sink or a shelf or a hook to hang towels. As far as seating, there was one really uncomfortable odd looking chair instead of a couch and the dresser drawers were basically broken. We had stayed at this property before and looked forward to returning, While the staff is great and location quite good, this room was terrible. On the other hand we also had a less expensive room that was actually quite nice and had the amenities and bathroom that should have been included in the suite. Very strange.... We feel ripped off..

I was in town for a couple of days of business meetings and chose the Eastside because of its central location in midtown. It offers good access via subway, cab or even walking to many attractions in the area, along with the businesses I visited. The standard room was adequate, but quite small and it was clean. The hotel staff were helpful, but not overly friendly. I was a little disappointed that the hotel did not offer a full-service restaurant. Of course, when you're in Manhattan, there are many dining choices. But it would have been nice to have been able to have a light dinner and cocktail in the hotel. In the morning I usually like to eat a breakfast in the hotel before departing for meetings. The Marriott offered only a breakfast buffet (included w/room). The buffet was adequate, but nothing special. I did find one very helpful employee, a young man who helped me clean a coffee stain from my shirt. Overall, not what I was expecting from a Marriott.

Near/next to several high end hotels on east side and just south of central park. Can walk to Times Square but is away from the hustle/bustle of the noise of Times Square. Went during xmas and was close walking to all of the high end stores that have the xmas scenes in the windows. No room service in hotel. There is a great local neighborhood feel Italian place (not super expensive) if you go right out of the hotel and right at the corner and it is mid block- San Martin.Small rooms and bathrooms but typical Marriott interior and comfortable bed. Also typical Marriott issues encountered: soap in sink but nothing for shower (a bit stingy with amenities or a housekeeper who wasn't at full attention possibly), non working outlets in bathroom and by mirror at desk so had to have electrician come fix, water in shower went from hot to cold to hot for all of our showers. Also, upon check in at 4pm, room wasn't ready. I have request for no feather pillows/comforter in my Marriott file so they always know it and front desk people mentioned that due to that, the room wasn't ready. After a 5 hour travel in and coming in when check in time is, that is not acceptable and was a bad excuse.

I am here with my family for some theater, dance and opera. Thought this would be a great choice given the location. Mistake!! We are life time platinum members. Stayed in seemingly countless Marriott throughout the world for the last 35 years. Thought this was a full service Marriott. Wrong!!. The Lounge last night had frozen empanadas, a salad they did not refresh, same for cheese. A few chips and nothing else. Ok so what can I say? At 7:15 they brought some frozen spring rolls, and at 7:30 took what was left and put them in the garbage. Then at 7:45 brought some cookies that were obviously from some place that was not very expensive or tasty. :- told my family this was not typical, but is it?? This afternoon ( Just came back from a Museum Trip and wanted some snacks for the family,). Found this "full service Marriott" had no food in the restaurant, it was was closed till 5:30. And no room service either. Full Service?? Guess not. Use to expect a Marriott was a great 1st class choice, especially in NYC, Well not any more. Consider this if you are booking a room here. Very disappointed and confused as a long time Marriott patron. I guess the watch word is be carefully in the future if you book a Marriott. Check what it means?? Ouch!!

This hotel is superb in terms of location, service and amenities, however some updating would not be a bad idea. Located very near Rockefeller Center and Grand Central Station so the location could not be better.The bar prices, even for NYC are a bit too high, we paid $60 for a bottle of wine that I just purchased locally for $8, so if you are there to drink, beware. Lunch is not served in the restaurant or the bar at least on the weekends and the concierge lounge is closed on the weekends as well. Overall it was a good stay and I would return as this was not my first time there.

We needed to stay here for business reasons, it was closest to our meetings. That being said, I wish we'd opted for something a bit different. The hotel was clean, but very old, and the lobby is miniscule, even by New York standards. The elevators were small and weren't always working well. The room was clean, but small, which is typical for New York. However it felt dark, even with all of the lights on, and nothing is creepier than a dark hotel room. there were not enough light fixtures to brighten it up. It was clean, the bed fairly comfortable but it was nothing special. No free internet, even for elite membership in Marriott Rewards. Lots of street noise made it difficult to try and sleep and the room was cold, like the windows created drafts (I had three windows, a lot by a hotel room standard). The restaurant was confusing to find seating for (portion of the table area was closed, only open for breakfast) and the menu, was typical Marriott - nothing New York special. Thankfully, only needed to eat there once, as the plethora of great dining was readily available. I am a long-time rewards member, and while treated well by staff, was a bit let down at this hotel. We had prepaid several months before to lock in the best rate, so we were there for the duration whether we liked it or not.

Nice stay at Marriott. Within walking distance of Times Square, Central Park, etc. If you have trouble walking I would recommend staying at the Marriott in Times Square. Take in a broadway play if you can and don't forget about the off-broadway shows... We have seen some fabulous ones! As far as Marriotts go it was nice but not superior. A bit of a wait at the elevators and the lobby was quite crowded most of the time. Bar area next to lobby. No room service.

I will shop for another option when returning to Manhattan. The room felt old but comfortable. In NYC and Boston you can expect a lot of downtown hotel rooms to be somewhat small and feel like what they are...pretty old hotels that have been remodeled multiple times. This Marriott is no exception. It had a low, popcorn ceiling and 2 small windows...one of which I discovered looked straight into someone else's bathroom if their lights were on and the door was open at night! The bathroom had good shower pressure but the first day of my stay the tub drained very slowly so my shower turned into a bathtub full of water. However, without me asking, this was fixed the next day.The lobby restaurant / bar service was terrible. Our waiter, Enzo, was VERY slow coming to arrange us a table. He was then even slower coming back to get our drink order and was leaving our table before everyone had even ordered. Then he took a long time to come back for our food order. I was unusually on the verge of finding a manager to complain. After poor meal service, they charged someone else's bill to my credit card and had to correct it.The location is excellent. It is a short walk to many Manhattan sites...Grand Central Station, Rockefeller Center, and more. It is in the heart of bustling activity...especially in Christmas season.

The location of the hotel was good but the ambiance left a lot to be desired. The lobby area was always crowded with either people from the streets or from large groups checking in and out. The elevators were extremely slow and also always crowded. I am a faithful, Gold Elite Member, and was very disappointed in the hotel overall as well as our room which had a beautiful view of a brick wall.With so many other hotels to choose from I would not stay in this one again.

This was my first trip to NYC on business and I booked this location through my corporate travel site. I have to say that the rate I paid was significantly lower than the advertised rate on Marriott's website. For that reason, I felt I got a decent deal.The accommodations were sufficient, nothing to really write home about. However, if you're looking for somewhere that is centrally located and within walking distance of basically everything in NYC, this is your place.

This is the my second stay at this Hotel. Came primarily to enjoy NYC and all that it offered during the holiday season. If you are looking for a modern trendy hotel, this is not it. However, the rooms are clean, comfortable and basic and for my purposes fit the bill. Also, the staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The main draw for this hotel is the location. You have easy access to the Lexington Avenue Subway line, Grand Central Station and only a short walk to Rockefeller Center where you can view the Tree. For breakfast you absolutely must go to Essa-A-Bagel on 3rd Avenue on 51st Street. Bagels are to die for. For dinner you can walk to 2nd Avenue and find many fun neighborhood restaurants and bars that won't break the bank. My only complaint is that you had to pay for WIFI in the Room but it is free if you go down to the Lobby. Considering room rates, one would think it should be a perk of staying in the Hotel.

This will be the first really negative review I have written for any of the hundreds of Marriott properties in which I have staid as a Platinum Elite member of their frequent stayers program. And, I have staid at this property probably eight times in the past! What has changed??? Firstly, the property is just tired compared to other up to date hotels these days. Then to my shock, surprise and inconvenience, they have discontinued room service. Can you imagine any hotel in New York City where people may choose to not go out to eat for a myriad of reasons, not being able to pick up the phone and order a quick snack or some substantial meal to be brought to their room. Plus, I picked this hotel through the Marriott reservation site and there was NO notice that there was not room service. OK - so I tried to eat at the restaurant. Guess what???? There is no real restaurant. It is some cluttered area of fake wooden tables adjacent to the bar where on a Sunday night at 6:30 pm, not another person was dining. I guess that was my real warning. Looking at the menu, there were meager selections and nothing of any real interest for a good dining experience. So I did the best thing I could, treated myself to an incredible Filet Mignon at the nearby Smith & Wollensky's. I am certain this was a better choice by far than eating at the Marriott anyway. I have already told this property I will not be staying as a guest on travels to Manhattan in the future. It is a shame since it had been a reasonably priced, pleasant mid-town Manhattan hotel for convenient use in my past. I will look into other mid-town Marriott properties of which there are plenty for any future stays while in town.

If you are expecting Marriott standard you will be disapointed. The hotel has a 80's feel and defenitely needs a make-over. The location however is great, within walking distance of everything you need for your NYC visit.

I stayed at the Marriott East Side for the first time and it was a total mistake. Apart from its central location, there is nothing good about this hotel. No minibar, no amenities, even not providing an umbrella when it rains. It supposed to be an upscale hotel but was a total failure and I hope I will not be obliged to stay here for a second time... A small tip, next door is Hyatt Lex 48 and it is a way better hotel.

Went out last summer for the US Open with one of my best friends -- girl trip in Manhattan over Labor Day! While I love the location and the Marriott brand, it definitely needs some help. It's a great place to stay, as you are in a super safe neighborhood, and can walk around at night without worry (at least I do). Great restaurants and landmarks abound. Cool lobby with interesting travelers. Wonderful breakfast with nice servers, helpful. Comfortable lobby to meet friends in -- etc. Our room was....interesting, and the layout was awkward. We had 2 doubles/queens and there was a dresser with a TV on it that was literally 4.5 inches from the end of the bed. We kept snagging our clothes on the dresser knobs while walking past! There was funky white stuff on the headboard (ew!) and we left a note and tip for the maids each day, and it was NEVER cleaned off. More than this though -- we had serious problems with several staffers. Holiday weekend, lobby bar, Sunday night (Monday being Labor Day) and there are maybe 10 guests drinking. The floor manager decides to close the bar early, and send staff home! We sat there for another half hour while guest after guest came in for a drink...and we had to keep say, nope, it closed early! Crazy. Guess she wanted to get home. We asked the 2 check-in clerks where the closest corner shoppe was so we could get a bottle of wine for our room, and they were horrible, snotty and not helpful at all! Awful experience, so bad, we actually met with the GM the next day and he took our comments super seriously. We also had the clerk at the breakfast bar (what is the bar at night) tell us the auto tip (when signing coffee to your room) didn't go to him, but to the daytime bar staff! So we gave him an extra cash tip, and then found this out to be false! That's stealing. Leaves a bad taste. I trust, however, that the GM of this property is doing all he can to make it right. I'll definitely stay again, it's a great choice for Manhattan! Have fun!

We stayed here during the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade and this property was perfect. Their staff was always there offering to help. This was one of the most helpful staff I have ever incountered in all my travels. The location is just great for walking around. I would certainly recommend it and will stay there again when back in New York. We had two full beds and plenty of space to walk around. The size of the service counts more than the size of the room.

The hotel was immaculate, the lobby welcoming with the fireplace. We did not however get a room on a high floor as requested. It was so noisy , we did not sleep at all for 2 nights. At $280 per night, this is unacceptable. They did not honor our request for a high floor at all.

This hotel is NOT luxurious and doesn't pretend to be. It IS, however, located in one of NYC's best spots and easily accessible to wherever you want to go. For the price - you can't beat it! It's always very busy and sometimes hard to get help with questions, etc. The room seemed a little cramped but if you want luxury at twice the price, you'll easily find another place in the city. Found the staff most helpful during the rush hour to get a cab - which seemed almost impossible. The doorman made it look easy. Internet in the room was a plus.

Great location to explore NYC Has a great classic entrance and the staff and the concierge really make up for some of its failings. Room was small but warm and a had a hot powerful showerStaff are helpful and attentive Look out for the concierge service from Ann and JC-they really know they stuff and can get tickets in sold out showsNeeds a bit of an update and some of the decor looked tired

Literally!! The room was very small and noisy. Yes, it is NYC but the traffic noise and the wind howling through the windows led to many interesting dreams. The water in the bath room ran from warm to cool like in a cycle, both the sink and the shower. The wall paper was peeling in some places. Much less than I would expect from a full service Marriott especially at the rate charged.

We checked in on Nov 15, and had a very rude man check us in. Was not friendly or helpful at all! Hotel has been refurbished over the years, lots of people will find it charming, even though it has a terrible layout. Some elevators only go to certain floors, yet the elevators are pretty much side by side. We had a room with 2 doubles, although my travel agent said she booked a king. One bed was absolutely terrible, I shared that with my daughter, and the other bed was pretty good, which my husband slept in. Room was a good size, likely bigger than some apartments in NYC. Bathroom was large, with peeling paint and no bathroom fan. Breakfast buffet was not included in our hotel, and it was $34 per adult. The food was good, but the price was absolutely ridiculous. Noise outside was terrible, I am in NYC often for business, and have stayed at much quieter hotels. All in all, I would NOT stay here again, nor would I recommend it to anyone.

Just got back from Thanksgiving weekend in NYC and had a very pleasant stay at the Marriott, its not the best accommodations you can get in the big apple, but for the price it is the best value.Great midtown location, 49 & Lexington, you can walk to Times Square, Rockefeller Plaza, Grand Central and of course all of Midtown in 5 minutes. You are surrounded by great restaurants within a block or two, Smith & Wollensky, Bull & Bear, and so many other great places.The property is nice and clean, the rooms are typical Marriott. The sleep quality was good, but for the price it was GREAT...
user_location: La Fortuna de San Carlos, Costa Rica
user_name:
sircaralot
La Fortuna de San Carlos, Costa Rica

review_body: Stayed in Marriott in October 2014. Great location but rooms were a little jaded. Breakfast was surprisingly expensive so skipped it totally. Perfectly good deli just across the road - got breakfast there 4 mornings spending approximately $30 for 3 of us each morning verses appox $50 per person per breakfast at the hotel..
user_name:
John G
Ireland’s Ancient East, Ireland

review_body: Nice hotel option to the W. Next Door. Convenient if you want to get away from all the traffic near times square. Bell staff and front staff is good for a NY hotel. Rooms are small - but this is very typical of all the NY area hotels. Probably larger than average for a NYC hotel room. Generally one of my first choices of places to stay

This is a good hotel in a location that suited our needs this trip. It's close to the 6 subway and Grand Central. We didn't pay for internet (gold Marriott level) but travelers should know it's $17 per day. We had access to the M Lounge which provided a super breakfast and snacks and dessert at night. Our room was in the corner with 3 windows (interior so not much of a view but very quiet) and two beds. Amenities included coffee machine, fridge, hair dryer, ironing board...everything you would expect. Lots of big towels and the housekeeping staff did a great job every day. The staff (from front desk to bar to lounge to bell staff to doormen to housekeeping and maintenance) was very friendly and polite, especially considering it was Thanksgiving weekend and very busy. They always greeted you and offered to help. This was my second stay here and I would stay here again if I needed to be on the east side. We didn't experience any elevator issues although obviously at some times they were busier and you had to wait a moment for the next one.

Marriott East side is located in mid-town and close to the business district. The check-in service was efficient and I got lucky as I got room on a high floor. The room was spacious by mid-town standards. The room had a nice king size bed, sofa, office table and a good bathroom with tub. Given the month and temperature being sub-zero on Celsius, the heating was good. However, it was very noisy and caused me disturbance in my sleep (on top of jetlag). Also, given the weather, absence of hotel slippers was felt - as walking in bathroom tiles had its cold effect. The shower should also consider having a powerful geyser (though the one provided was ok on hot water). The lifts are noisy, slow and takes a long time to come up. It certainly needs upgrade. The check-out was quick and efficient. The hotel does not have room service (which is a shame); however, they suggested calling seamless.com to order food. I should say this was a great idea.I could choose from wide variety of restaurants and the delivery was to the room. Overall, I would consider this a functional business hotel A bit better than courtyard but certainly not to marriott's standard.

We used Marriott points to book this stay, so I wasn't surprised when we had a very basic room next to the elevator. Very basic.Other than that, the only comment is about the elevators: more are needed. During peak hours it is impossible to get an elevator. We waited fifteen minutes for one during peak checkout time; we bullied others into letting us on! We were at the hotel two nights - that translates to many peak hours.

They could not find our reservation during the check in process. Very frustrating. Set a wake up call at 7:30 and they called at 7:00. The concierge room was nice. The food served was tasty and diverse. At times, there was a long wait for an elevator. The beds are comfortable but the rooms are dated.

We went to celebrate a few 30th birthdays and this hotel appears to be ideally located to take in all the main attractions NY had to offer. It certainly was ideally placed for this, easy walking distance to Empire State, Rockefeller Center, Times Square and Central Park. Very comfortable rooms, memory foam mattresses! The only thing that let this hotel down was the bar, service and opening hours. The bar closes at midnight, even to residents and the automatic service charges that were applied even if they got the order wrong.

I went with my husband to New York. This was a business trip for him and I tagged along. This hotel is centrally located to many of the sites in the city. The hotel rooms are on the small side, but clean and quiet. I stayed next to the ice machine and the elevator and it was still very quiet. I would suggest a room on a higher floor to stay away from the street noise. The internet was an additional cost per day. No wifi. I was able to look up some things on my phone. I am a walker, so from here you can walk to Central Park, Rockefeller Square, Grand Central, Times Square, and the Theater District. I walked to the Lower East Side (Chinatown, Little Italy, etc.), but this is about 1.5 hour walk. It is easy to catch the subway close by. There is a store across the street to get a quick inexpensive meal, snacks or items you forgot. The restaurants nearby seem expensive, but I didn't do my research on this. The concierge is extremely helpful. Take the Airport Shuttle to/from hotel to save some money. This hotel is expensive per night, unless staying on the weekend.

This hotel was packed on the weekend, more of a hotel for tourists. Lobby is like a supermarket. Infrastructure is outdated. I had to take 3 different elevators to get to the gym, and there is no way around it!! Elevators are slow and hard to come by. This place is all about the location. A 3 star for business travelers and 4 for leisure because of the location.

I liked the clean rooms and they were up to the standards Of any 3 star hotel. Liked the ambience of the lobby. Very helpful staff.Now comes the hard part...I would expect $450 room tariff will at least fetch fixtures that are not rusted... The water in the bathroom went down the drain so slowly.... At one point the bathtub was flooded...And the room was so small that I barely had space to keep the one large suitcase I took with me. There is no room service what so ever ... While all the nearby hotels offer the same.So all in all.. Less than average experience for the price and ok experience otherwise..

The update of the Marriott East Side has finally been completed. Though the hotel looks as good as ever, the change apparently isn't that dramatic. The biggest changes are the bar/restaurant and the concierge lounge. The gym on the top floor is a wee bit cramped, but it has a lot of equipment and the view is spectacular. Unfortunately, the new restaurant is a disaster. Even as a platinum member, the hotel charged me $35 for a buffet breakfast that featured dry scrambled eggs (no omelet station here!) and the most disgusting potatoes I've ever eaten. The restaurant doesn't even offer a menu option for breakfast. Sadly, like so many other Marriotts, this hotel has outsourced its food service, with typical awful results.

My brother and sister in law recently celebrated his 40th bday in the city and stayed at the Marriott East Side. I wanted to do something nice and have dessert sent to the room before they kicked off their night out so I called the hotel's restaurant, 525 Lex. Brian, the restaurant manager could not have been nicer. He took care of everything and made sure the sweets were delivered when I asked. Great customer service

We stayed 3 days in this hotel. Room was very nice. We were on high floor, so it was quite calm. Well located. I just had one problem with a computer at the business center, but the Manager was very nice and it all work out at the end.

We booked Marriott East Side which is at junction of Lexington and 48th on East Side. It's a great location within easy walking distance of the Rockefeller centre, MOMA, 5th Avenue, Central Park and Broadway.We read reports from other visitors complaining about :-1. Noisy rooms2. No room service3. Shabby furnishingsWe stayed in a 1 bed junior suite as there were 3 of us. We were on a low floor (7th) which concerned us about the noise aspect when we arrived, However it was completely peaceful. Key thing is to ask for an inside facing room - there's no view but more importantly there's no noise.Re room service - they clearly could not make this economical as the hotel is surrounded by excellent cafes and restaurants. Ashley's Fine Foods over the road seemed to be open 24/7 and always had freshly cooked noodle and rice dishes to eat in or take out - we used this several times as so convenient.The furnishing in the room was perfect - nothing looked too old. Lighting wasn't great but it was an inside room so probably to be expected.Staff were all friendly. JC at the concierge desk helped book our transfers and sorted out some tickets for us.

The hotel is nice and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. Our well-appointed room looked recently renovated and had the usual comfy pillow-top mattress and duvet covered comforter. It wasn't exactly roomy - just adequate space. Our room was rather long and narrow so felt just a bit claustrophobic. If you are not a concierge member, you will not get free breakfast or WiFi. At the time of this review, the WiFi was a hefty $19.95/day. Ouch! A coffee in the cafe will set you back a lot. Go to the nearby Starbucks! The elevators are very small and very slow with two sets serving different floors of the hotel. They were often quite crowded. Seating in the lobby is rather limited so if you are waiting for a friend you will likely find yourself standing. The hotel is reasonable walking distance to the train so not too hard to get around NYC. I'm giving the hotel four stars because there is nothing overtly wrong about it but I have a lot of other faves in NYC that I'll return to instead.

Good location, polite and helpful staff, very comfortable beds. Absolutely up to Marriott high standards. Plenty of restaurants and bars nearby. A must is a visit to Grand Central station, only a few blocks away.

I have been to different concierge lounges in Marriott hotels, but this one was by far, the best. Roomy, clean, and the staff was superb. The hotel's location is prime, out of the Times Square mayhem. Many nice stores on Lex and restaurant options on 3rd.

We have stayed at this hotel 3-4 times per year now for awhile- always an enjoyable stay. The location is particularly convenient to the 5th ave shopping, east side hospitals, and the Lex Ave subway. We have always found the rooms to be very clean and the housekeeping staff alays helpful with extra towels, tissues, etc. What makes this hotel stand out is the M Club Lounge and the staff theer, especially the hostesses. They are always working to make everyone's stay special with smiles, warm greetings, and helpful advice - always freely given. Some of the rooms are a bit small - this is typical of the Lex Ave hotels.Try to reserve or request a larger one if this is an issue. However, they are all very up to date and quite comfortable. Noise levels are typical of most NYC hotels (e.g., sirens). If noise is an issue for you, then stay away from the lower rooms facing Lex Ave (upper floors are quieter).

The check-in process was fine - the people at the front desk were friendly, got us an early check in to a room, and the bellman brought our bags up quickly. The lobby is perfectly fine, the location is very convenient. The room felt fairly dingy and in need of an upgrade - though I think this is true of many hotels in this area of NYC. I decided to check the mattress in our room and discovered that the mattress itself was significantly stained. We asked to be moved to a different room on a different floor and experienced the same thing. At that point, we decided not to stay in the hotel given significant concerns about cleanliness. They allowed us to cancel our room without penalty, which I appreciated, but did not feel like they were sufficiently apologetic or concerned about the quality of the mattress.

Its our first time in NYC, but as we travel worldwide we consider it A proper 4+ star hotel in a convenient place around Manhatan center, especially if you like shopping.Located in a walking distance from many museams, attractions, times square, 5th avenue, library etc.Good services, friendly staff, clean and more than enough warm rooms during winter.You can not consider it cheap, but the price is fair thinking the advantages.

I have stayed at this hotel a few times for both business and personal trips and will continue to return. Great Marriott property in a location close to the park (0.8 miles away), a subway station (2 blocks) and walkable distance to 5th ave shopping and midtown attractions. Service was fantastic. Rooms are nice by NYC standards - not huge but clean and typical Marriott decor. My only complaint would be that the elevators can be slow. Other than that I would recommend this hotel and will continue to be a guest there.

beds were really comfortable & service was great ...side tip ...getting broadway tickets from hotel concierge does not save money..better to go to TKTS yourself or get ahead of time before getting the city

This was a family trip staying 7 days in a Superior Double and on the whole the experience was good. Conveniently located with easy access to all the main tourist attractions - most accessible on foot. Friendly relaxed atmosphere with attentive staff. Good sized room with incredibly comfy bed which was huge. Only drawbacks were the outrageously noisy air con which. although effective at controlling temperature, kept me awake all night. Sounded like an aircraft taking off every time it started up.Also the in-room Wifi is expensive at $16 daily. Instead we trudged down to the lobby when necessary where it is provided free. Thankfully there is no pressure to use the bar facilities when popping down to access the free wifi . Would definitely stay again provided the Air con issue has been addressed.

I stayed here with My Wife in February and had an really enjoyable stay. Upon arrival we were upgraded to a Junior Suite which was a lovely surprise and it gave us a much needed extra bit of space. The room was comfortable as was the bed and we found it a really comfortbale and quiet sleep after the miles and miles we covered on foot each day! The staff were polite and attentive but however, I do echo another contributors comments in respect of the Lifts and the restaurant. Lifts were slow and at times it felt like id aged going from the 5th to the Ground floor and vice versa. And service in the bar/restaurant was slow and at the pace they decided. You almost had to shout to be heard or seen.Despite those things we had a really enjoyable stay and would return.

The Concierge was especially helpful; helped make the stay very pleasant.Location is great, close to Times Square, Broadway, Shopping. I felt safe walking back by myself after a Broadway Show as there is plenty of Pedestrian traffic.Rooms are nice - stately old charm elegance.I had free wi-fi as part of my Tour - staff ever so helpful when I had connection problems.

For the good:The staff at check-in was polite. The bed was comfortable.The bad:The elevators are dreadfully slow. The Concierge Lounge felt like a staff kitchen or office break room. Definitely not the CL experience I was expecting. The worst part of the stay however was the restaurant experience. The bar tender all but ignored me. It took 10 minutes to get a channel changer to turn on the World Series game 7. When my overpriced medium burger came out well done I sent it back. The new one was a little better. To add insult to injury though, 2 pours of Basil Hayden showed up on the check at $55! I was drinking Blanton's single barrel for much less than that across the street at the Waldorf Astoria a couple weeks ago. Having gold status at both Marriott and Hilton, I'll be back at the Waldorf for next week's trip.

We stayed here for 3 nights in Oct 14. The hotel decor is nice, but slightly dated. The rooms were large for NYC, and very comfortable. The hotel is located a 5 minute walk from central park, and times square etc, and there is a metro stop a few blocks away which was useful. Staff were polite and helpful. Would stay here again when we return!

Great location. The rooms were small and the service was okay for New York. We could walk to most places we wanted to go. Penn Station required a cab ride for us; but that was okay. We did not ever think about eating breakfast it was so expensive. The price for wi fi in the room was so expensive.
user_location: Smith Mountain Lake, Virginia, United States
user_name:
Marie H
Smith Mountain Lake, Virginia, United States

review_body: Rooms are quite big and comfortable. Wi-fi in the lobby doesn't work well, and the price charged for wi-fi in the room is too expensive. Breakfast isn't that special given the high price of it. The best thing is the location. Not sure if I would return to this hotel.

The Marriott East Side is located away from the Times Square and Rockefeller Center crowds, but still within easy walking distance to each. The United Nations complex is nearby and easy to get to. This area is wonderful because it is not as touristed. Grand Central station is a few blocks away. Ess-a-Bagel is 2 blocks from the hotel. Can't say enough for the location. Love it! The hotel itself is a classy, old-style atmosphere. The rooms are modern, up-to-date and clean. The complimentary breakfast is good and you can visit the lounge throughout the day for water and sodas. Great hotel and staff!

I stayed at this hotel and have to say that it was a perfect location.I enjoyed the close proximity to anything one can imagine that is relevant in New York.I went to 5th ave, Central Park, Times Square, Empire State Building and more.The room was nice with a view but tiny...The service was ok but cold.The lounge had some nice bar but nothing special (-:

Shocking that the hotel does not provide room service with $300 plus room rates. After a day pounding the pavement, I would expect at least a made bed and fresh towels. What a disappointment. Apparently I need more verbiage to post...so in summary, room found at 7:52 pm like we left it at 9:50 am.

Pro's- Fantastic midtown location, staff very helpful & friendly. Stayed in corner room on lower floor which ended in 03. Room very spacious but lacked in amenities & was dark. As another reviewer stated, "for quitter stay definitely request higher floor." That is a must in midtown Manhattan if you are concerned about noise. Comfortable bed. Lobby is updated as well as "M" lounge but rest of hotel is in need of updating.Con's-My reservation & rate included breakfast. I arrived on Thursday & had breakfast included on Friday morning but "M" lounge is closed on weekends resulting in NOT having breakfast included for the 2 additional days of my stay. I was notified about this upon arrival. Thinking breakfast was included in rate for duration of my stay was part of reason I chose this property. That was disappointing.Rooms are in need of updating. Fabric furniture in room had dark stains, wood furniture in room had dings, finish worn off, was old. All wall surfaces in room & hallways are in need of painting. All carpets in rooms & hallways are in need of replacing. There is no room service. The lobby bar is rated a "C" for sanitation purposes. For those of you that frequent NYC, each eating establishment is rated by City of New York Board Of Health. Acceptable rating is an "A". There are several other Marriott mid town locations. I plan to chose one of those, not the Marriott East Side on my next visit to NYC.

Attended a meeting on site. Found rooms adequate but nothing special. Very limited view. Service was good, but could have been better. Location is nice and price reasonable. Food at on site restaurant was lacking and wouldn't eat there again.

I stayed at this property recently on business. The hotel is in an older building that narrows at the top so the rooms on those floors are quite large and 4 of 16 are on the corners. So ask for a room above the 24th floor or so. The rooms are also very quiet for a midtown Manhattan hotel. The beds are wonderful and you have your pick of pillows. The gym is on the top floor and has a nice view. It is a bit crowded, but it has a lot of equipment and even in the busy morning rush there was no wait. Staff is friendly and helpful. A good choice in a good location, and better, I'd say, than the three hotels right in that area, including the DoubleTree (which is a dump) and the W (where I have stayed often in very small rooms) on the next on the next block. Certainly go visit the bar at the W, but then walk 1/2 block to your quiet spacious room.

The location was fine but I expected more, lack of room service is something I wouldn't expect from a Marriott. The room was small, which is common for NY hotels, but was quite dark with not a lot of natural light in the room itself primarily due to where it was located in the building. Breakfast was also a little overpriced for a buffet. Other than that, an OK stay.

I've stayed at 10 different hotels (all 4 star) in NYC and this hotel is a perfectly fine place to stay in NYC. It doesn't have the gargantuan-tour-bus-crowd-feel, which is a plus to me. Location on Lexington and 48th was convenient, a subway station is at 51st/Lex. Bartender was excellent, wish I knew his name! Housekeeping staff on the 17th floor was friendly and very appreciative of our daily tips. Speaking of which, are hotel guests getting stingy and not tipping the housekeeping staff? Shame! My husband is a Marriott gold member and our room was a corner room, probably a bit larger than normal. It was very comfortable and clean. The bathroom is small, but remember, this is NYC. It was clean and updated. The concierge room was excellent Thursday night for apps and a glass of wine, and breakfast Friday morning was, too. Unfortunately, the lounge closes at 2 pm Friday and doesn't reopen until Sunday evening. The bell staff was friendly and efficient. The concierge is a chatty Cathy and I grew quite frustrated waiting to ask her a question while she spent a good 30 minutes talking to women who had just flown in from California. I saw the same women at concierge desk again the next day and the conversation was just as long, and again, while another guest was waiting to speak to her. This was probably the only drawback my entire stay. Thank goodness for smart phones because I found my answer that way. All in all, I would stay here again.

Nice staff. Parking expensive, even for new York. Nice bar and cafe.Tired hotel. For the money they charge, they need to spruce it up a bit.I would not stay here again. Too many other choices for their price range.

There are more elegant hotels to stay at in NYC. There are Boutique Hotels in NYC with more services. And, there are hotels that house highly rated "Zagat" restaurants. But, for location, room choices, service and overall value, there are few better choices to stay in NYC than this hotel. It's always mentioned that the hotel's location affords you the perfect starting place for any excursion you have planned. Well, that is true. While this hotel has over 600 rooms, it has the feel of a much smaller hotel and an air of quiet and solitude. On this particular trip, my husband accompanied me for his first stay at the Marriott Eastside. He so enjoyed the history of this hotel and the comfort of the room after a busy day in NYC. Most importantly, I cannot over-emphasize the level of service by the employees of this hotel. I have been coming here for several years and still see many of the same faces in the same positions. We especially want to recognize several employees for their outstanding service: Denise, at the front desk, Albert, who showed us to our room, Angela, our housekeeper, Jo, the concierge, and Mike, the head doorman. We save our highest accolades for Mariam, who works behind the scenes, to ensure that your stay is exceptional. Bottom Line: Our recent 6 night stay was more than enjoyable. We will be returning!

I personally like this Marriott more than the Marquis. Great location and decent size room. The hotel is between 49th and Lex, a little bit away from the Time Square hectic scene, but not too far. The hotel is fairly small and it's not difficult to get in and out (compared the Marquis which is like a zoo all the time). In addition, it's generally priced cheaper than the Marquis.

One night stay, great location close to Grand Central Station. Noisy night with inconsiderate guests but room decent as always with Marriott's major city hotels. Didn't use restaurant or bar but staff seemed good overall, would go back on location alone. Gym is excellent even though quite small, lots of equipment and worth a visit despite the complicated journey with two elevators to get there on 35th floor!

I would stay at this hotel again.The lobby is always busy with peopleVery nice bar overlooking the lobbyGood location, you can walk everywhere.The Hotel is safe, for some reason the dead bolt slipped on when I closed the door, so essentially more door was open for fours over the super hour. And my room was right at the elevator. No-one entered my room, So I think its a safe hotel. The rooms were clean, probably updated 10 years ago. But its not showing excessive wear. I would stay at this hotel again. If you need a haircut just walk around the corner on 146 East 49th street, to Gentleman's Tonsorial Parlour - The New York Shaving company. Had a great haircut and they offer a whisky and water while you wait. $30 They also offer shaving supplies and shaving lessons for $40. For the ladies their is a place right next door.

We always try to stay at a Marriott during our travels. So glad I picked the Marriott East Side. Since we are Platinum status with Marriott, and I was celebrating a special occasion, we were upgraded to a beautiful room on the 33rd floor. It was very quiet and comfortable. The M Lounge (concierge lounge) was the best one we have experienced. It was a large room and offered a nice variety of food and drinks. The staff as well as the General Manager were all very accommodating a pleasant. The only negative comment I can make is that the parking fee is expensive. Oh well, that's what happens when you stay in a big city! Other than that, we would definitely return to this location when visiting New York.

I came to the Residence Inn Marriott for a business meeting, and it was the worst mistake I have ever made with hotels. The property in Annapolis is so old and unclean, roaches are climbing the walls, and the managerial staff was so unprofessional. The front desk associate was great. But she was the only good part of m y experience at this hotel. It is a shame Mr. Marriott is not in-charge any more. Boy would he be disappointed. That hotel should be condemned!

Okay, so I get this is NYC and stuff changes. However, this time it's for the worse. For 12 years, this hotel has been a top choice for when my business takes me to midtown. I rarely get an upgrade for my status, but overlooked that for location and good service. The service is GONE and now seriously looking for other choices.Pros: all left is location.Cons: no room service, no recognition of Marriott status, tired gym, prices higher than many similar and true full service hotels, rooms getting old.I hate to ever say this, but this may be my last visit to this once famous hotel.
user_name:
ther0nt
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Just experienced the new M Club Lounge at the New York Marriott East Side. It is fantastic - modern design, great food and nice vibe. If you are Gold or Platinum, you have to stay at the East Side Marriott when in NYC....or if you are not, do yourself a favor and upgrade to an executive room at check in - worth every penny!

I stay in a full Marriott expecting to take advantage of my platinum status and a full service hotel. Otherwise, a Courtyard would do just fine for a lot less. The Marriott East Side fell right in between. First, I did indeed get upgraded. I have stayed here before and had a very small room. I was upgraded here to a corner room on the 26th floor easily twice the size of my last room with a separate sitting area and plenty of space. Nicely appointed bathroom, updated fixtures, the room was great.First change was that my status entitles me to Concierge Lounge access. As with many Marriotts, it was closed for the weekend. Normally, I get breakfast coupons to the restaurant in this situation. Here, they gave me an extra 1000 pts. Since the breakfast in the hotel was $34 that was not a good trade off. There are good options in the area, but it took me 40 mins to run around in the rain and get something to eat and some coffee at a reasonable price. Second, was there is no Room Service. You can place an order at the restaurant and go down and pick it up yourself. Annoying, but not a big deal. What made no sense to me though was the 15% gratuity automatically added to the check. I was the one running up and down the elevator to fetch my food. What am I tipping for? There was no service. I mentioned this at check out and the clerk seemed quite surprised and said she would mention it to management. New York City is expensive, I get that. But there are some things going on here which don't feel right. Certainly tipping for no service feels like Marriott asking you to pay their employees so they don't have to. Include it the rate and be up front about it, that is nonsense. All that said, Hotel is in a great location, well staffed, with doormen and a concierge desk, very walkable to Grand Central, Times Square and the Theatre District. Rockefeller Center is a few blocks away, the Waldorf Astoria across the street. It would be 4 stars if not for the items noted above.

What a great place. I stay here multiple times a year for business travel and simply love it. The staff is friendly, the rooms are clean and the location is great. It's great for both business and leisure travel. Keep up the great job

The room smelled badly and staff people were rude after hearing about it. Do not buy a timeshare from Marriott. They will rip you off in every possible way and say it is just the way we do business. We don't care. We don't have to. We are Marriott.

The hotel while charming is just old and needs a face lift. Valet took an hour for our car (stated 30 mins). The hotel shampoos/soaps are disgusting "aromatic woods" collection. Why would I want to smell like musky woods? Also no room service unless you are a Gold or Platinum member. disappointing! Not what I expected from a Marriott property for 750 a night :(

What nice, sweet people from the doorman to housekeeping! Right off the bat, I asked for a high floor, quiet room, view of 49th and Lexington, corner room...and get this, we got there about ten am and they checked us in! All my picky demands were met, plus this wildly early checkin, and here is the really piggy part....it was all free on loyalty points, three nights for120,000 points. We must be the manager's worst nightmare! Shirley at checkin was the angel who arranged for all this I believe. Maids wrote Ty notes for tips, which was nice. Forgot to replenish coffee fixings once. I couldn't find a way to open the large area of the safe, thought maybe it doesn't open to take a computer...seemed like just the top drawer opened. Closet doesn't have room for clothes and safe and ironing board and hair dryer....but these complaints are really silly. Staff wonderful, room enormous and comfy, verizon service great, used my own wi fi so idk about that....doorman got us a car instead of cab to airport and that was FABULOUS. I don't know why other reviewers are complaining, I adored this place.

Hotel in a great location in NY. Close to Rockefeller Centre, Time Square and Grand Central Station. Good size and clean bedrooms.To save money breakfast at Au Bon Pain at 595 Lexington Ave. and not in the hotel

Don't stay at this hotel, it shouldn't be part of the Marriott brand. I only stay here when my preferred hotels in Midtown are full. This hotel's only redeeming factor is location. For business, you are in the heart of Midtown. For tourism, it's a reasonably short walk to the Rockefeller Center, Central Park, Bloomingdales, Grand Central Station, and more. But location is the only thing this hotel offers. The building is old, tired, and rundown. The elevators are small and cramped, and don't stop at every floor. To get to the fitness center, for example, you take an elevator to the 32nd floor, then take another elevator the 35th floor, then walk up stairs to the gym. Although the lobby has been recently redone (and nicely redone), the rooms and hallways are small. Each of the 3-4 times I've been here this year, my room has had been musty. Only a few rooms have any view, most look out at an nearby office buildings or into an ugly interior courtyard/rooftop. There are not enough power outlets in the rooms. There is no room service; you have to eat in the hotel restaurant in the lobby. What prompted me to write this review was a recent stay where I discovered (in the morning) that my bathroom had not been cleaned from the last guest. When I pulled back the shower curtain to turn on the water, I found a dry and crusty washcloth in the bathtub, along with hair and soap scum. Gross, and that means no shower today. The staff was apologetic when I called to tell them of the problem, but there was nothing they could do.If you are wanting to be loyal to Marriott but need to be in Midtown, stay at the Hotel 57 (at 57th and Lex, a Renaissance property). If you want to be in the Midtown area, stay at the Marriott Marquis (in Times Square). And if you aren't worried about loyalty programs, stay at the Washington Jefferson on 51st. Also, be aware having prefered status with Marriott doesn't matter to the staff. I've never been upgraded here, where the Hotel 57 down the street moves me up 2 and sometimes 3 levels of room any time I stay. But don't stay here - it's a waste of your money.

I stayed here twice this year mainly because I'm a Marriott Gold Club member (at least for 2014). I'd stayed here once before this most recent stay, in February this year, and was a little unhapy about my stay because at first Marriot had screwed up my Gold Card membership and the hotel did not give me its benefits. When this was straightened out I had already missed the chance to get a room upgrade which comes on check-in. (This was not really this hotel's fault because the Central Marriott office had accidentally removed my Gold Card membership; the next day I was able to reach them and get it reinstated). That stay eary this year ended up being ok though, adequate, despite its bumpy start. The Marriott Club Executive lounge (which members have access to) at that time was very crowded, in fact completely full in the morning for breakfast and as such was rather uncomfortable.When I stayed here again in September (2014) I had a much better experience. It looks to me like an entirely new, or newly remodeled at least, executive lounge with much more space, better breakfast and overall a much nicer place to spend time. (The lounge is not open weekends, except for Sunday evening). The hotel room itself was comfortable, in fact quite nice for the reasonable price I paid (for a Manhattan hotel room). (I tried expending my stay online to include weekdays but the price was double for these, due I think the the UN General Assembly taking place then). Also I was not able to get a late checkout, which normally Gold Card members have no trouble getting, because the hotel said these were not available due to the UN General Assembly meeting. Still this stay was a good one.The hotel is conveniently located in Midtown, a few minutes from Grand Central and its many transportation options.My only complaint on this last stay was that after I arrived at the hotel, sometime after 11PM on a Friday as I recall, the fire alarm in my section of the hotel kept going off, to be followed by an announcement that there was not actually a fire. This happened about three times before it finally stopped. As I had just arrived it wasn't a big deal, but for anyone trying to sleep before this time it would have been unfortunate.I will look to stay here again potentially on my next trip to Manhattan. I rate the hotel only "average" because of the whole set of experiences I've had, but I'm optimistic that in the future I will be able to rate it above average if some of the quirky less positive things don't happen again.
