It was a pleasurable stay at Marriott East Side. My daughter and I were coming in NYC for an audition and they allowed us to check in super early, 7a. What a great relief to get rest and ready before the audition. Thank you, Marriott!Our room was clean and comfortable.

I stay at Marriott because it is usually reliably high quality from one hotel to another. I was disappointed with Marriott east. We needed to switch rooms initially because the first room backed up to the elevator banks! The second room was small, no light in the closet, and toilet supplies,coffee cups were not replaced. The cable reception was spotty. The lobby decor was dated. On the positive side, the staff was excellent and very helpful given that my complaints are beyond their individual control. The location is excellent.These deficiencies ought to be easily correctable

I just love this place! Normally when I stay in New York it's a Courtyard Fairfield etc. because the Marriott Eastside is priced out of my range. I do always check and luckily for this stay it was in line. Location is perfect, at least for me. It is on the east side, away from a lot of the noise and crowds but easily accessible. There are tons of restaurants within easy walking distance.The hotel is best described asstately. There is a uniformed doorman out front, and the architecture is old and impressive. The staff is always friendly, the lobby is addicted out in red carpet and wood. You feel like you're arriving at a classy establishment, very different from typical chain hotel.The rooms can be variable. Understand had a corner room, high up with a nice view of the Chrysler building. The room for me was large by New York standards clean and comfortable with a shower and tub. It was very quiet.I had concierge lounge access for breakfast, which was great selection of eggs other hot items as well as cold.This is a great choice for those coming to New York and wanting a special experience but not wanting to pay $500 a day.I guess you can tell I like it here!

A "girls weekend" of shopping, walking, sight-seeing and fun, staying in this hotel was perfect. One flew in, now came by train, and we met up at the Marriott. Our room was ready early, a blessing (it always is). The maids are fast, efficient and the bell captain always seems to have cabs at his fingertips, the 525 Lex (bar and light restaurant off the lobby) is perfect if you are foot weary and don't feel like slogging out for a bite but feel like you are not lazy enough for room service.. A great place, our favorite to return to frequently.
user_name:
Anne T
Palm Coast, Florida, USA

review_body: At my daughters request, we took a trip to NY for her spring break (she is not quite 8 so this was surprising). I had called a month prior to request a room on a high floor with a view however, apparently the request wasn't relayed correctly (7th floor, no view right next to the noisy elevator). The 2nd night I requested to be moved and my request was granted in a BIG way!! We were moved to room 3207 which had 3 windows and a breathtaking view of the Chrysler Building. The staff, room cleanliness and surrounding area was fantastic and I will definitely be returning soon!!

This is an older building, but Marriott has it very nicely done. The rooms, while small as is to be expected for NYC, were clean and well appointed. Comfortable bed, and the common areas well kept and the staff what I call typical Marriott (professional and courteous). The location is perfect. We were in town for a 2 night stay, to hear the Munich Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall and generally wander around and relax. The location is great. Very close to Grand Central, Rock Center and surrounding areas. Also quite close to the UN (not that I cared). Very close to a T stop if that is how you want to get around. Cab ride from Penn Station to the hotel is about 10-15 bucks. I would stay here again if the opportunity presented itself.

We stayed at this Marriott Hotel this past weekend and there's quite a bit to write about--but first, I'll focus on the good: We drove in from the Philly area to spend the night as we went to a matinee and later on joined family for dinner. We were going to park at a garage, but after inquiring if this Marriott had parking, we took advantage. I'll tell you for the $65.00 charge for the valet parking for 24 hours, you cannot go wrong. Parking is ridiculously expensive at any garage..and don't be fooled..there is always a caveat when you see cheap prices. This deal was excellent. Another plus about the hotel--the location. We needed to get from the hotel, on 49th and Lex over to the West Side--45th between 8th and 9th. It was a great walk--about ten minutes--it would have been less if there weren't so many tourists but since I lived in NYC for many, many years, I've become a very fast walker. If you are planning to visit the city and plan an overnight stay, this location is excellent.Also, the staff was very accommodating. We arrived a bit early and were lucky to get a room when we arrived. There is supposed to be a 30-minute window of time to get your car when you need it--I think we waited less than 10 minutes. Honestly, the staff was very amiable.Now here is where things start to go slightly downhill......we were on the 8th floor and there was a very limited amount of elevators servicing the bottom floors--which was a pain because it seemed forever to get a lift--and when they did stop, they were full--the elevators were extremely small. Next..the room. The room was extremely clean, and the bed was, in the usual Marriott way, very comfortable. The room was on the small side, which is expected for Manhattan, but the bathroom plumbing was so noisy. After flushing the toilet, it made an additional flushing noise for about two additional minutes before stopping. Also, the water from the shower would go from hot to cold to hot to cold......Marriott--surely you can do better for a hotel that you are advertising as "luxury"...then..there is the issue with the windows. OK..so the building is old and pre-war. Fine. However when you charge upwards of $350.00 a night, the windows should stop the outside noise. Some time during the wee hours of the morning, we were awakened by the screaming of--I would say--a gang of club kids. The noise went on for a long.long time and my beauty sleep was sorely interrupted. Ummm....a 'LUXURY" hotel has windows that do not allow outside noise to interrupt the sleeping patterns of the hotel's paying guests.The menu for room service was virtually non-existent--unless we were just not supplied with one. I also have to add an extremely daunting issue--for the past 16 years or so, we have been faithful Marriott guests. (you can even read some very favorable reviews I've written on other Marriott hotels). We don't even think about staying at other hotels. However, we had an experience this time around that was the straw that broke the camel's back. My husband inquired as to why he didn't see our rewards points for this stay. He was informed that since we made our arrangements through an on-line discount booking service, we were not eligible for rewards points. He then checked another stay we had elsewhere and the same thing--no rewards points. He called the Marriott Customer Service and was very, very upset with the way the customer service rep spoke to him. Neither of us knew that you cannot get rewards points if you book through a third-party. I'm sure we are not the only people who were not aware of this. As such, if Marriott expects its customers who are in the rewards program, to only book through Marriott, then it is a monopoly of sorts because I never see great deals through the Marriott sites--the better deals are third-party. This prompts me to say "buh-bye" to Marriott. Too bad you lost two faithful customers..but we can find another real "luxury" hotel in the future. Sad day for me...Thank you for reading and I hope my review was helpful in some way.

I enjoyed my first stay at this property. The rooms are small, at least mine was and it was a Classic King room. The room is well appointed. It's an older building so I'm sure that they inherited the current room structure and if it's a historic landmark building, they may have been prevented from reconstructing the rooms. It's in a great area; a few blocks over from Rockefeller Center and blocks away from great department stores: the Flagship Saks 5th Ave., the Flagship Bloomingdales, Bergdorf & Goodman, Barney's, Niketown & Tiffany & Co. It's also close to Grand Central Station. The bed was extremely comfortable. I didn't dine at the hotel but did have breakfast at Café Metro which is a couple of blocks up the street on the corner of 51st St. & Lexington (same side of the street as the hotel). Cafe Metro has several locations in the city and has good food at very affordable prices especially, for NYC. The #6 train stops (Lexington stop) about two blocks from the hotel and it took me about 20 mins. to walk to the hotel from the Penn Station area. Paulina checked me in and was very nice.
user_name:
AJP57
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: No reward points if not booked through Marriott. Noise level in rooms unacceptable. Old facilities. Not worth the Marriott reputation and/or prices. Would not recommend this hotel. At New York prices, one certainly can find better rooms.

I booked an overnight at this Marriott for a romantic weekend. The valet was smooth when we arrived and every time we needed our car. The one challenge is the hefty 30 min required to get the car. When we arrived our room was not ready (it was early, so no big deal). We gave our cell number and went on our way. We also gave our bags to the bell staff. When we came back later, our room was ready. Getting the bags was a challenge. We called down and after a long wait got to the general line (I guess there was no one at the bell station). I asked for my luggage which they confirmed will be sent right up. 45 min later I called again, this time spoke to the bell staff. 10 min later we got our bags. The room itself was standard Marriott fare with a great view. One issue were the windows. They were relatively old and allowed more than a little of the noisy New York street to come in. While I would like to enjoy New York I want my room to be a haven, which it wasn't. The team was mostly top notch and looking to please and help, especially the team manning the entrance starting with the valets as well as the managers constantly looking to assist guests. We enjoyed breakfast in the lounge which was large and well stocked. All in all this hotel is certainly good, the team has a good attitude , but some processes and items need tweaking. I would consider staying here again - hopefully next time the windows would me more noise resistant.

On April 16-19, I stayed at the New York Marriott East Side. This “four star” hotel pride themselves as a “luxury” hotel. Unfortunately, I did not have a luxury experience. After traveling for 11 hours I arrived at the hotel several hours before check-in and asked if it was possible to check-in early given that I have reservations. I was told all of the (629) rooms were booked and that I may want to contact the Wyndham Hotel or Fairfield Inn Times Square. I returned to the hotel later that afternoon and was placed in a double occupancy room with NO sunlight, views of brick buildings and water stains on the ceiling. I asked to move to another room – the second room had a view of a wall and minimal sun exposure. This room had a chain of issues that included water marks on the ceiling in the bathtub/shower, running toilet and clogged drain in the bathtub. Taking a shower was like swimming in a pool due to the poor drainage. Maintenance came to the room to “fix” the clogged drain. Maintenance later voiced that he contacted housekeeping to clean the bathtub after he unclogged the drain. After waiting for 30 minutes we contacted the front desk and asked what time housekeeping would arrive to clean the bathtub/bathroom. We were told that housekeeping was on their way. Thirty minutes later we called the front desk AGAIN to report that housekeeping had not arrived and that we wanted to retire for the day as it was 1am. We spoke with the hotel manager “Neeraj” and expressed our dissatisfaction with customer service and the hotel guest experience that started from when we attempted to check-in early. “Neeraj” apologized (as expected) and offered to provide 100 Marriott Rewards Points to compensate for the inconvenience. (Are you kidding me!? After this experience why would I want to stay at a Marriott hotel?) “Neeraj” did not offer a room change or upgrade or a reduction on the hotel bill. Housekeeping finally arrived 10 minutes after speaking with “Neeraj.”My stay at the New York Marriott East Side was HORRIBLE. I WOULD NOT recommend this hotel to anyone visiting NYC. Given the volume of hotels in the area and the city one would think that the Marriott is aware of the fierce competition and would appreciate their guests. I previously stayed at The Benjamin (a half a block from the New York Marriott East Side) and the W Times Square – both provided first-rate customer service. Denise, JC and John (?? bald guy) were the only hotel representatives that I interfaced with at Marriott who were helpful.

Overall, I found the hotel to be pretty good and would stay here again.The location is probably the best feature. Most major Manhattan destinations are walkable, plus the 4 and 6 subway trains run along Lexington and are only a few blocks away. Grand Central station is also only a reasonable walk away. The tourist crowds in this area of town aren't an issue. The hotel, and my room, appear to be clean. The staff was reasonably pleasant enough. The Lounge was probably my favorite part (for Marriott Rewards members only). The East Side had more food options than other lounges across the country and the food was quite good. On one night, I found it good enough to not even seek dinner afterwards. As is the standard, all drinks (non-alcoholic) are free and a computer is provided for guest access in the lounge.I utilized the gym, which is on the 35th floor and does have very nice views of the city. The facility is very small but has the basics - treadmills, bikes, a few machines, and a small weight rack. It's below average, but it will suffice. If you're hotel room is below room 16, you have to transfer evelvators twice to get there (1-16, 16-32, 32 to 35).The room itself was pretty standard, although definitly on the small side. The room I was provided had two windows, but had zero view. They looked out onto the roof/brick walls/other windows. The windows also had bars covering them, which is never a pleasant feature. I typically expect to be placed a better room than that given my long-time Platinum status.

This was at least the fifth time I've stayed at the Marriott East Side. It's a well maintained hotel located just far enough from Times Square to avoid the crowds, but close enough to get there within a 15 minute walk. The room was in good shape, clean and updated. I had the opportunity to use the Club M which provides snacks in the evening along with an honor bar. The food was okay...hummus, cheese, crackers and a couple of hot hor d'oeuvres. Nothing very special. The one oddity with this hotel is that the fitness center is located on the 35th floor, so I had to take the elevator down to the lobby to get on another elevator to get to the gym. But the gym is fairly well equipped. I will stay here again.

Good location, you can walk to almost anywhere from this location. Fifth ave shopping, Rockefeller Center are very close. Times Square is a small hike, but not bad. It's mostly quiet here at night, the rooms are small but cozy and decently appointed. Overall, it was a nice stay. Also, the staff are very helpful and considerate.

Good location, good service, over-priced bar. Room was clean but a bit dated and the radiator was loud. Nice, small gym. No major complaints, but there was no "wow" factor. Reasonably priced hotel, probably best for business travel and not far from Penn Station.

Nice lobby and very friendly front desk staff when I checked in. Just stayed for the night but this was a great location. Hotel rooms, hallways, décor after you get past the lobby and bar/restaurant are somewhat outdated and nothing special. I always stay at Marriot's and I got a decent deal on this hotel for the night but if I had to pay the posted $350 a night rate for this hotel - I would consider elsewhere in Manhattan and I'm a huge fan of Marriot's. $65 for valet and $17 for internet.

The late night bellman and check in staff were not happy to see us. When we got out of the cab , the bellman pointed imperiously to the narrow windy ramp so we could roll our bags up. When we finished struggling to get our multiple bags to the door, he asked if he could help us with our bags inside. No thanks. As we are "Elite" Marriott members, the desk staff informed us that "this hotel does not participate" in some of the amenities. Once in the room we discovered there's a lot of street noise from busy Lexington. First room in 4th floor was so loud we asked to be moved. Higher up room on 10th was slightly less noisy. They claimed to have no higher rooms. Part of the challenge is the construction in the area, which may improve when the projects finish. Sound abatement would help. Rooms in need of repair. Housekeeping mostly good but sometimes spotty, which is not unusual. Beds need replacing. Balance of staff very nice and concierge lounge good when it's open. Great location otherwise, but we hope not to stay here again at least for a long while.

my sister and bro were spending a couple of nites here before the superbowl weekend and i was visiitng them and it seemed like pepsi had taken over the hotel and only the superbowl guestes mattered. there werent even any chairs to sit on the lobby, the the whole area was taken over by pepsi. the restaurant / coffee shop was under repair....so again..no place to sit.the rooms....average....so not worth the price.overall...disappointed....only the location rocked.

In town for a reunion. Chose this property because of proximity to subway (that back fired. Oh Well) Rarely stay in NYC due to expense. Decided to splurge and this was worth it (for room and amenities) Some negatives: Why do the expensive hotels charge an extravagant price for internet access when the budget hotels offer it for free? And why should BFast at the hotel cost $34 when an equivalent Bfast around the corner was $10?We were upgraded to a penthouse(?) Jacuzzi room a bit larger than lower floors but required an elevator change for access. Did appreciate the quiet of the upper floorAs to subway, MTA closed station closest to hotel for weekend repair work. Could not have predicted when we reservedA bit more expensive but worth it for a NY vacation

Stayed here using our Marriott points and was very impressed with the staff at check in. They were very helpful, efficient and courteous. We were upgraded to a corner room with a sofa bed. The rooms more spacious than I expected for a hotel in Manhattan. The bed was extremely comfortable. I can't find any fault with this hotel, or its staff.

Hubby and I stayed here this past weekend, Saturday April 5th. Paid $150 total on Priceline. Nice room, big for Manhattan standards, clean, etc. Hotel is in good location. Would definitely stay here again!

The Marriott East Side is indicative of the area, quiet, gracious and predictable. This is neither the location nor the hotel for the frenetic activity of Times Square nor the Bohemian quirkiness of SoHo. However, it is a great choice for a stay in Midtown with access to all of the city as it is located just a few block from Grand Central Station and within an easy walk of the 4-5-6 subway lines.Our room, facing another building on the 19th floor, was impeccably clean and very quiet. It is a bit disappointing, as a Platinum member, to not have access to the Concierge Lounge on a weekend, but with a Starbucks a block north and another a block south, morning coffee was readily available without having to settle for the in-room brew.We found the staff to all be gracious, from the front desk agents and security folks in the lobby to the housekeepers, we always received a greeting. New Yorkers do not tend to exude warmth like Southerners, but their reserve is not the same as rudeness.
user_name:
Linda K
Port Saint Lucie, Florida

review_body: Me and my son recently visited New York for a quick weekend trip. We found the property to be updated and of Marriott quality. The Concierge lounge closes on Friday at 1:30, but by 12 noon all food items were removed. This location does not offer a breakfast voucher as many properties for the replacement of the lounge for Gold members. This was a little disappointing. The location is good by New York standards, but depending on where you are spending most of your time, times Square or Central Park seem to be more central. The main reason for the average score was that there seemed to never be enough staff to handle the guests. The bar area had one person working with at least 100 plus people lingering around and the same with front desk questions. To sum it up, not the best, not the worst but would not recommend.

Would definitely stay here again. Room was clean and modern. Location was great and only 4 blocks from subway. Bathroom was a bit on the smaller side, but sufficient. Great staff - would definitely recommend!

This hotel is steady but unspectacular. For a Marriott it is not terribly grand. As NYC goes, the common spaces are typically small in size and rooms are just fine. Service is excellent. Location is prime - a few blocks from Grand Central Station and behind the Waldorf Astoria.

stayed there for one night. Very good value for NY even in March. Smooth check in. Good bar area. Rooms small but efficient. Desk and king bed with flat screen. Bed was comfortable Clean. gym is very nice. Its on East Side Lexington and 48th so you have to walk several blocks to get to times square but only a few blocks up to 5th avenue. It is all walkable as long as not pouring rain. Expensive breakfast at hotel(that is always the case) but right down the street(100 yards away) is Longwood gourmet which offers great breakfast at a great price. I would recommend this hotel as long as it was in the mid 200s.

We had a great stay at the Marriott Eastside. This is a great location on Lexington Ave. The hotel is diagonal from the Waldorf~Astoria where the DCAT convention was going on. My suite was spacious with a nice view of the Chrysler Building. The staff was very friendly. Check in was quick. My room was ready at 11:00 AM when I arrived. I will keep coming back to this hotel.

I've stayed here many times. They provide excellent service, with great facilities. The breakfast is a bit skimpy, but adequate. It is not far to some great sites, including Times Square, Grand Central Station, Park Avenue, the UN, etc.

First let me state that my boyfriend and I were really looking forward to visiting NYC. We've stayed at Marriott locations before in other states, but this by far was not our favorite. Although the hotel is beautiful near the front desk, there was a lady who worked at the front desk who was very rude.....I mean unnecessarily rude. BRIEF DESCRIPTION: She wears a bun in her hair. She made our entrance into the hotel very uncomfortable. OAN: Our room was very small and we did not know we had a refrigerator in our room until the day before we left. The refrigerator is located in the dressers.....who does that? Another thing that was disappointing was the holding fee we were charged. We knew nothing about a holding fee until we arrive at the hotel. We understand that hotels have this type of fee, but it's best to be informed about certain information before arrival. The only good thing about this hotel was the concierge. They were very helpful during our stay. Overall if you are looking for a hotel to stay at in Midtown Manhattan, this is not it.

Stayed here at the last minute becasue a business meeting ran late. Check in was with a young lady who wasn't particularly friendly, but hey, it was late. I Picked this 4* property because I wanted to order room service after a long work day. SURPRISE! No room service. Hey Marriott, you need to re-brand this property so business travellers don't make the mistake I did. Courtyard would probably fit better. Good location near Grand Central. Room ok. Fitness center was an adventure to find, but well equipped. It's just that if I wanted to stay at a non-full service property, I would have booked somewhere else. Instead, I got to pay full service price for a limited service place. Disappointed

I try to always stay at Marriott when travelling in the US or abroad because I have found that there is a basic service that never disappoints. This was not the case at the East Side Marriott where I recently stayed.The disappointment for me was the concierge service upstairs-I believe the 16th floor. The evening cocktail offered Scampi or Samosas, along with cheese and stale broken water crackers. I do not eat seafood or samosas,which in my opinion are specialty dishes, so i had to go outside to the local deli and get some food. You would think a chain like the Marriott would offer something that has broader appeal such as your basic chicken or beef. That has always been the case at almost all of the Marriott chain hotels that I have stayed at where they offer a huge variety and choices, you can just about have a full meal.An even worse experience was breakfast the next morning.Along with eggs and toast etc, they served various pastries. I took a bite into the danish-it was rock hard, must have been 3 days old.I opted for a different kind of pastry, and that was also rock hard, I figured I would try my luck for the third time but the same result.  How does a chain like the Marriott, especially in NYC, have the nerve to serve stale food? The food that was dished up to me at this Marriott was positively the worst I have ever experienced.They will tell you that they will be opening a new concierge lounge soon. That is terrific to hear,but is no excuse for the poor and stale food choices offered at the existing concierge - you still have guests using and paying for the current concierge.If having a concierge service is important, as it is to me,I would avoid this Marriott unless they clean up their act.There are many hotels in the same neighborhood that probably offer a better concierge, - anything has to be better than what was dished up to me at that concierge.On a positive note, the room was fine, clean and comfortable.

I have unfortunately stayed at this hotel three times this last year and each time, I have paid an exorbitant amount for a small, dark and dreary room. This last time, last week, when I checked in, the man at the Elite desk thanked me for my loyalty in being a Gold member and said he had a nice room with a King sized bed for me. I found myself in a tiny room with a window that faced directly onto a brick wall so that in the middle of the day, the room was pitch dark and needed to have the light on just so I could find the bed. The chair was parked in the corner between the wall and the TV (the only place it would fit) and it had no lamp by it (I guess because there was no room for it) and since the overhead light was so dim, the chair was unusable for reading. The service cart was parked in front of my room all day so I had to walk around that in a narrow corridor just to get into my room. This room cost me approximately $400 per night. My team leader picks this hotel not only because he is a loyal Marriott guest and because of its location, but also because he finds the executive lounge a useful place for his team to debrief at the end of business meetings and to talk during breakfast. Too bad the executive lounge was closed and locked Friday afternoon and Saturday when we were there. The service at the bar was terrible - when the waiter at the bar did not deliver my glass of wine 20 minutes after I had ordered it, I went up to the bar and got it directly from the bartender and then the waiter got irritated at me that I had done that! And the bar was not even crowded. I travel frequently on business and stay at Marriotts all over the US and Europe and generally find them clean, convenient and pleasant, but not this Marriott.

I frequently stay at Marriott properties and must say the staff in New York was extremely friendly. We drove into the city and valet parked definitely worth the money. The stylish lobby had limited seating which was disappointing especially around the time we were checking out because the wait was 30 min for our car. . Each day we were greeted by a jolly door man who impressed me with his friendly good morning and his stylish, official top coat. I have to agree with comments about the aged elevators. time be replaced. Our cozy room was a perfect size. located in a quiet area on a high floor. Even though the view from our window was a brick building we were not in the room during the day so we were ok. lots of outlets and good lighting. A huge disappointment was the high internet cost . really $16.95 a day. This property is in a seasoned building but kept up very well as a Marriott. overall a great stay. .

The Marriott Midtown is a wonderful, centrally located hotel in Midtown with easy access to everything! The room was clean and had a wonderful view of Lexington Avenue. It is in a great neighborhood and in good company with other wonderful and popular hotels. The concierge, Kimberly was the best! She made multiple arrangements for us and also had fabulous recommendations for dinner. The staff was friendly and accommodating. We loved our 4 day, 3 night stay! We will definitely be going back to this hotel when in NYC!

Eastside Marriott is a hotel I have frequented on many occasions over the past several years. It's a very average hotel in midtown. The rooms are decent size and typically clean. They could use some updating, but overall, it's a pleasant experience. The beds are comfortable, and the location is fantastic. If you are so inclined, the gym is on the top floor and offers a great view of the city.A couple of drawbacks. The elevators can be pretty slow, I am pretty sure I have waited over 5 minutes in the morning for the lift to arrive-- not a huge deal, but an annoyance. Additionally, the hotel bar is severely overpriced. They charge a mandatory 18% gratuity on everything and the price of the drink boarder on absurdity. An decent midlevel bourbon will cost upwards of $40 (including tax and 18% gratuity)-- or roughly the same price as a bottle. If you do stay here, I recommend going across the street to the Whiskey Blue for your cocktails.

Been coming to this property for years. Is in a great spot for midtown business and financial clients. Good concierge lounge, restaurant is ok, regular NYC prices. Elevators are slow, but what buildings have anything faster? Good prices for weekday business visits. Better than intercontinental across the street.

Conveniently located for the purpose of our trip, with rooms of adequate size for NY. I concur with other reviewers about having to wait for elevators in the morning and evening. My main complaint is regarding wifi: its only free in the lobby and outrageously expensive in rooms.

The New York Marriott East Side is conveniently located and nicely appointed. My room was a double/double and was very spacious and attractive. Good bedding, most TV channels are HD, and a very good concierge floor for premium guests. Staff is pleasant and accommodating. A good choice in New York.

The mixed reviews on trip advisor are a bit scary but when we arrived here we checked in with no problems, nice staff and the lobby had a good atmosphere. Lifts always seemed to be pretty quick to arrive too!Room was very clean and tidy, on 10th floor. No view but to be honest we were hardly in the room in daylight! Used the aircon/heating which worked well too.Shower great, nice toiletries in the room too. Used the fridge to store our champagne my husband had ordered for our arrival! Tea/coffee making facilities in room too. Plenty of plugs (strange highlight I know but with all our phones and camera batteries to charge this was a great plus!!). There were 3 of us in the room and the size of the room/beds was fine.We didn't use any of the bar or restaurant services so cant comment on them. We didn't use the gym (LOL we had walked off all excess calories!) but went up to see what it was like - great equipment but not a soul in it! Looked like it had great views!It's all about Location in NYC and for us this was a fabulous location! Being so close to Central Staion was great but only a couple of blocks from the Rockefeller and 5th Ave etc was great. Really recommend here for a stay if you want a good location at a reasonable price. We were glad not to be staying in the crazy chaos of Times Sq but close enough to walk there easily!

Used the bar one evening for a drink...we werent residents but looked good....2 glasses of white ZIN and a cocktail = $50....tip added too....smarmy service..what a rip offf...avoid this place even if you go to the liquor store!

This was one of the weakest Marriotts that I've ever stayed in. The staff is nice and my room was decent sized for NY. However, my view was of a brick wall looking into other rooms. I assume there are better views in this hotel but I'm gold and this was where they put me so don't count on a nice view :) The concierge lounge was okay but nothing special. The worst part of this hotel is the elevators. In the evening they are slow and crowded. In the morning they take at least 5 minutes and possibly much longer. I had to use the stairs because they are all too full for me to get on. It turned out to be good exercise but this might really bother some people. This hotel clearly needs more elevators or at least faster ones. Make sure you leave plenty of time to get to the lobby in the morning. Kind of disappointing for a Marriott.

Service is great as expected. Rooms are on the small side and definitely could use some touch up in the maintenance and decor department. But overall shower pressure was good, concierge room is fantastic, beds are soft, rooms are quiet and dark. Nice hotel.

We were in the city for only one night so this hotel worked out ok. The staff was friendly and attentive. We were there on a paid rate of $179.00. Very inexpensive for New York City so I can't really complain. We are Platinum members and I called ahead to see if we could get an upgrade to a larger room so that the room with two double beds could also accommodate a rollaway bed (which was an additional $40.00). They were able to do that. When we got to the room I was surprised that this small room would be allowed to hold a rollaway but they somehow fit it in.The hotel is an easy walk from grand central and the location was great for doing what we wanted to do, especially on the East Side. The hotel itself is outdated. The room was the same. I know they can't change the building structure (which could be charming) but a little bit of updates would help. Room windows were very drafty and the heating system clanked everytime it kicked on. We were on the 10th floor and the street noise was loud. But, you are in New York City that is to be expected. The concierge breakfast offerings were very good. Eggs, plenty of Danish/breads, fruit that was very fresh, oatmeal and cereal. Coffee was very good.I probably wouldn't stay here again unless we got a really good rate. I much prefer the Renaissance Times Square.

My daughter and I spent the night here and it was very nice. The staff were very friendly. The room was nice. There was some traffic noise but not intolerable. The hotel itself was very quiet. We didn't hear any noise the entire time we were there. The location was great. We would stay here again.

We chose this hotel based on location and were not disappointed as even during the blizzard we could access public transportation and excellent restaurants were within walking distance. Our room was an extra spacious king and was large by NYC standards yet small compared to other cities. The room was clean, a corner with a view toward Grand Central Station, good elevator access and convenient to the exercise facility which was up two floors. The concierge lounge featured great coffee and an adequate varied breakfast. Evening appetizers were plentiful but not all that healthy and the dessert offering was mainly cookies. The honor bar was adequate to the task. My only real complaint was the inability of the doorman to secure taxi service and that was not really his fault.

Not the best Marriott in the area. Expect noise from traffic on Lexington, slow elevators, average and expensive breakfast. Eye mask and ear plugs needed for a sound sleep. Good location is the best one could say. Fine for a solo , one night stay, rooms are too small for anything more.

I had such high expectations when I chose to stay here, and they were crushed. When you walk in it seems like a very nice place, but then it ends. I had booked a room with 2 double beds and pull out couch.. but when I got to the room it was a king bed with a pull out 'chair' that barely slept 1 person. So 4 people are crammed into this tiny room with one bed, and when I called the front desk to see if they had anything else, all they told me was that they were sold out, and that was it. They didn't even have the decency to put my extra towels and pillows in the room. It took them almost 2 hours to bring them to me after I called. Oh, and the beautiful view of a brick wall just made it just that much better! I was so glad that I was only there for one night, and couldn't wait to check out the next morning. When we did check out, we were waiting for the rain to subside before we went walking with our luggage, and they were incredibly rude about us sitting in their lobby.. even though we were paying guests. I understand that seeing 4 college kids may give off the wrong impression, but we did not cause any disruption and were in town for an important conference and I don't appreciate the poor service.

This is a lovely Marriott in a beautiful historic building. Yes, there are quirks. But the rooms were nicely appointed, and comfortable, and the location is great --right near a major subway stop for the E. train. There are a host of superb restaurants all around--one being the National. The fitness room on the 35th floor has a wonderful view in multiple directions. It is less than 1 mile walk to Times square and Broadway. Would stay here again.Advice to anyone visiting New York City: bring silicon earplugs. There is always street noise which might bother you if you are a light sleeper.

The only thing that wasn't a disappointment about this hotel was the location. Upon entry we immediately went to the Elite check-in where there was little reception. When asked if it was possible to receive an "upgrade" we were advised that there was none available. We had asked for a high floor and was given a room on the sixth floor. Upon opening the door the room was very dark, only to find out it was because the windows faced bricks in an alley. We immediately called downstairs and were given another room, now on the fourth floor. When we retrieved the new key card from the lobby the reception clerk never apologized or hoped the next room would be better. The concierge lounge was well stocked, but it's upkeep needs to be managed. It's not pleasant to be eating your breakfast surrounded by dirty plates or busboys throwing dirty plates on the cart, making tremendous noise. Where is is the hospitality?

Don't let the Marriott site photos fool you. Small guest rooms ala 1925 with new wall paper but clanky cranky wall Heater/AC units keep this from being 4 star and almost led me to rate this three star. Weird Elevator layout means you have to take an elevator to 16th floor, (if your room is on floors 1-15) thence to an elevator to floor 32 thence another elevator to floor 34.Even with my trusty ear plugs I could not sleep until I cut the jackhammer of a heating unit off and piled on the covers.Restaurant was closed- and a crummy buffet was being served in what appeared to be a derelict ballroom (I walked in waited for 5 minutes, no one offered to seat me- then decide to enter myself looked around- did a u turn and ended up at a small Italian restaurant on LEx and 49th). Lobby small- quirky but not in a good way- drafty in the winter and just strange looking with no or hardly any seating.Rooms- small with updated furniture-but nothing could hide the fact that this room (1435) was a small cracker box with windows dirty with hardly an view (one window looked right into another floor of the hotel because of the design). Dark and depressing fortunately I spent no time there. This room was an upgrade (meaning I paid for a better room) I can only imagine what the "base room was like"Bed good Marriott quality and Bathroom okay- small but adequate.Check in was fine.Better choices nearby (Waldorf or "W" across the street might be a better choice). Concierge level nice enough (thanks to my status) but with Wine being sold at $ 8.50 a glass- forget it. Breakfast okay (free in Concierge Lounge) but not great. Keep in Mind I am a loyal Marriott Gold member (see my other reviews) but this is one hotel I will not visit again Marriott Gold membership or points or whatever. bad Value for this hotel (bill of $ 389). Marriott needs to rethink this hotel- not sure how- but it needs help. I cannot imagine people returning out of property loyalty.

I should have seen it coming when I stepped out of my cab. Nobody to help with the bags. There was a "doorman" who didn't open the door, didn't say hello . . . didn't do anything. My room was awful. I am Mariott Gold Elite, so I usually am upgraded to a nice room when I stay at a Mariott. Instead I got an interior, small room at the end of a dark hallway. The room itself is worn, with a desk that looks to be decades old, a desk chair that is broken (i.e. doesn't adjust) and a tv that is set at an angle that makes it challenging to view from anywhere in the room unless you are sitting sideways on the bed. There was no water in the room (either for sale or for free). I ventured up to the vip lounge. It was pathetic. They charged (and not cheaply) for all alcohol. The "deserts" were two types of tiny puffed pastries that looked straight out of a Costco box and strewn about on a platter. I will not stay at this hotel again and it has caused me to consider going back to Starwood for my regular hotel royalty.

Stayed at this hotel MLK weekend and it was nice - staff is very friendly and I love the location. Room was equipped with two double beds and a nice size for NYC. I would stay here again given the chance.

Overall, a great experience. The desk staff was so nice and helped get a birthday gift to me that my family had sent. Great location, nice sized room (great for NYC), very clean. I did have an unusually annoying issue in the lobby lounge. The bartender, restaurant manager and a security officer were leaning against the bar talking when I arrived to have a drink and wait for my sister. No one came over to my table. I deliberately made and kept eye contact with the 2 F&B guys but to no avail. Finally, after about 10 mins, I went to the bar after deciding to leave a paltry tip as a message. The bartender gave me my wine and told me a gratuity was already included in the price. While I tried to decide whether to complain, I saw why the bartender (Steven) hadn't come out from behind the bar. He was wearing blue jeans. Since the manager had been there during my incident he had to have known all of the above so I saw no point in complaining at the time.

Stayed here for one night on business. Room dingy and uninspiring. Mini bar empty and no water. Room service claimed they were very busy so bottled water would take 45 minutes. Room service dinner was frankly revolting . Chips that bent into hairpin shape when you picked them up !! Crab cakes with large lumps of grey indeterminate fish. Not many redeeming features.

This hotel is definitely a great place, because of the way it is managed, and where it is.It has the original charm of what must be the original architecture, but modern style & clean.Small elevator, during busy times.The room was spotless with a good view of city life. Quiet, & comfortable.Staff are pleasant, smiling, & wonderfully helpful.It was easy to walk to sites, and easy to get to the train for further destinations.
user_name:
George K
Washington, Pennsylvania, United States

review_body: As a platinum elite member I returned here again, encouraged by some good rates and their new renovations. The service was awful, and the front desk was horrible; I asked to have a room for family arriving the next night: subsequently, despite my request to give him a nice room, the manager put my brother, his wife & daughter on top of the elevator and they were awakened that night by an abusive man and woman shouting expletives at their door. It persisted despite a call to security, plus no one from the hotel followed up to extend concern despite me even calling the next day to report the incident. Check- in took over 15 minutes and it was still wrong and my room, with two windows facing a wall, certainly not a platinum upgrade as advised. The hotel otherwise was not very busy for the MLK weekend.They put my brother in a room for 2 nights though I kept saying on Sunday we had reserved two rooms for one night. Twenty minutes of various phone calls to reserv. and front desk still did not resolve this. On check out, they were charging us for an extra night: more time spent to resolve this issue.Also, no breakfast for elite members on wknd, and the lounge once opened on Monday was barren (from 9-10 AM) of many of the items (empty platters, no bacon, sausage, cheeses etc.)Overall, the new lobby bar was great, as is their location, location, location. Rooms are small, facing walls, and overpriced even for MLK weekend in NYC, my home town.

Another excellent Marriott. Stayed here for business. Large rooms, clean and nice toiletries. It is about 3.5 blocks from the subway so convenient Midtown location. Concierge lounge offers multiple options for food, snacks and drinks. Plan on staying here again.

We were in New York city for a few shows and sightseeing staying at the Marriott. Everything with the hotel, food and service was good our only complaint was the room we received hardly had a window, the only small window looked out the back of the hotel directly to a brick wall about 5 feet away, if you bent you neck you could and looked around the corner you got a peak at an apartment building basically an fire egress 29 stories up nothing more. The room was also very small. We should have complained but felt that they were probably fully booked and we were not planning on staying in the room. It appeared when they remodeled they compromised quality to get every foot of floor space as rooms.

Stayed here with work and found the hotel to be clean, good sized room, and a good central location. I asked for a room high up and to the back of the hotel (away from Lex Ave) and the staff delivered that up. Didn't eat at the hotel apart from 1 dinner on the first night. Food was OK if rather greasy. It was at 11pm so I suppose more room service style food being plated up. My safe broke (battery ran out in locking system) but a member of staff came up and fixed it very quickly which was great. Other than that nothing else went wrong.

My friend and i stayed here for 2 nights at the end of November!! i was surprised how good it was and how clean and how huhe the rooms are for New York!!on arrival the receptionist was very rude but later on we talked again and she couldnt have been nicer i suppose she was havin a bad moment as we all do from time to time. the room was massive and very clean. it was nothin exceptional but was perfect for what we wanted. Location was great 5-10 minutes and i was in times square. the only down point was no free wifi but just go to a pub or restautant and we had some. I plan on going back to New York this November for my 30th and if the price is as resonable again i will without a shadow of doubt stay here its the best I personally have stayed in New York

Easy to walk everywhere. Marriott always has the best breakfast! Room 1217 bathtub needs to be replaced. Reported it twice to the front desk. Unfortunately car valet service took almost an hour. But would definitely stay here again. Would just keep this in mind.

I usually stay here when I visit New York (3-4 times a year) and it is consistently good. My office is in Times Square, however I hate staying there. This is a great neighborhood and not a bad walk to the office.The staff here is very helpful and nice. The concierge lounge is fantastic. To me this is the best Marriott property in the city!

I was so fortunate to be able to stay at this lovely hotel for 2 nights at the end of the Thanksgiving holidays. The hotel itself was a lovely old New York hotel that has been well maintained. The rooms, of course, were small (it is NYC after all), but they had everything I hope for in a good hotel: a comfortable bed, a great bathroom stocked with nice toiletries, a safe and a refrigerator. Because it was the holidays, one evening, they have held a small guest reception where they greeted us with wine, Baileys and Christmas snacks. This wasn't advertised, it was just something they "like to do a few times during the holidays." Well, if that wasn't enough, I have to say, what really made me love this hotel was what happened when I arrived home without my jeans. I called to find out if they had them, knowing that I would get them back if they were there. I got that, but I also got great communications on my issue from a very nice man named Bill. Bill is their Loss Prevention Officer. I could tell by my conversation with him that he loves his job and takes a lot of pride in what he does. Well, I have my jeans, and I am wearing them as I write this. Thank you to everyone at the New York Marriott East Side. We had a great stay.

My wife and I stayed at the Marriott East Side during New Years Eve a week ago. We took the red eye from California so one of our major concerns was that we would not be able to check in when we arrived in the morning. We got to the hotel about 8am and were greeted by a very friendly doorman, bellmen and front desk staff. I wish I could remember the reception desk persons name because she was very nice. To our surprise, she had a room for us and even upgraded it which was an added perk. We've been to New York a lot and have taken the dreaded red eye a few of those times and have had to check our bags at other hotels because they supposedly had no rooms available that early. That was not the case here. The prices were good for New Years and everything was to our satisfaction. The lobby has a nice bar area to chill at after a day of walking around NY. Our friends even came back to the lobby bar after we left and they were actually staying at another hotel. The location was great, it was about a 5 minute walk or less to 5th Ave and Rockefeller Center but was not in the middle of the hustle and bustle which was nice. We will definitely use this hotel in the future. Thanks for the great stay Marriott East Side. We'll be back. LOL

My husband & I stayed at the marriott east side & to be honest, we were in the room very little. It was a little plain, small & could use some updating but had wonderful fluffy bed & that's exactly what we needed after pounding the NYC pavement all day (&night). Very clean & the lobby is nice with a bar & restaurant that was always busy. The location is perfect! We walked thru the diamond district, park ave, Madison ave & Times Square & just easily made our way thru the city. Only used subway once to get to financial district & entrance is right by hotel. Took a cab a couple times for dinners - Stanton Club social is a neat atmosphere in downtown but our favorite meal was at Peking Duck house. There's one in China town or one a few blocks from hotel that's a short walk. Back to hailing a cab at dinner - watch other guests or passerbys - we had 2 groups cut us. The valet is not really paying attention when it's super busy so you're on your own. However, we had a great helpful valet for the trip back to the airport. He got us a driver with a nice suburban (no stinky cab!) & it was a lower rate than cab fare had been to the hotel so bonus. We would def return to this hotel & city. Loved every minute of our trip!!

good location easy check in, reasonably priced for the city. very accomodating staff, rooms were clean. room and bathrom size typical for nyc no noise from outside to speak of. easy walk to shops, east river , many attractions nearby.
user_name:
Alan G
Waterford, Connecticut, United States

review_body: Location: excellent. Short walk for many points in NY and very close to line 6 subway. Many restaurants and stores around.Room: I was in the 8th floor. Large room with noise from the heater and the toillet flush. It bothered me a little. Zero noise from the outsided. There is no wifi in the room. You will need to pay around USD 16 but it doesn't work very well.Bathroom: large but with some small mold spots. We didn't have toillet paper replacement.Staff: people from the reception was not that friendly - kind of doing a favor to answer my questions. The cleaning staff was very friendly.I would stay in the hotel again.

Fast check in, super clean rooms. Fast valet parking. Friendly Staff from the bellboy to the maid. Beds are good. Very cozy bar at the lobby. Walking distance to everything. Excellent location. I ask for connected rooms and lower floors. Eventhough it was high season(christmas) they pleased me!!!

I am a life time platinum Marriott member and rarely take the time to write hotel reviews. Multiple stays at this hotel have resulted in lack luster experiences, however this particular stay topped the disapointmants of stays with no internet access and the need to keep the window open for temperature regulation dispite the noisy roads below and blowing snow. I'm checking out a day early, moving down the street to the 57, and have resolved to not use this hotel again. Management could not be reached by myself or the Marriott Platinum desk the evening of this stay.Steer clear of this hotel if you expect Marriott quality or at the very least a hastle free stay.

Family spent 4 nights here in mid December 2013. First, let me say the location is perfect, the rooms were very clean and nicely decorated. BUT the street noise via the single paned, older windows, even on the 9th floor, made peaceful sleep difficult. The bathrooms are tiny. And the lobby has no seating except for two chairs! The bar prices are extremely high and the restaurant does not stay open for dinner. The breakfast menu is very overpriced, even for New York.

I stayed her for a week long business trip in late December. My room was on the 6th floor and facing the Lexington Avenue. As such it was very noisy and for several nights I had to use the ear plugs provided by the airline on my transatlantic flight to block out the sirens, horns and traffic noise. Furthermore the plumbing was exceptionally noisy. Check-in and out were both completed efficiently but on both cases the desks seemed undermanned given the lengths of the queues! The housekeeping staff kept the room clean and tidy.

I have stayed at the New York Marriott East Side before, however I have never reviewed it. During my first stay a few years ago, I admit that I wasn't all that excited as I felt it was a little too east for me. (I know it says EAST in its name...nevermind that!). But after spending four nights there...and then returning there again, there is nowhere else I would rather stay. I love its location. I love it being a big Marriott branded hotel (and not a Renaissance, Courtyard or the newest one beside it..The Lexington Autograph Collection). Being a Marriott Rewards Gold member, I love taking advantage of the beautiful concierge lounge and free internet. (Note about the breakfast served in the concierge lounge...when they say the hours are 7am,-10am...they really do mean 10am. We arrived to the lounge at 9:52 and within 8 minutes...poof...everything was taken away! But arrive early as there was a nice spread). Regardless...The staff were very courteous and friendly. When we first checked in, we arrived to a room with an adjoining room. We've had trouble with that in the past. Immediately we went back down to the front desk and asked for another room. Without any questions, we were given another room without an adjoining door. And this was at 9am! A pleasant surprise to have our room ready so early. The hotel well maintained. It's a quick walk to the major attractions and amazing shopping. The subway is only two blocks up (at Lexington and 51st). If you haven't already tried this hotel...I highly recommend. You won't be disappointed!

This was a very nice hotel for an overnight stay in December 2013. Upon arrival, there were several bellhops and valet's waiting to help with bags. The only drawback was that we were not 'allowed' to push the baggage cart with our bags, so we ended up carrying up our bags to the room to avoid waiting for a second bellhop to bring our bags up. The room was very clean, bed was comfortable and the thermostat adjusted quickly to warm/cool the room. We also used the valet service which promptly brought our car once we were ready to leave. A pleasant surprise was the holiday festivities, including an elf and "The Grinch" in the lobby handing out hot chocolate and hot cider. Overall, I would stay in this hotel again and recommend it to others.

Having stayed in hotels around the world this was by far the worst experience. Our credit card was over charged by $2500, we were told we could not have the room booked and charged various amounts and not the flat rate booked and concierge was not interested in assisting in gaining tickets for attractions. The manager eventually sorted our overcharge but have to wait up to a week for refunds. Great location and rooms but that is all. The first Marriott Hotel I have had a bad experience.

We stayed here Dec 21-Dec 26, 2013. Overall it is a very nice hotel. Our room was clean and the Marriott beds are really comfortable. Location is great for shopping, getting to subways, restaurants. Staff is friendly and courteous. Especiailly the housekeeping staff, who took great care of us during our 6 days. Also the Irish bellman (sorry, didn't get his name) who stored our luggage on the last day and made sure our limo knew we were waiting for others in our party. Only problem we had was our original room. I booked an ADA room in a quiet area of the hotel and our first room was RIGHT behind the elevators and was not ADA. ALWAYS call the hotel after booking online and make sure the understand you do not want to be behind the elevator as it is about as loud as the L train to Brooklyn!!!

Travelling with 3 teenagers and their forty something mother. The junior suite was just manageable for 5 but this is New York. Valet parking for the car was busy and there was a wait. I left my handphone in the car and managed to retrieve it with the help of the helpful valet. House cleaning were friendly and helpful. Hotel is busy. Check out is fast if you manage your own lugage and get ready before you retrieve the car.

The hotel was what we expected for the rooms we booked, we got a corner room which for NYC was pretty large. The rooms were cool and comfortable, a little loud at times but hey its New York, if you want peace and quiet go to the country. The staff was very accommodating, we had booked 2 rooms and one of the couples traveling with us backed out last minute and the hotel was great to accommodate us last minute in comping a room, really saved us all some good money. The only aspect of the Marriott east side I would have to complain about was the bar... It was over priced for no good reason some mixd drinks hit close to $30, and I know hotel bars are always a sink but never had I seen one this bad, one of our friends had a glass of wine that the waiter spilled all over the table. The glass was $15 and he didn't offer a refill, a comp, nothing, he barely brought the napkins. Not to mention we waited over 15 minutes for our "super premium" drinks that left the pallet wanting... Over all would stay here again but would not stop in at the bar.

Had not stayed at this hotel since 2000 or 2001. Loved the location due to being near my Madison, Park and 5th Ave favorite shopping stores. Hotel was slightly renovated and room was clean and comfortable but even for the city the bathroom size was totally unacceptable. Get rid of the bath tubs and replace with small standing showers. Only stayed for 1 night due to husband and I meeting family visiting. We had late night drinks at the bar which was WAY to pricey $70 for 4 drinks was crazy and also to have the bartender yell across the room that we had to come get our own drinks and he was closing soon.

Was surprised to walk into a lobby that was basically none existent. No couches, chairs, tables etc. where is a weary traveller to plop down? Well, at the adjacent bar so they can sell you a drink. The bellhop service was bored and lackluster. Front desk was businesslike but not friendly. You ascend to your room in a tiny, I mean tiny elevator. The good news is that your room is not tiny. Very well sized for NYC. But don't expect to get alate night cocktail or even food here as it closes down early. Bath amenities are skimpy but free in room coffee. Annoying to have to pay for internet access.

This hotel is in a very good location, nice walks to central park, times square/broadway. The rooms we got were very large (917,1117 and 1517). The service was either great or terrible. The concierge was very good as were the doormen. The waiters at breakfast were also great. I would like to name one in particular who was very attentive to us, Pienaky Choudhuri, I had him write his name down so I could mention him because he gave us outstanding service everyday. Breakfast buffet is also quite good. The bar/dinner service however is absolutely terrible. We had to wait ages just to have someone take our order and when they did I got a dirty glass. The elevators are also a big problem as at certain times of the day you might have to wait over 20 minutes! In general I would recommend this property just go out to dinner every night which is not a bad idea in NY.

Stayed with friend for long weekend in mid-December. Room was on 15th floor. Lovely. Bigger than expected based on previous reviews. Agree with others that the room was noisy. Service was as I would expect at a Marriott - consistent, clean, pleasant. Very much enjoyed coming into lobby in the afternoon from the cold blustery day and be greeted with free hot chocolate and cookies. Yum!

the staff make this one of the best Marriott properties we've stayed at. Incredibly helpful and friendly. property is well maintained and refurbished. the rooms are adequately sized, given that this is a historic property. excellent fitness center is a bonus. The location is perfect for shopping, theater, Rockefeller center, etc. highly recommend.

This hotel defines itself as classic traditional. Yes, maybe the lobby is but the rooms are small dingy and the one I was in was not clean so I left for the JW Essex House (awesome btw) within 15 minutes after checking in.I went to check out the concierge lounge first for some hot tea. The lounge is a spacious renovated space. I had my hands full, was really tired and had the onset of some nasty bug so was a bit spacey and could not figure out how to get hot water out of the espresso bar. I asked the old east Indian man working in the lounge and he tersely said over there while pointing at the machine I was just baffled by. I said I need you to show me please and he stood up walked two steps toward the machine and pointed and tersely stated there, again. His actions sent me in a tail spin. I was so angry and felt so disrespected by this lazy stupid man that I walked out without any tea and went to a room I hoped would be more comforting only to find it the size of my closet with a tiny window and a nasty 80s orange motif. I turned around walked to the front desk told the front desk manager Neeraj what happened after waiting 10 minutes to speak with him. Left the hotel for good and checked into the gracious JW Marriott!!

This must have been my lucky stay as I got upgraded to a spacious corner handicapped room on the 8th floor. While this is not a new hotel, it does quite well in comparison to other equivalent (and equally expensive) properties in NYC. The service was good and the gym on the 35th floor was well equipped. I can never get over the additional charges for internet access...

Stayed here for 3 nights with my partner. My first time in New York. The hotel is in a fantastic location, within easy walking distance of a lot of the main tourist attractions, Broadway, Central Park, Rockefeller Centre, Empire State Building, grand Central etc. Rooms were the usual Marriott style, lovely comfortable beds, nice toiletries, coffee machine in the room.Fantastic breakfast, highly recommend the huge waffles!

stay here at least once a year and am always treated well. location is excellent - plenty of shops and restaurants nearby and close to subway. can walk to many parts of Manhattan from here. although we arrived early in the day - they made a great effort to find a room for me. rooms in NY are sometimes a bit small and it is no exception here. however, have never had an issue with this. always clean and up to date. staff is always friendly and helpful. highly recommend staying here

The NY Marriott East Side is a great value for a mid-top tier hotel. The hotel is not new and the lobby is not big. But it has all the magic of a true NY hotel - great doormen and a flurry of activity. I loved it.

Overall this is not a bad place to stay.Convenient location and fairly comfortable rooms. However.The rooms that face inside the "square" , look out into each others rooms and it is like being in a prison or dungeon. (room 823 and similar). Your only hope of seeing the sky is to stick your head as far into the window as possible and strain to look up the remaining 28 floors and hopefully see a very small patch of sky... It was miserable for 6 days.... On the other hand, the room was "comfortable" at least it had that going for it.Another drawback to this hotel is the concierge lounge.Nice docents but the place can be overcrowded in a hurry.Couple this to the food and beverage layout and what you can get is a terrible bottleneck trying to get to food on one side of the room, and beverages on the other side.And what's up with NO COOKED MEATS with the morning breakfast fare??? A little bacon goes a long way to make eggs go down easier.Getting the breakfast and afternoon servings "refreshed" was a little too slow as well. I know it was busy but a little more effort would be nice.Oh, the coffee, espresso, latte maker is a fine piece of equipment... Pours a nice beverage.A makeover of the layout could garner better flow for food and beverage and probably gain some seating capacity.Not a bad stay but I do like other Marriott properties in the area better.

I stayed here on business for 4 days with no issues at all. This Marriott is convenient to everything especially if your sightseeing. I had a King room which was clean and comfortable. It is small, but most Manhattan hotel rooms are. The staff was gracious and helpful. Check in was a breeze. The only down side was the available food choices in the hotel are limited, but a block or two walk in any direction will conquer that.

This was an interesting Marriott to stay at in NYC. There were some positives like finally a Marriott with pretty decent towels and sheets. This is the first Marriott I have stayed at where the bathroom towels don;t feel like sandpaper. It also looks as if the hotel has been renovated which was nice to see. For NYC, the front desk staff was moderately pleasant, not friendly, but not nasty either.Just okay. There were also quite a bit of upper management in the lobby which gives one the impression that they care. On the downside, the rooms are quite small, the air conditioner/heater units are hard to control and Marriott continues to put these crazy heavy duvees that double as bed spreads/blankets that make the beds incredibly hot. Also amazing was that even 5 floors up, you could here the street noise so loud and clear that we had to download a white noise making app...just to get to sleep. If you run a hotel in NYC, invest in noise reduction windows!Another down note was they were giving out "NYC pretzels" in the lobby. They were in chafing dishes and supposedly warm. I got one that was hard as a hockey puck and cold which is not the way to promote food operations in your hotel. The big issue I saw was security...or lack thereof. Most hotels especially in NYC go overboard to make sure you know and see security to deter anything happening. Not here. Never saw much security, no checks and balances when coming into the hotel.I came in very late at night and when I entered the lobby I did see 2 security guards talking by the front desk. I tried to show them my room key...and they never budged from their spot, never even looked at or acknowledged me. I tried several times holding up my key, I actually tried to get them to check to see if I was guest, they never even looked my way. Very disconcerting that anyone could just walk into the hotel with 2 guards in the lobby and no one asks for id or a room key.Great location , but there are some things that need to be addressed.

I Stayed the thanksgiving week in the Hotel, the room in the 28 floor was nice, clean and big. The bed was comfortable and the Bathroom size nice. The cleaning lady was really nice and caring and our room was cleaned very well. The Restaurant service was really bad, not only in the mornings, but in the Thanksgiving dinner the service was slow and really bad. We waited almost 20 minutes to be served with our first course (a salad) the waiter was never around and we waited ridiculously for a meal that it was already cooked. (turkey, gravy,). Overall my impression of the people who works in the restaurant area is that they are not happy to work in service, and that everytime you needed anything it was a problem with them. Really Marriot need to improve this because it is not a cheap hotel and the food is pricey. I am really dissapointed on this because we received a better treatment on our Newark Marriot Stay. The hotel is beautiful and it has the New York Style but with rude people working in the front desk and in the restaurant you will loose customers. I will never return to this Marriot again!!!

I stayed at this property the week before Thanksgiving. The king Room is very comfortable, not exactly spacious, but remember, this is Manhattan. Check in was a breeze, about 3 minutes, maybe less. Elevators are a bit slow. The location is great for shopping, dining, trains - we walked from Grand Central, with luggage, in the rain (could not get a cab) and it only took a few minutes. Many restaurants will deliver directly to the hotel so there is no need to buy pricey hotel food. Concierge is great for suggestions. Would use this hotel again.

Married couple with teenage son, first time in New York. We were gonna do all the touristy things available to us. This hotel is a great jumping off point. Very reasonable rates for Manhattan and we could not have asked for a better location. 10 min walk to Rockefeller Center, 15 min walk to Times Square, Shopping districts, Central Park near the Plaza. Also, if you're taking any hop off hop on tours, there is a stop right across the street from this hotel. It was amazingly convenient and safe too. We walked around the area well past midnight and never felt uneasy. Its a gorgeous hotel with very clean and modern rooms. A bit small but you can tell it has been recently remodeled. We were completely content with our 5 night stay. Housekeeping did a great job daily and the consigner was always helpful. My only gripe would be the wait staff at the bar/lounge. The hotel does not have much of a lobby area...literally two chairs. We sat at the lounge near the bar waiting for our ride. The server rudely asked us not to sit in those chairs (which many were empty) because they needed to be saved for those who were ordering drinks. I didn't think that was right. We were guests of the hotel and deserved to be treated better.Besides that, we had a wonderful stay and would not hesitate to stay here again. I just wish they would train their staff to be more accommodating to guests...after all...they are in the hospitality industry!

From the time we arrived on September 5, 2012 the attention from the Bellman, Front Office Agent and Director, her self, was absolutely outstanding, the lobby was beautiful and the atmosphere just welcomed you to relax.The room accommodations sophisticated and elegant, and balcony views were spectacular.You made our Family and Friends get together an experience to remember for many many years to come.Already think and planning to return sometime in 2014.

Just got back from spending the holiday weekend in New York. Chose the Marriott East Side due to a combination of amenities, price and location. I'll discuss the good and the bad.The good-For $300 a night, the weekend after Thanksgiving, you can't go wrong. -Stayed in the king room (cozy). Room was large enough for 2 adults and very nice.-Gym was solid. Good assortment of cardio equipment. Limited weights, but never an issue getting on to a machine.-Amazing location. 15-20 minute walk to Times Square and Rockafeller Center. No need for a car and little need for a cab. Took one cab over the 2 nights, because we wanted to go to a restaurant about 2.5 miles away.-Lobby was gorgeous. The bad-Parking is $65 a night. No fault of the hotel, it's like that everywhere, but if you drive, be prepared. -Everything in the hotel is expensive. Be prepared to spend $40+ for breakfast for 2 after tip. There are local diners where you can get in and out for $20 which are only a 10-15 minute walk. A coffee was $4.50. Drinks at the bar are $12-$15. Again, no surprise, as everything in New York is very expensive. I'm just stating the facts.-I paid one night in gift cards and prepaid another night with rewards points, yet they still put almost a $700 hold on my credit card. (Which is still on it) Made little sense. Seeing everything was paid for. I wouldn't have even known this had I not looked at my card detail to make sure that I didn't have any odd charges being in the city. They offered to call the bank to lift the hold. However, had my credit card been near limit, this may have posed a problem when shopping. Thankfully, it wasn't and it didn't. Additionally, seeing I paid with the gift cards, I actually had over paid by $6. However, they destroyed the gift cards after scanning them. Therefore, I lost that balance. No biggie, but I stay at Marriott's about 40 nights per year for work. Therefore, one would think that they would have tried to accommodate. Strange. Overall, I had a good experience. However, I wasn't overly impressed with the attitudes of the employees. If I was staffing a hotel close to Times Square around the holidays, I would want happy and cheerful employees. Instead, they were so serious and difficult to talk to. Would I go back? Probably...unless I could get a different Marriott in the area for under $400. In that case, I would try a different one.
user_name:
Joshua M
West Warwick, Rhode Island

review_body: We stayed for 4 nights total, from 27-Nov through 1-Dec, two rooms, as a family (5 people total, in two rooms). The hotel exceeded our expectations in every way. Mr Hosmer, the General Manager, and Ms Goldberg, assisted to make our stay not only pleasant but spectacular. There were employees of the hotel that went above the normal level of service, in every department we were in touch with. We will definitely stay here again-and-again. Thank you.

Last few times I stayed here I really enjoyed the location, service, and value. This time though I'm here on business and the utter lack of food service is singularly shocking in a Marriott. It's simply closed from noon to five every day and when open, the dinner menu could fit on a napkin. Slight exaggeration there but it's a very limited dinner menu. I understand the competition from the surrounding restaurants is a factor and can understand the limited offering but what I can't abide is closing for five hours. Frustrating. Otherwise this hotel would get 4 stars so for most this hotel still works great...just wish they could make an effort to have some food service available. Bartender service not up to usual standards either. Bartender was put out just now that I wanted a coffee and soda while he was closing out or something.

As always the Marriott is a great hotel with an extremely comfortable bed! The room was clean, service pleasant and staff very helpful. Great price for Manhattan. It is a very short walk to the Twin Tower"s Memorial. A short taxi ride to mid town.

Very nice place with a great staff. We were here for the thanksgiving Day Parade just a few blocks over as our sons college was marching in the parade. The staff helped us arrange for a good Thanksgiving dinner for some of the band parents. The room was nice, clean and well maintained. If coming to NYC, stay her

This is a very smart, well positioned Marriott hotel and perfect for a Christmas stay. No-where seemed to be far away and there were also some nice cosy small places within a few hundred yards if you wanted something different to the hotel.The staff were the usual NY bundles of cheer and we felt very welcome indeed. It was a little cheaper than our previous NYC visit when we stayed at teh Marquis Marriott on Times Square. The East Side was more than up to the job for slighly less money.

We loved New York but were not too sure we'd find a good place at a reasonable price. The room was perfect...very cushy bed, modern looking room, coffee maker with lots of coffee packs, fantastic location, quiet, great service. We will stay here again!

Last week I had a two night stay in New York City. My office is at 3rd Avenue and the Marriott East Side hotel is about a 5 minute walk from there. It was a real easy decision to stay at the hotel.The Marriott East Side is an older hotel that had a few major issues that I would like to highlight. For $500 a night, you expect a decent room...First, my room was on the 9th floor but it sounded like I was right on the street. Several times each night my sleep was interrupted with street noise. I am assuming that the windows are older and not that sound proof. So I would tend to want to stay up as high as you can to avoid as much of the street noise as possible. Second, the water temperature in the shower was very inconsistent, going from hot to cold and then back again frequently.
