Not something anyone likes.Third, the hotel room (standard room, two beds) was very small. It was just me on the trip so the size of the room was not an issue. But if my wife was travelling with me, the room would not have been acceptable.Conclusion....stay at this hotel if it is very convenient to your other travels in New York City (and it is just you alone without a travel partner), stay high up to avoid the street noise and, fingers crossed, the water temperature issue is something that won't repeat.

The rooms and hallways smell of public restroom air-freshener. The Wifi costs $16.95 per day. The gentleman at check-in insisted I was at the wrong hotel. I showed him my reservation confirmation which I had printed (what a good idea at was). After 5 minutes he apologized saying he had mistyped my last name and that he was happy to confirm that I indeed have a room at the hotel.I have had a nicer room at the Pierre for only $10 more!Dont stay here! My corporate travel agent stuck me here! It will NOT happen again!

We were impressed with this place and thought we had to pay more to get a nice room in NY. Not so! Beautiful room, nicely appointed, great view, very quiet. The bed was SO comfortable! Good location too. Really nice mid-priced hotel. Would stay here again!

Stay there twice a year for at least he past 6 years. Our last trip this summer was a disgrace. No one seemed to care. Front desk clerk rude. Went to dinner, our waiter left! Yes left, took forever for manager to address the situation.In short, not how it used to be. Trying one more time in January ....

Agree with the reviews of others as they are accurate. Good location, plenty of restaurants and attractions nearby, good staff, nice to have a small fridge in the room and a bar in the lobby (although the restaurant was only breakfast and lunch). On the downside, older hotel, noisy even with the fan on high depending on the room location, somewhat dated in many ways from the appearance to the elevators. Pricey for what you get and what you have to pay for, including the $33 cold buffet (breads, fruits, cereals, etc.) and the nonsense wifi charge. No information sheet on hotel amenities, services, wifi connections, etc. was found in the room. Plenty of other hotels in the area and worth shopping around for a better deal.

My husband and I stayed overnight due to an early start in the morning. The check in staff were very friendly and helpful. Out room was spotless, comfortable and quiet. The concierge lounge offered many snacks although we were not there for the buffet that they had during the evening. We would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Ilene and Jerry F
New York City, New York

review_body: 2 adults and 2 children stayed here in July. They first gave us an accesible room, and it was very average. After two nights, and after the bathtub started getting clogged, we asked to be moved. They did so, and placed us in a regular inside room. The room itself was nice (for Marriott standards), with normal amenities. This room also had a water problem and they tried to be as accommodating as possible, but it just took too long. It seems that issues take a while... but again, staff were polite and friendly. The hotel is in a very good location, next to many Midtown attractions and sites within walking distance. I personally like Marriott hotels, but this one was not the best I´ve been in. The fitness room has amazing views of the city. It´s worth it to just go up and check it out!

We went to NY last weekend and stayed at the Marriott and loved it. The hotel staff wasextremely friendly and helpful. The location was perfect, we were very close toRockefeller Center, Times Square and Radio City. I would definitely return.

We having been staying at this hotel often for about a year. We love the location and the boutique like feel. We are lifetime platinum members with Marriott. The rooms are adequate although smaller. The bathrooms are adequate as well. There is nothing splendid to report here but no major negatives either.Housekeeping service often fails to leave refills of toilet tissue and soap. The wifi service falls short in that you need to sign up each day of your stay. Also, if your device goes to "sleep", you need to reconnect. This becomes quite burdensome.The concierge lounge is OLD, and messy. We have been told that a newer , better one is in progress, but little attempt is made at maintaining the current one. The breakfast service has all the usual and necessary items. There certainly is no attempt at presentation. The fruit has been rotten several times and often times the melon still has green rinds attached. One of our favorite things in this lounge was the mesculin salad every night. We are healthy eaters and we looked forward to it. It has been discontinued.for a while. We have made several attempts to discuss this with food service, but they do not return our phone calls. The A/C system is old, noisy and has trouble maintaining temperature.Front desk staff is friendly and the bell service is very accommodating.We have been wondering lately,if the hotel has changed management since service appears on the decline. We would like to continue staying here, but it is becoming difficult.

Spent a long weekend in NYC with a friend from the UK. Her first visit. Location of the hotel was super. We walked everywhere - day and night. The front desk staff was very pleasant and helpful. The room was fine and spotlessly clean. Small but had 2 doubles which is not an easy find for a reasonable rate. Our only complaint was the extra charge for wifi in the room. Seems rather ridiculous in this day and age, but this was pretty minor and we used the wifi in the lobby bar. I would defiinitely stay here again!

Not sure about the negative reviews as we thoroughly enjoyed our stay. It seems to be an older building but we found it clean and our room was in great condition. Our check in person really set this hotel apart and she was extremely nice, pleasant and helpful. Every person we dealt with was great; from a room upgrade to a late check out, we could not have been treated better. The location was also great for us as it was close to Rockefeller Center, Radio City MH, Times Sqaure & Central Park without being too close. We would absolutely return.

Very dated room. Stay at Marriotts globally and this one is way below what we expect. Double room was very small even by Manhattan standards and very dated with old carpeting, old furniture. Room had a musty smell especially in the bathroom. There was a large area between the 2 beds that was saturated with water. We put a towel on it to absorb it and told the front desk. When we got back to the room, the towel was still there and nothing was done. We would have asked for a different room but we had to go somewhere shortly after we checked in and time didn't permit. We booked through the Marriott web site so this was not a "Priceline-type" room. At checkout, the woman at the desk asked about the room and, when I told her, she did give a discount, which was very good from a service perspective. We will stay at other Marriotts in Manhattan but not this one.

Clean, nice, typical Marriott, quiet rooms, great breakfast and friendly staff. Right next to the subway so really easy to get around. Great neighbourhood, safe, lots of great restaurants, close to all the tourist stuff. Enjoy.

We asked for a room on a high floor which gave us a view and made the room quieter. The room was called cozy and it was but it was plenty for two people for two nights. The bed was super comfy and the bathroom was well appointed with granite counterspace. The breakfast was great. If you can get the buffet with your stay. It was a $35 per person savings if we had to pay. Well worth it. The bar there is also night and was perfect for a night cap. I liked the location - down the street from Grand Central and only a few blocks from Rockerfeller. Easy to take the Subway up to Central Park too.

This hotel is really beautiful. I was expecting a little more from the room judging from the location of the hotel, the appearance of the lobby, etc. but it was still very nice nonetheless. Just a few blocks from Times Square, midtown, Central Park, and extremely close to all Subways. Room was upgraded (comfortable beds, flat-screen tvs, upgraded shower, etc.) and was always cleaned up by the time we got back to the room. I'd definitely come back for a stay.

Nice hotel in a very good location. Fancy enough for a Marriott ... but I would call it a good 4 star hotel, not a 5-star. Clean & modern enough. But just like everywhere in NYC, the staff could be more courteous.Positives:- Excellent location for mid-town Manhattan (Grand Central, Times Square, 5th Ave, Central Park).- Modern rooms - not too big or small (NYC standard size - I have stayed at 2 other equally expensive NYC hotels - rooms & bathrooms were the same size).- Good Pizza on the room service menu- Fast internetNegatives- Long lines at checkin (even for Platinum members)- Very hard to get attention of front-desk staff- Very hard to get the house-keeping to send me a list of charges for their laundry services- Street Noise -- but that seems to be normal in NYCOverall a decent place - but wouldn't go back in a rush.

We enjoyed the stay here, a classic as classic you can get in Marriott. The top of this experience is going to the gym at sunrise and enjoy the great view over East river. The bar, restaurant and all other services meets expectation.The staff is wonderfull all around

I stayed for 3 nights last weekend. The room was facing the Lexington street which was very noisy at night. I could hear all kind noises from the street because the window was not double pane.The room was also right in front of the elevators. Some people was chatting very loudly while waiting for the elevators. I could hear all their conversations from my bed.Other than the noises, the room was nice and spacious for NYC standard.

We stayed here on a Saturday evening and found no issues with this hotel. Check in was wonderful - in fact we were allowed to check in at 9:15 AM because our room was ready. It was a large corner room with a partial view of the East River, and other than an ambulance or fire engine, we did not hear any street noise (on the 21st floor.) The king bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was a decent size and very clean. We both thought it was a very nice hotel.

I have stayed here before and was quickly reminded this not the usual Marriott standards. The bellman did not open my cab door or help with luggage. You don't need key access for elevator- not great security. The rooms are dated and the water pressure is poor. This place needs to kick it up a bit.

A beautiful hotel - warm, friendly staff - PERFECT location!! We did A LOT of walking in NYC and this hotel was centrally located for everywhere we needed to go. There are a lot of Marriott choices in NYC but we are sure that we made the right one and will definitely stay here on a return visit.

I have stayed for almost 1000 nights with Marriott over the past 8 years. I used to love this hotel. I was shocked by how terrible the check-in process was. I arrived on a Saturday night. The dude that checked me in did not do any of the usual Marriott process: he didn't thank me for being platinum, didn't ask me if I wanted points or gifts, didn't give me a choice between breakfast or extra points for closed concierge. What was really shocking was that he started making a personal phone call during my check in process!! I just arrived after a long flight from Prague (where the Marriott was delightful) and I was getting very irritated. This was extremely unprofessional. The long haired front desk dude didn't have a name tag on, probably for a good reason. Overall, New York is quite nice during this time of the year. But the management of this hotel showed dramatic change over the past few years. I'm not sure if they switched management company but this is very disappointing.

Stayed two nights for a conference. I called ahead asking for a quiet room, and didn't care about a view given Manhattan's noise. That was partially accommodated (I think, could have been random too), as the room wasn't right on the street, but I could see that other rooms would have been quieter given the layout. Windows aren't soundproof and from the 9th floor I could still hear traffic on 48th. At least I wasn't on Lexington. The rooms aren't large, maybe average size for NYC, but given the building's design, all are laid out differently. Décor was a tad dated but it was clean. Exercise room on the 35th floor crow's nest was neat - great views while working out. The food was good at the conference, which doesn't always happen when 60 people get the same meal. There was a water emergency in the neighborhood one night by the city and not the hotel's fault. Water was going to be turned off in the middle of the night. To their credit, they put a note in rooms and left 2 small bottles of water.Rate was almost $400/night, discounted for the conference. I suppose it's supply and demand, but for that, I don't think it was a good value. Nor was it bad; it was average.

Yes this is cheaper than other NYC hotels in this region. Yes its a good location and building looks fancy from outside.BUT, if we start from the reservation process, let me tell you, you don't get what you think you will, and get something else (not in a good way). You'll see people are not really helpful and no one cares to give you a hand about anything even its their job. By surprise I found one helpful and nice person to after pushing too much.Lets get into the rooms. there is literally no water as a beginning. There is an EMPTY refrigerator and when you ask to have some water bottles in your room (with its price of course) they say no. You got to go and buy in a vending machine grocery or gift shop. Well I think I did not know what a Marriott hotel is. I should be suspicious not seeing stars. There is more service and care in 3 star cheap hotels.Room is not so clean for SURE.

Clean, good service, good location, no problems. This was the most affordable hotel I could find for the price that was nice. There was enough room for my cosmetics etc. in the bathroom, the bed was comfortable, there was a mini fridge, and a single cup coffee maker along with a safe in room. For New York it was pretty quiet in my room. I slept well. No noise in halls from guests.

This hotel offers a middling (but free) weekday food service, a decent fitness center and rooms that are definitely larger than average. Sadly the staff in the lobby definitely doesn't make you feel at home even when the area isn't crowded. I ended up relaxing in the lounge of the Radisson a block down due to the rude service I received from the Marriot staff at this location.

Business for Waldorf Astoria which had discounted rates for our group. I decided to try a Marriott nearby. To my surprise it was right across the street. We had a red eye check in and service from Issac was friendly and very helpful. This Marriott serves illy coffee!! So I knew my morning would start off great with an awesome workout in their fitness center followed by illy coffee. The beds were very comfortable and bathroom was clean. This will be my hotel of choice when visiting NYC. Busy area but not crazy busy like Marriott Marquis. This location has a Much nicer view and easy walk to Grand Central and Bryant Park.

The room was spacious, the bathroom as well. The room was being cleaned every day. The guys working at the concierge were really helpful and ready to assist us. We really appreciated that. The only drawback is that the hotel does not offer free wifi in the rooms. I would stay there again though, as it is a very good located hotel and we had quite a pleasant stay.

I continue to return to this Marriott and enjoy my stays every time. The location in the city is ideal and the amenities are perfect. Staff if really helpful and the restaurant/bar is nice with good choices. Please keep up the great work!Matt

Felt transported back in time with the building as art deco and beautiful as this former Shelton Hotel. The customer service was lacking right from the start. The lady checking us in didn't acknowledge us with a hello; barely looked up to us while we were getting checked it. She didn't offer anything even though I am a Silver Elite member (and of Ritz Carlton). While taking a shower, the water was backing up, but we didn't tell the hotel about this, and we just dealt with it so this is moot. Our room on the 29th floor was was excellent, with even more excellent views of midtown. It was very spacious. I noticed the same scuff marks by the elevator doors which I suspect as the carts that the housekeeping push through without regard to the architecture of the building. It is a historic building but it seems like the employees aren't taking pride on that. Great location otherwise in midtown east, away from the noise and clutter of Times Square but close enough for the shops, etc. Will be back only because it's near Grand Central, Park Avenue, etc.

Let me start by saying that I spend a lot of nights in Marriott properties. I had high expectations given the cost and location that just didn't come through. Even though I have Marriott status, I guess my company rate trumps my loyalty to the brand since I was stuck on the lowest possible floor directly across from an elevator. The street noise combined with the hallway noise were terrible. So far as the room, I had to clean the prior guest's food crumbs off the desk before I could use it. The room was small but not too bad for NYC. I gave low marks on service because I was sitting in my room when a painter walked in the door without knocking. On top of just coming in, I can't believe he actually wanted to paint the room while it was occupied. I guess it was lucky I was there to prevent a room full of paint fumes later.Seriously, there are so many things there that could easily be fixed but it's the missing attention to detail and courtesy that will keep me away from this location in the future. There are better, less expensive places to stay

Nice hotel. Staff was friendly and helpful. The room and hotel was clean. Bed was comfortable. I was on the 20th floor and could hear the street noise so if I had it to do over, I would ask for a room on a higher floor. Not sure if it would help, New York street noise is part of it.

I was at NY for business and it was a good stay overall. Pros location and sleep quality, beds are confortable, bath amenities are real good. Cons rooms needs more space, it was small, nice decorated but small, we booked a double twin room for two and it felt a bit crowded so maybe 3 or 4 is not a good idea if u like your space. They should have wifi included package for business travellers.

Stayed here one Saturday night to attend a wedding in NYC. First, and foremost, the staff is extremely nice. The shower is great. And that's it. The room was very expensive. Parking was even more so. $65 for overnight is steep even for NY. The room is tiny, and a bit dingy. Despite advising that we were here as part of a large group booked for a wedding and that a bus was picking us all up at 5, we could get no accommodation for an early check-in. And the next day when we asked for an extra hour to check out so we could attend a post-wedding breakfast, again we were turned down. This is not service. The bed was comfortable and the room was clean. But there have to be better hotel values in NY. And the location isn't too great, either, for visitors. The location only works for business travelers.

This was at one time an apartment building (home to Georgia O'Keefe) and is a bit dark overall. Elevators are a bit slow and awkward. Rooms are good-sized. Not a cookie-cutter hotel. Having access to the concierge lounge (Gold+ members only) makes the stay much better since otherwise there are no free amentities (no lobby coffee or water, etc.). Location rating depends on your agenda. No real lobby seating except in restaurant.

This was our second stay at this Marriott location. Great neighborhood, friendly staff and good sized room. A good selection for breakfast, but a little pricey. However, we expected that, so no complaints. We had a variety of choices for breakfast, from the coffee counter in the Marriott, the restaurant, some area eateries, as well as the Waldorf Astoria right across the street, which we also tried.We had a corner room which was nice with three windows, one of which gave us a view down Lexington Ave.We'll be back.

Had advance booking for a weekend night, verbally confirmed by hotel staff the afternoon of checkin. Once there at 4:30 pm (1/2 hr after checkin time), informed by check in clerk, Isaac that 'executive decisions' had been made, and we no longer had a room at hotel! Given 2 different explanations for this - "oversold" and "water damage in room". Were redirected to a different hotel, which was per desk clerk, "Much nicer" than Marriott east side - again, untrue. Not even in the vicinity of our original dinner reservations or other plans.Disappointing and disturbing to say the least. Never again.

It is my favorite hotel and close to work and good foods around. Also it is fairly safe to walk around and the facility is not the top notch, but they are good for downtown new york city.Service is also good as it can be and I would recommend this Marriott to any Marriott goers.

This hotel is in a great location walking distance from most of the cities attractions i.e. Time Square, The Rockefeller Building, Empire State Building and Grand Central to name a few. We arrived late after a 30 hour trip from Sydney and were promptly checked in found our room which was adequate although it had no view. We had a slight contretemps about breakfast due to the fact we were about to start a coach tour but the assistant night manager made every effort to sort out the problem but she couldn't to our satisfaction at the time but the next day she succeeded. We then returned 2 weeks later and she remembered us and said the the breakfast was available the next morning but unfortunately we had to leave early to get to the airport, We did have a breakfast as part of the tour and it was excellent with plenty of choices, Wi-fi is available in the lobby and concierge was very helpful in booking our airport pick up as was Anton in helping us with out flight check in for the next day.

We stayed at this Hotel as part of a Tour Package so unable to establish the type of room we were in. However, the furnishings, bed, pillows, etc were of a high standard.The buffet breakfast had a good selection of hot and cold food to suit all tastes.There are plenty of cafes, restaurants and shops in all directions with a good selection on offer on Third Avenue.Reception staff was friendly and efficient. Free wi-fi was available in the Lobby.

Couldn't beat this hotel on location as it was only a couple of streets away from all the major attractions in New York. However, there was no-one on the desk to check us in when we arrived. When we finally got up to our room, there was no water provided and when I called down to the concierge for this, they would not bring it up to the room and I had to go down to fetch it. Bag attendant was also moody on departure. Room was clean and comfortable.I would recommend this but do not expect exceptional service.

I was really pleased to get this hotel, got a great deal and it was actually very comfortable and close to everything. The rooms aren't huge but they are big enough and comfortable. Staff were very nice and helpful!

Hotel room and service was great. Room size was large and spacious. Bathrooms could be better sized. The bathroom facilities was slightly dated. Location is average with about 10-15min walk to 5th ave shops and times square.
user_name:
Kate V
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: first time at this hotel and was very pleased. the two bed room i shared with a friend was very spacious and set up well. especially liked the big closet in a hallway leading to the bath - we weren't tripping over each other getting ready to go out. the staff was incredibly nice and j.c. the concierge can set you up with anything you need. the neighborhood of turtle bay is great for tons of restaurants and bars with a real neighborhood feel. it's a short walk to rockefeller center, the theatre district, fifth avenue and the park. really perfect for getting around during the day but gives you the option of staying closer to home at night with lots of food and bar choices.

Stayed here last month and will be returning this month! Hotel has character- old time NY with all amenities uptodate and beautiful. Bed comfy and room was good size especially for NYC. We stayed on the 25th floor- very quiet with a view of 49th street- lights glistened at night. Dealt with 2 managers(Christne and Nicole) for 2 different situations ( Marriott gift card problem and airport). Both were gracious, professional, followed up when promised and assisted me with solving problems to a reasonable outcome. Cannot compliment the staff enough on their attitude and helpfulness. See you soon!

Room was spacious (especially for NYC), large comfy bed, “noise-proof” windows, large beautiful bath with great water pressure and steady temps. Great service!Easy, quick check-in. Check out is at noon and you can leave your bags with the bellman.Downsides: $12+/day for in room Internet access (3 FREE hours in the bar/lounge)Only breakfast and dinner served; no lunch OR snack and no apparent room service except for breakfastBreakfast (as is usual with Marriotts) is VERY expensive (e.g. $31 for a buffet?)

Good location in Manhatten,nice, comfortable, and clean but slightly dated.We found it very noisy in the evenings - a lot of street noise.Breakfast was nice, good service, very helpful staff.Good walking distance to The Rock, Grand Central and Pershing Square for a good breakfast.

Very convenience location, reasonable room rate, spacey room size, bedroom is spacious and bathroom is clean. Staff are attentive, recognize the marriott membership. I like their gym specially. Walking distance to Grand Central Station. Recommended to all.

$499 per night plus tax is a lot of money for a hotel room!I only stayed here because I could not find anything cheaper nearby that had good guests' reviews.There are a number of companies located within walking distance of this hotel so it is a convenient location if you are in NY on business trip in this area.It is also within walking distance to Grand Central Station.I arrived late and was given a room that was geared towards handicapped people (a doorless shower, the shower faucet set at waist height, lots of support bars positioned around the bathroom and a low hanging bar positioned in the closet). This was a large room with 3 windows. All the windows faced other buildings with windows that were fairly close so I kept the shades pulled down all the time.Marriott always has the best beds, comfy pillows and the nicest linen! Everytime I sleep in one of their beds I fantasize about having one in my own home :) Upon my arrival at around 7pm many guests were gathered outside of the hotel waiting for taxis and before I had started to settle my taxi bill a doorman had my door open, my luggage out of the trunk of the taxi and someone else's lugaged placed in the the trunk! So there appeared to be a probably getting taxis around this time.Then once I was checked in there was group of people piled up in front of the elevator banks waiting for an elevator to come and I could hear a couple of people complaining about the long wait time. Outside of this peak time I did not have to wait long for the elevators at this office One thing that happened at this hotel which left me unsettled - on the day that I was leaving I had a bellman inside of the hotel ask me did I want to take a black car to the airport intead of a cab. When I asked him what was the difference he said that there is no difference, the black car will cost you $64 whilst the cab will be the flat rate of $52 + tolls + a tip. I was asked this when I left my bags in storage and again when I picked them up. I told him no I did not want to take a black car because I always take taxis to the airport. Then when I got outside of the hotel another bellman asked me did I want to take a black car to the airport and again I asked what was the difference and he said there is no difference. We had a bit of discussion on this but I felt like he was trying to encourage me to take a black car instead of a taxi. By time I got into my taxi I was really irritated. I felt like these bellman were encouraging me to take a black car because they were going to get a tip from the driver for doing so and in the end I would probably end up paying more for the black car than I would have for the taxi.A pet peeve of mine - there was no complimentary WiFi at this hotel!!At a rate of $499, WiFi should be included in the cost of this hotel.

I have booked this hotel for a group of international consultants for a week - we are actually still here as I write. The service at Mariott East is outstanding. Reception, concierge, housekeeping, bar - but especially reception: they make us feel we are their own, personal, special guests. Whatever requirement or problem we've had, they solved it effectively, right away, and with a smile too. This is a special hotel, regardless any other consideration in terms of rooms, decor etc...Plus the Bloody Marys are amazing...Will return!

Family members who came to town for my Birthday had rented an Apartment nearby so me and my wife decided to stay at this Hotel to be nearby them. When we got to the room there was a bottle of red wine, cheeses and fruit with a Happy Birthday card signed by the front desk, compliments the management. I thought that was very, very nice indeed and I did thank them for it. Besides that, it was a very nice hotel to stay in, the rooms were clean, good location and the staff were excellent, that had nothing to do with my birthday, this is a hotel with lots of employees and would be difficult for them to track who's birthday it is. They are equally nice to everyone. Will definitely stay there again. Marriott is by far, my favorite Hotel group to stay with.

A well positioned hotel near the subway and Starbucks and an easy walk to the UN and Broadway. Rooms were clean/nice albeit a little dark due to no overhead lighting and little light from the street. Bar drink selection was good but a little pricey in comparison to nearby restaurants and similar hotels. Wifi speed was decent but pretty expensive ($17 a night). Service/staff was fair. Towels were pretty threadbare - not the kind I would expect from a quality hotel.

First consider that this is New York. So, if you are from the mid-west expect your room to be much smaller, everything to be much more crowded, and to be three times as expensive as you would normally expect.The concierges lounge is only open specifics hours, you cannot enter unless it is during those hours. Which means you cannot get water or soda when the lounge is closed.I found the staff to be very good at their jobs. They go out of their way to be friendly and take care of your needs. My room was well cleaned each day. But the best part of this hotel is the location. It is within walking distance to a lot of major attractions. I am positive that I will stay here again.

We got a good deal using hotels.com for this hotel for our 1-night layover trip (onwards to Turkey). There are some clear pros and cons here. Pros:- great location on Lexington, a lot to do here but not as crazy busy as some other parts of midtown. But still easy access though to the main locations- clean, spacious rooms. Try for a higher floor to avoid street noise if possible. Bed and bathroom were great. - good customer service at reception and good facilities for storing bags- multiple subway options nearbyCons:- our room had semi-transparent window blinds with no curtains. Not good for privacy esp as our room faced inwards to the hotel- upon checkout, the porter gave us a hard sell on booking a town car to the airport as opposed to using private cab or subway. I found this a bit surprising, both because the cab would cost three same or less and the subway was cheap and much shorter than the "two hours" ride he quoted to us. I'm guessing the hotel might have a partnership with one of the car services here. Overall it was a good value stay. If recommend for a short stay in new York while i think you can find something better if staying for longer

We just returned from a 3 night stay and were very happy with this hotel. We have stayed at many hotels in NYC and for this trip I was looking for a nice hotel in a good location at a reasonable price and I found it. We had a room on the 25th floor which was quiet and comfortable with a great king bed. The concierge desk usually had a line but the one time I called with a question they called me back promptly and were helpful. Our only meal there was breakfast and our server and food were very good, although hotel pricey, of course.The location is wonderful if you want to be within walking distance of the theatres and Central Park. There are plenty of fancier hotels available but our 3 nights here were $731 total and it is easy to spend that for just one or two night in New York. I would definitely recommend this hotel.

There was long wait to get checked in the Elite members lines so we had to go to another line. There was no one manning the concierge desk. The room was nice and comfortable. The shower was weak. Other than that, the hotel it located in great area without the crowds but yet within walking distance to some sights and public transportation. Hop on the grayline tour bus on the corner and see the city.

We have stayed at this wonderful hotel for 10 years now for three nights over Thanksgiving.The location is excellent and the staff is always welcoming. Manager Chris and assistant Harriet have always been wonderful to us. We take the red eye flight from Los Angeles and arrive at the hotel early a.m. and always find our room ready for us which is very nice. The hotel recently remodeled the ground floor restaurant space and its very inviting and the food is great!We are Marriott Gold members and stay at Marriott all over the world and are never disappointed.When in New York, we would not stay anywhere else.Thanks for all you do,Jeff and Wendy Zaas

Great Location.. Starbucks just a few yards away, "City Tours" Open Top Tour Bus across the street and Grand Central Times Square not far away.. Our room was quite adequate and comfortable wth plenty of clothes closet & drawers, large TV & safe. The bar area on the ground floor is well equiped and roomy but failed to serve us when we arrived late back at 12:30 one evening (informed that State Law forbids service!!!).The Concierge offered us the choice of limos to Newark Airport instead of taxis & train transport on our departure, which was much mor relaxing.I would highly recommend this hotel if visiting NYC.

We have stayed in the junior suite for twelve nights in this hotel. It was great because this room made posible to acomodate all 5 together (2 adults and 3 children). This suite was big enough for us, if i am not wrong it has around 30 square meters. Just 5 minutes walking ro the subway and around 15 minutes to the 5th Avenue and others... Staff was great and very kindless ! When back to New York it will be sure to stay there again !

Very close to Grand Central Terminal and easy walk to Times Square, without being in the thick of it. Close to several markets and very convenient if going to the USOpen as the #7 train out of GCT is very close. Also close to other big name hotels.

We recently stayed in a junior suite at the Marriott East Side. The suite was roomy with a large closet, safe and desk area. It had a hidden refrigerator and a nice sized television. It could have used another sink in the vanity area and the toilet was very loud and took a long time to refill, but other than that the room was lovely. It was nice and clean and well maintained. Our room was quiet and we did not hear other guests even though we were told they were sold out. WiFi is available and quite expensive, but for some reason we were told ours would be complementary, which was a nice bonus, however you have to re-register each day for the service. Valet parking is expensive ($75/day) and off site. They take your car and request 30 minutes notice if you want to go out.Since it is an "old" hotel (not built as a Marriott) it has a true lobby with plenty of bellman to assist us. The doormen were friendly and helpful and the front desk was accommodating to our needs. We never had to wait long for a elevator which is always a plus. I would like to stay here again during my next visit.
user_name:
pah11
New York City, New York

review_body: Let's start with expectations: 1) It's New York 2) It's Manhattan. Booked for Girls weekend for US Open Tennis. Room was a "cozy king" that was actually roomy. Bathroom was tight, but it suited our needs. Clean room, plenty of towels and toiletries refreshed each day. Lexington Avenue is a nice change of pace from the Times Square hustle. Lot's of friendly smiles from hotel employees and willingness to assist. Didn't get a chance to check out the terrace lounge, but lobby area was nice and guests seemed to enjoy relaxing there. Good area for getting to the Open on the #7 via Grand Central Terminal. P.S. no elevator problems as reported in previous reviews.

I debated for weeks about whether or not we would stay at the Eastside or at the nearby Residence Inn during a 5 night vacation on points. The Residence Inn offered some kitchen facilities for some in room dining possibilities, while the Eastside had the concierge lounge (for Gold members) with hot hor d'oeuvres late afternoon and evening and dessert at night (all of good quality and more substantial than expected) WITH the attached terrace to enjoy a drink on a nice summer evening. SO, the Eastside won out due to the terrace--and guess what--it was closed!! Disappointed that the person I talked to did not tell me this as I asked about it specifically when I was going through my decision making process. BUT, they did accommodate our party of 4 in a larger than normal room by combining points + cash, which made for a wonderful, comfortable stay. We found the staff to be VERY helpful and responsive, especially when I had internet problems. The promised morning newspaper did not show up, nor did turn down service, but we were so busy/tired we didn't really notice until the day before we left, so decided not to make an issue of it. No breakfast on Saturday or Sunday morning in the lounge, but this allowed us to go out to the Village for a nice brunch and on the other mornings found the lounge breakfast superior to any Residence Inn breakfast I've ever had. Only complaint--why don't they have some china coffee/tea mugs vs the cardboard ones? Beds were wonderful, had both a whirlpool tub and a separate shower, mini fridge for our drinks. No problems with the elevator (in contrast to the Marquis), never a wait. Three blocks to the subway, 2 to the bus line and of course, a taxi to be had out the front door. Dos Caminos is only a couple of blocks away and a great choice for dinner.

After having avoided for years NYC chain hotels and opting instead for various boutique ones, we have to admit it was a mistake. Every 'boutique' hotel we stayed in NYC always featured a room a size of a matchbox. Marriott East Side, however, provided a quite spacious accommodation, where one doesn't feel cornered in. Plus the much nicer, much calmer and less crowded location - as opposed to West Side, Times Square, etc. - was definitely a big plus. A few other highlights. This was our first time a hotel room didn't have a mini-bar, which fell under 'good riddance' category. The lobby was crowded and lacked intimacy but it is fully expected from a Marriott. The soundproofing wasn't great as far as hallways and adjacent rooms were concerned, but our windows facing the bustling Lexington Ave did a good job of keeping the noise outside. A Manhattan hotels' inherent problem of rattling AC units wasn't that bad. And surprisingly the TV reception (on a decent size flat screen) wasn't bad either. The Wi-Fi is about $17 per day. Very expensive. The hotel parking/valet is very expensive too, around $75 per night. We, however, were able to get a Groupon deal for an Icon parking on 53rd St (about 9 minutes walk) and it cost us $46 for 2 nights. Breakfast provided by the hotel is as expensive as hotels breakfasts get, but the location offers you multiple other choices so you can save big. The value we got from Expedia was amazing, around $260 for 2 nights, but the usual rate is more like $400 per night. We would recommend one look for various deals (Groupon, LivingSocial, etc.) to get a more budget-friendly rate.

Stayed here for 6 nights with my husband and daughter. Stayed in a one bed suite while my daughter had king size room. Suite was very nice with a great view of the east river. Staff pleasant and accommodating. Made good use of the concierge lounge only downfall it's not open on a Sunday and only opened sat morning. Great central location. Would use this hotel again.

We were on the quiet side, thankfully, and the room was large enough for two double beds but there wasn't enough lighting in the room and the water temp of the shower seemed to change every minute.The Concierge Lounge is closed on the weekends. I don't understand that policy at all. And you have to leave breadcrumbs as you take the convoluted path (multiple elevators) to get to the exercise room.I stay in Marriott's as much as possible in my travels but this was probably the first Marriott that I was disappointed in.

Stayed one evening on business trip. Convenient location, but nondistinct hotel. Lobby small and for most of stay filled with bags (bus trips?). Bar area nice and updated, but like any number of others in city hotels...Concierge lounge fine - but again, damning with faint praise here! Hotel staff friendly enough...rooms small (remember - NYC), but clean and comfortable. General sense is this was a convert hotel and so it reflects a mish mosh of architecture,etc.If you need a midtown hotel to grab a night's sleep in predictable acccomodations, this fits the bill. Price is moderate.

As a Platinum Marriott member, I do try to stay in Marriott properties as often as possible when I am traveling. This property was the closest full-service Marriott to the client I was working with in New York City. The client has since recommended that I stay in the Renaissance on East 57th the next time I'm working at their offices.My room was dark and dreary and desperately in need of updating, as was the hotel. In addition, the room was quite small and required me to literally climb over the chair to the desk in order to get to the bathroom - where there was no hot water. I was moved to another room, a room that did have hot water, but was equally dark, dreary and in need of updating.The concierge lounge was also a disappointment - one of the worst I have seen in the US. The food options were extremely limited. Plus, the food was displayed in a most unappetizing way - appeared to be just thrown on to plates or into pans - it looked rather disgusting. I do think the staff in the lounge should pay attention to the cleanliness of the food area.I dreaded leaving the office and having to return to this hotel in the evenings - it was just so depressing. I know it's an old hotel - my company actually used to hold off-site meetings here years ago. As a hotel in the middle of New York City, it would benefit from some attention from Marriott.

This Marriott was super convenient, located just a short walk from Grand Central and right on Lex. We really enjoyed the quick check in and the room was clean and the dining area was also great. Marriott once again did not disappoint. Great service, great location. Would stay here again in a heartbeat.

I've stayed here many times over the years and its major selling point is its convenient location. There are a few things, however, that make the accomodations less than ideal. 1) It's in an old building so the elevators tend to take forever . 2) the gym ( although relatively nice) is on the top floor and it takes 2 or even 3 separate (slow) elevators to get there. 3) the check in area must've been redesigned since my last stay and I found it to be confusing 4) during this particulart stay, there was a housekeeping service issue that was not resolved in a timely manner. This hotel is fine if you're a traveler who isn't looking for a luxurious room or above and beyond service.

Convenient location at 49th & Lex, an easy walk to subways, restaurants, Grand Central Station, and business offices. The check-in line was short and the clerk went through the process quickly and efficiently. When I got to my room, I found the safe wasn't working. I called for assistance, which resulted in a visit from a fabulous security officer. He quickly identified the problem and fixed it in a professional yet personable manner.The room was clean, the bed comfortable, and had a desk for work. There was enough space for my suitcase on a stand and my suits in the closet, plus a couple purchases in the corner. The only real issue I had was with the water temperature in the shower - it kept changing from scalding to freezing. The cleaners also missed stocking some of amenities, with both tea and lotion not being replaced after I used it. I left a couple of notes for the housekeeping staff and they took care of it.Checking out went smoothly. The bell desk both held my luggage while I headed to the office and scheduled a car to the airport for me. The car was on time and the driver got me to LaGuardia faster than expected.

It was several years ago that I stayed at this location. What a beautiful building. Our room was so beautifully appointed with several windows offering beautiful morning light. I have stayed at 6 or 7 other hotels in NYC since this stay, many in the Marriott chain and this hotel remains one of my favorites. When planning a trip for next month I was so excited when we settled on this hotel. Hope my friends traveling with me with will be as enchanted as I was.

The location is awesome!! The staff are very friendly and super helpful. There is a restaurant inside the hotel but a bit pricey but everything in NY is pricey. Our room was nice and extremely clean but the bathroom is a kind if small. We love this hotel- close to all the shopping and subways. We will definitely stay here again.

We were in New York for one night and I settled on this hotel for 3 reasons- 2 beds (apparently hard to find in New York), breakfast included in the rate, and the proximity to where we needed to be. Hotel lobby feels like a trains station with a surprising deficit in personnel at the front desk. When we checked in (and got out ears talked off about nonsense while others waited) we were informed that they only had king size beds available and that one of us could sleep on the pull out sofa. I was not okay with this as this is one of the main reasons I chose to stay here. Manger got called over, simply to hand over our keys and to say there is nothing they could do since we booked through a 3rd party site and next time we should book directly through them (no apology, nothing). So basically selecting the option that says 2 double beds is essentially useless. The room itself was large and clean- but outdated and stark. It felt very inexpensive and old. Bathroom was as basic as it can be and the elevator doors were directly in front of our door- 2 feet in front- so several times when we opened a door there would be a person standing there looking directly into our room. The fact that to get to the gym you had to go through our floor didn't help with the traffic of people. I didn't hear much noise at night from it though so I suppose that's something. Next time I want to share a bed, I'll pick many of the other lovely options in NYC. Poor planning on my part I guess but really no reason to stay here unless it's free through your Marriott points program.

This was our third stay in the last few years. Having lived in Manhattan in the 60s we are comfortable getting around on foot, by bus and subway, and (with luggage) taxi. All of those are convenient to someone staying at this hotel. The other plus for us is the easy access to our floor without using the lift – something that not every hotel will accommodate. The staff was very nice and the lobby a cheerful place. Of course, wear and tear comes with all of the traffic, but we were happy with our room and the hotel in general. We will continue to base our Manhattan stays here in the future.

Young couple on city break. What a fantastic location, Central Park, Times Square and lots more all in walking distance. Hotel/RoomGreat looking hotel, lobby showed off some classic looks and a nice modern bar. Lifts were old school but in a good way and corridoors nicely decorated. The room was very modern with great use of red, clean, tidy and contains everything you need; a safe, fridge, coffee maker, huge tv, closet, drawers, toiletries, fantastic shower, huge bed and iPhone/Ipod docking clocks! Our room was a little small but big enough for us. Apparently not all rooms have been modernised, unfortunately our view was another window of a room from the same hotel.FacilitiesGym was modern and had all the basics, equipment looked new. Bar was modern and expensive but free wi-fi for guests in lobby area. There was a shop hidding away between the lifts which had your typical tourist souveniours. StaffVery friendly and helpful staff, offering advice without being prompted, eager to help. American staff in general everywhere in NYC all seemed so friendly. Door person or security in the lobby or outside at all times.TransportTaxi from Newark Airport to Hotel was $70? A town car from Hotel to Newark was $90. Part of this was a toll charge for the bridge. Recommend booking transfer in advance before you go as will probably be cheaper. METRO CARD is a must, taxis costs can rack up, we bought a metro card which you can top up as you travel - use this on the bus and enter it into ta slot and it returns it to you minus the fare. Buses are fairly simple up and down or left and right, as its all in blocks. This can help if you are traveling from the Hotel all the way down to the financial district or just to help if the legs are getting tired.Tourist ThingsCentral Park on a sunny day is beautiful and would definately recommend a hiring a bike, there is a dedicated bike route and some areas are off limits to bikes. The Mall was impressive but unfortunately the Bethesda Fountain was closed for an event so couldnt access it. The lake has turtles in it! NYC Zoo was small and didnt have much however was worth it to see the Polar Bear.ShoppingMy girlfriend recommends Columbus Circle for variety and just enjoyed window shopping and quite reasonably priced as the big 'uns like Bloomingdales etc are expensive and left her depressed :-( Tiffany's jewelery was amazing but she was afraid to touch anything!The room on the top floor of New York Library was impressive and Bryant Park in general on a sunny day, people were playing chess, ping pong and they were showing films on giants screen outside.I thought Ripleys in London was better but was still interesting, Madame Tussaudes was fun but I've been to the one in London a few times now so is losing its appeal but a must for a newbie. Time Square at night was awesome, there is seating on top of the tkts office, if you climb to the top there is a live webcam which will show you on one of the giant screens.Grand Central Terminal was breath taking, its only a building but you just feel in awe. You MUST find the whispering corner, it really does work! Cheese Cake in the Central Terminal Market was lush. If you can view the lobby of the Crystler building, its grand and reminds me of old school New York.We took the train using our Metro Card to see the Yankees play at Yankee stadium, the train brought us right out the stadium, great stadium... I wish I bought a yankees top! We are not baseball fans but wanted to go for the experience, the atmosphere wasnt great but some of the classic baseball tunes were in there and everyone was friendly. We thought the hot dogs at american sport events were suppose to be huge when we sampled the basic hot dog it was like a one from a tin can :-( despite these is was a good experience and would still definately recommend it.Pier 25 adventure golf was great, shame the water feature wasnt working. We want to go to a traditional american diner and was so disappointed that the famous empire diner had closed, we bumped into pearl street diner and my girlfriend said she had the best burger EVER! Police Museum, statue of liberty were closed due to hurricane sandy.Wouldnt recommend South Street Sea Port, museum of sex, empire state buildingDefinately recommend, Helicopter ride, Top of the Rock, staten island ferry, Grand Central Terminal, Central Park, Blue Man Group(Theatre Show), Pier 25 Golf, High Line

Very old hotel in good position.The lift are slow and you literally wait many minutes to take one of them!The position is good, but many other hotels are in better position than this one....Unacceptable prices for the offer.... old rooms, old hall, old lifts, everything is old but if you want to connect WiFi they ask you the crazy amount of 19,95$ per day!!! The results is a huge amount of people in the hall where WiFi is free.....In four nights they never changed the bag for the ice.....never happened to me before....The single bottle of water costs around 5$ as well.....No way I will be back, but this time it's been the only hotel I found a room, having booked very late.....

No hotel is perfect, and this one could use some improvements, but let me say first and foremost the attitude of the staff of this hotel was awful. The front desk staff and bell staff are so dispirited or maybe I should say they are jaded but they just don't care. I arrived on a Sunday night and it was pouring rain. The hotel rooms do not have umbrellas in them so I asked both the front desk and bell staff if they could loan me an umbrella. "No" was the answer. I asked if they had any suggestions as I had to head to my office a few blocks away and it was pouring rain. The only comment one staff member had was "I think there is a Duane Reed a few blocks away and they may still be open. Maybe they have umbrellas" Thanks a lot. I spend more than 50 nights a year in hotels for work. Not only does this make me not want to stay at this hotel ever again, but it means that a Marriott hotel anywhere in the world will be at the bottom of my list for future travel.One other odd thing of note about the hotel was the heavy uniformed security presence in the lobby at night. There were at least 2 security officers (if not more). Maybe that makes some people feel safe, but it made me really uneasy. What is it about this hotel in a safe neighborhood in mid-town Manhattan that requires such a heavy security presence?My room was ok. The bathroom was newly renovated and nice but the mattress was definitely in need of replacement.

For NYC, this was an extremely pleasant experience, I will definitely stay again. I am a Marriott Silver business traveler and this was absolutely perfect for the location and price. Rooms were small but this is NYC, what do you expect? Everything was clean and staff was good. The location is perfect, especially if you are traveling into/out of LaGuardia Airport and want a good midtown location. In the AM, I needed to get to the airport and the bellman went outside and got a Town Car for $45 - after being in NY for a couple of days, this felt like a good deal. Thank you Marriott - great job for ensuring a consistent stay in every Marriott and Courtyard I have stayed; this is not replicated in the industry, often hotels in the same brand, e.g., Hilton hotels, are hit or miss depending on the location / management.

We stay here twice a year, at least for the last 5 years. This trip was one disappointment after another..... from check in , to dinner at the 525 (where I think our waiter left the premises), to trying to find our maid ( heard them in a room around the corner from ours), must have been on "break" because they were in the hall minutes prior, I felt let down. It seemed to be overtaken by a tour, so that's where the attention was devoted. It was obvious.I am a loyal Marriott fan, have stayed all over the U.S. in them, this was my biggest let down.Planning our January trip now, but to be honest , I am looking around...

We enjoy staying at the New York Marriott East side. The staff is always helpful and friendly.;the location is great. The rooms are well kept and tastefully decorated. The breakfast in the club room gives you a lot of variety and choices. The evening hour in the clubroom also has many choices. If the weather is good we love to sit out side of the club room for a view. We will be returning soon.

The hotel is wonderfully situated near Grand Central Terminal, Rockefeller Centre and United Nations. We had a great time walking around the area. The service from the staffs were excellent and a guest relations gentleman offered us a slightly better deal for our departure transfer to the airport. You may also wish to try out Madison Diner Restaurant along E 53rd street.

We stayed here in early August for a quick get away and to meet my son, daughter-in-law and grandson. The hotel staff were all very helpful, although during peak summer months they could use a few more staff, but overall an excellent stay. We requested a corner room, and got a little more room. Overall, nice rooms, and great location! Enjoy!!

Stayed here in February for a weekend. Great hotel. My room was large, with 2 windows facing south, the beds are soft and plush. Do not have anything negative to say about the place. Location is great too - on Lexington Ave across the street from Waldorf Astoria. Not too many places to eat though nearby.
user_name:
rdekhkanov
New York City, New York

review_body: This old remodeled hotel sits under the shadow of the Waldorf-Astoria. Lobby is at par with other 4 star hotels. Room was small for the price ($200 priceline) sleeps only 2. Location not bad although not close to Grand Central (7 block walk). Feels safe at night.

We ended up getting Broadway tickets and wanted to stay mid town. We had stayed at the Marriott Eastside several years ago. This experience was even better than we had remembered. The bar and dining area is totally renovated. The concierge and all hotel attendants were so courteous and friendly. The room was fresh and neat and the cooling system perfect, the bed comfortable and we had requested a non adjoining room not near the elevator and got exactly what we had hoped for...a room far down the end of a quiet hall.Price was great for midtown hnotel!!

I am a platinum member and we have stayed here at least 10-12 times, Never had a problem, service is great, and Kenda the concierage is the best I have ever seen, It is close walking distance to Broadway and the upper east side. The dooman go out of their way to hail a cab for you. The remodled bar is convenient to have friends visit and the restaurant is adequate.
user_name:
Linda M
San Juan Capistrano, California

review_body: This is one of my favorite NY hotels. It's got a great vibe to it. The elevators are slow, but the rooms are spacious and the beds are spectacular. Rooms are clean. The gym, on the top floor, is really nice - a lot cleverly fit into the space. Great views from treadmills. Service is great - from the valet and bellman to the concierge. Overall, a great stay for business.

Our family of four stayed at the New York Marriott East Side for two nights this summer. It was the perfect "home base" for exploring Manhattan. Very clean, comfortable and quiet. We were on a higher floor and not facing the street, so that helped keep noise down. Everyone at the hotel was nice and helpful. Our room was nicely sized for NYC - not overly spacious, but really, who spends much time in their hotel room when in NYC? The only negative was a slow-draining tub but that is a truly minor quibble.The location is fantastic - close to everything without being in the chaos. We walked practically everywhere - Central Park (all the way up to the American Museum of Natural History), Times Square, Empire State Building. There are multiple subway stations in close walking distance, including Grand Central.
user_name:
Rebecky75
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: It's been a few years since I stayed at this property so I thought I'd give it another try. After reading other TripAdvisor reviews about room selection, I asked for an inside room. While there was no noise, the room was very dark, as the windows faced other buildings. The rooms, and especially the bathrooms, are maddeningly tiny. No way could I have stayed in this room with my husband. There was always a line of people at the front desk, as well as at the Elite members desk, and when I asked the bartender to make change for a $20, he acted really annoyed. On the concierge floor at 10:10 PM, I stopped in for a cookie. Five other guests arrived at the same time. The attendant had already put away everything but water and Nutrigrain bars and turned out the lights. She acted very annoyed that a late burst of guests arrived. The rest of the staff was great, and much improved over years past. Outside the hotel, just on the next corner, as many as seven ladies of the night lurked looking for customers. There are plenty of good Marriotts to choose in NYC. I'd skip this one.

Stayed here for a birthday weekend and were not disappointed in the hotel itself. Check in was smooth, room was clean and comfortable and the location is fine. I would stay here again.The only complaint that I do have, and it is not with this hotel specifically but with many hotel chains reward programs, is that when using reward points for rooms, you are typically and usually given less desirable rooms. This has happened to us absolutely every single time we have redeemed points for hotel stays with Marriott. My husband does not have 400,000 Marriott points because he is not loyal to Marriott. He has them because he chooses to stay in their branded hotels and PAYS for those nights. Those points are not free we earned them and should not always be given crappy rooms. Occasionally they will switch us but in this case, they insisted that the entire hotel was booked so for our 120,000 ish points to we saw a concrete wall, roof top and garbage ally.

The Marriott East Side is centrally located to several subway stations and away from the craziness of Times Square. My husband has premier status which allows us to have access to the concierge services for food and a place to hang out. Several years ago we got to know Kenda the night time concierge there. She is always very helpful with our requests. On this very last visit our daughter was moving and needed some moving boxes. Kenda called downstairs and had the custodial care bring up a bunch of flat boxes all taped up ready for us to transport. Now that is going well above and beyond her scope of duties. It is because of Kenda's exceptional service that we will return to the Marriott East Side again. I do agree with several reviewers that the rooms could use some updating. I also wish that the concierge food service would have more than egg for breakfast (sausage, ham, bacon or mushrooms and spinach)jThe hotel lobby has been renovated and looks very nice. During the weeknds the hotel provide wine and a light snack. I notice they were serving ice cream. I would rate Kenda 5 circles if I was just rating her. However, taking into account that the food i and rooms I gave it a 4 because of those factors. Most of the staff were very nice as well. We arrived very late the first night and the gentleman at the front desk was ok but didn't provide what I would call warm and friendly service. It was more of a methodical processing of checking us in. The other gentleman that was working to our left was much friendlier to the patrons he was servicing.Overall, Kenda always makes us feel welcomed and has become our friend for life.

My wife and I spent two nights at the Marriott East Side for a getaway weekend. The hotel is in a great midtown location, close to Grand Central Station, without all of the noise of Times Square. We really didn't spend much time at the hotel but had a very nice, king bed room on the 28th floor with a decent view of the city. Service was very good. A bellman greeted our cab and handled our bags. Check-in was very quick. We were greeted by a doorman every time we entered or left the hotel and cabs are always available, if needed. As others have mentioned, the elevators are slow and there can be a bit of a wait for one.I definitely recommend the hotel and look forward to staying there again.

I get that it's an old hotel but it could use some sprucing up, which I think is in the plans. The wait for the elevators is horrendous. I stayed there twice within a week and it was a problem both times. Didn't have a chance to eat at the hotel but I ran a meeting there and the food was good. Meeting staff was efficient as well. Gym is decent. Concierge lounge offerings were a little weak in the evening but good for breakfast. Location is a plus.

Convenient to a large number of corporate offices. Small-ish rooms, with decent amenities but little in the way of plushness. Some rooms have odd layouts. If you get a pocket view of the Chrysler building, it's very pretty. Better-than-average fitness center with great East River views. So overall a good stay, especially for NYC where high demand lowers standards. But I really wish this property were better. It has the potential for old-school charm, and a great history, all of which is trampled by the merely decent, standardized offering. One more thing: plan at least 5-7 minutes extra for any elevator ride. That part of the facility is fully aggravating.

I couldn't get a room at the Omni Berkshire or the Waldorf, so i took a chance at the Marriott East Side. Nice size rooms, convenient to Park Ave or east side restaurants. Easy to get a cab on Lexington Ave too. Was pleasantly surprised,and would definitely stay here again

Since I couldn't get a room at the Residence Inn Times Square, this time I stayed at the NY Marriott East Side. I called ahead to request an early PM check-in. Well, I arrived at 10:30 a.m. expecting to drop my bags off. To my pleasant surprise, the nice lady Sandra told me that my room was ready. What a treat this was! My spacious "cozy king room" was very clean, which is important to me. I had seen a promotion on the website about a complimentary breakfast. Of course, I called and spoke with the Front Desk Manager who agreed to give me one free breakfast during my stay. I was annoyed that I overslept and went down to breakfast at 8 a.m. because I wanted to avoid the crowds and lines. There were no lines nor crowds, although plenty of people were eating. The waiter John who took my order was friendly, accommodating and had a great personality. The food was delicious, and there were nutritious items to choose from. I also liked the quick check-out options via TV or phone. This property is close to the Theatre District, and I was able to walk to the theatre instead of riding the subways. I would definitely stay here again, and recommend this hotel to solo travelers, couples, and groups. I only wish that I could have stayed longer. This hotel deserves the Category 8 rating!

The East Side Marriott is my go-to hotel in the city for business travel. PROS:- Great location. It's close to Theater District but away from the noise and crowds of Time Square. Also easy walking distance to Fifth Avenue.- Coffee shops, restaurants, and 24 drug store all within 1 block. - Subway just two blocks away- Quiet, clean roomsCONS:-Rooms are small but this is to be expected in just about any NYC hotel-My room was quiet but to cut down on noise you may want to request a non-adjoining room. -Air conditioner in the room can be noisyAll in all a very good choice if you want to be close to midtown attractions but away from some of the heavy tourist areas.

We went in to see the Macys 4th of July fireworks and did not want to travel back. This Marriott is convenient to walk to Grand Central Terminal, Park Avenue, and Rockefeller Center. There are all different sizes and types of rooms available; ours was a good-size corner room with two double beds a view of the East River. Since our stay was during the week, as a Gold member we had access to the concierge lounge, which is one of the larger ones I've been in. I have stayed here a few times before and will stay here again.

Our family of 4 (daughters 8 & 11) just returned from our first trip to NYC. We struggled over which Marriott to stay at (platinum so we used points). The Marquis is tempting but after visiting Times Square we were relieved we didn't have to navigate that mess every time we were coming & going! This hotel is close to 2 subway stations & bus routes so getting everywhere is easy. It is quiet and clean - staff was friendly. Our room was big enough for us staying for a week with 2 kids and the concierge lounge is nice. Our advice is to stay here while visiting the city - go to the Marquis for dessert at The View and return here for a quiet night sleep.

Vacation dates 30 June to 06 July 2013 I divided my vacation into two difference experiences the first 4 nights I stayed at The Algonquin Hotel wanted to get the feel off what its to stay in the middle of the city the multitude of people, the noise it was just crazy in a good way the personnel where excellent they provide us with excellent customer service experience very helpful the room was nice a but tiny but had an excellent decor ,the second part of my vacation I wanted to be more out going so we decided to move to the New York Marriott east side it’s a wonderful hotel rooms are larger and its offer many onside amenities I will most likely return to the Marriott east side hotel and stay a full week instead of 2 night . Overall I will recommend both hotel the staff are knowledgeable and very patience.

We had a Stay-Cation here over the July 4 weekend. The city is a great time to visit during a summer holiday weekend because all the locals left the city to be in the Hamptons or Jersey shore. Check-in was quick and busy during a Saturday afternoon as the front desk handled the guests smoothly. As Platinum members, we were upgraded to a corner room. Ask for to be on the side street of the hotel as it is quieter. The corner room is a spacious room for enough room for 2 people. Bed is very comfortable with quality linens. Bathroom is good size, updated, and a powerful shower head. Fridge and Safe are in the room. Staying at this location, you are walking distance to Bloomingdales and lots of shops on Lexington Ave. Subway stop is Lex/53rd. For Restaurants and Bars head to 3rd and 2nd Avenues. We like to go to Hillstone, 53rd at 3rd Avenue. We would stay here again.
user_name:
jb645
New York City, New York

review_body: This is a nice hotel in a great location. We booked a larger room which, by New York standards, was good. The bed was comfortable and the staff was extremely friendly. Bathrooms are small but - hey - this is NYC. The lobby can get crowded at times. The lobby bartenders are excellent.

We stayed there 4 nights in June. Room was small and bathroom very small. Elevators can be very busy. Our room had O view. The location is terrific but thats about it. The Doorman Mike and a Bellman named Patrick were great. I'm also very dissapointed that Marriott changed their award points program. It now cost almost twice as many points for rooms.

This hotel was pricey but worth it because we had three adults and two teens in our group and we needed plenty of space. They had a room (jr. suite) for us that was very spacious, clean, comfy and quiet with two rooms. The location of the hotel was in a nice and safe area that was very clean and upscale and less hectic than times square. If you are looking for comfort this is a great choice. If you want to save money, you may need to keep looking. Very expensive food and drinks, so you'll want to eat outside of the hotel.

Terrible service upon check-in. Ruined my whole taste for the hotel. Will not recommend at all. So many other hotels to choose from in the area. Poor views good location. Not worth the money. Go somewhere else.

I booked the King Cozy Room through Expedia.com at a rate of $300 for the night (average for a decent room in NYC). The room was quite cozy, but still a decent size for NYC. It's big enough for 1-2 people max. The room was clean. The bathroom was a good size. Only a few walkable blocks from Grand Central Station. I have no complaints other than for some reason our clock radio alarm went off by itself at 6am and we could not for the life of us figure out how to turn it off. We even tried to unplug it and it still went off. We are convinced it was haunted.
user_name:
ToyHarlem
New York City, New York

review_body: For positive comments: Don't be afraid of this place for uncleanliness or safety. Its "fine" but that's all. This is a decent hotel and has a good location. Easy access to 5th Ave shopping Central Park and Times Square. The 6 Train subway stop is nearby. Its an historic Hotel alright but its a tired facility. The odd elevators are a curiosity often noted but that was not a serious drawback. I found the small drab room disappointing and musty. There was a vague ?fruity smell in the room. Not sure if it was a cleaning agent, the fridge or the humid air during the heat wave during my stay. The beds were nice and good bedding and duvets. Bath was small but fine. he AC and toilet made some odd noises but worked well. We had 2 windows facing the concrete wall next door. The reservation was made specifically for 2 double beds (EXPEDIA), and there was a choice on the booking of 2 doubles or a queen. On arrival we found that there were no available doubles, only King rooms. After some griping we got the manager to fix it so that the double could be had. On the plus side they were happy to check us in when we arrived. It was only about 11 AM. The nearby sites and attractions are OK and the cost was low (for NYC) but I would not stay again. I hate to pay so much and feel that I should stay out and about until the very last since I had no desire to spend an extra minute in that dank room. I guess it is worth it to pay $100 more per night to avoid disappointment.

Great hotel within of walking of park avenue. Beautiful corner room was given to us and had a wonderful breakfast. Most staff was friendly except for one lady at the rewards desk who just seemed indifferent maybe she should change jobsThanks terry clark

Three of us recently spent a few days in the city and stayed here at the Marriott East Side. Its's a very convenient location, easily accessible to the subway and within walking distance to Broadway and Rockefeller Center. It lives up to Marriott standards for clean, quiet and comfortable rooms. What set this hotel apart for me, though, was the personalized attention from the concierge, Margaret, in the Elite lounge. She approached our group and made suggestions for our visit, answered our questions about navigating through the city, helped us plan our day and even located a restaurant we wanted to visit and printed out the menu for us. For me, service like this is what makes a hotel outstanding.

I guess that if you are in a location like this then you can afford to charge sky high rates midweek. The housekeeping is excellent as is the noise supression in the rooms. The views of a wall from the 14th floor however meant you had no feel of the city(but hey its Manhatten)I would stay at a weekend again ,and leave the midweek rates for business users

Great location for taking a taxi to anywhere in Manhattan. Disappointed in the luxury of the room based on the price paid, nothing extraordinary in any way. Be prepared for small rooms, wi-fi is extra per day. Bedding was very comfortable. We had a stopped up tub/shower and this was not taken care of during our 3 night stay although reported the first night.

10 years and a lifetime ago, I came here with my now wife it was OK (the mouldy lemon in the fridge then was a put off then)..Back again on my own for business and it has improved considerably, checking in was quick and easy and put into a double-double bed room on the eight floor. Brick wall view but not an issue. Room is clean and tidy, \o/ no lemon in fridge....AC in the room is quiet and keeps the room cool, enough power points and a decent sized work desk fo the laptop work.Internet access is no free and is nearly $17 a day, can connect up to four devices to the room account, VPN etc there for business access, shame not free as in most city hotels around the world.Coffee machine, safe and fridge in the room for the late night cuppa's.Have to order breakfast if you want it the night before $17 to $22 so not cheap. No in hotel Restaurant but a variety of eateries on the doorstep.If you want a stepping off point for your explorations of NYC this is a good starting point, walking distance to some of the big name POI and easy access to public transport

The lobby has had a make over and now feels very fresh. Rooms are good sized and definitely improved over the years. Not sure i would stay with my family as mid town is not the best location. But in terms of business it's great.

If you want a good hotel in a great location on Lexington, this is it. One block from Park Ave, and a short walk over to Fifth. Shops, restaurants, cafe's all in the area. A subway stop one block away. Check-in is quick and service is good at the hotel. The rooms are larger than most in NYC. If you have access to the club level, breakfast and the newspaper are available each morning. The only downside is that there are a fair number of tourists staying there.

Location cannot be better, unfortunately rooms were on 3rd floor. Very noisy, you can hear all sounds all day and night long.Room very big for NYC standards. Basic though. Cleaning service was not the best either. Rooms smelled. They did not clean ice buckets or coffee makers daily.I guess for the price that is what you get.

We stayed 3 days. I have stayed constantly in Marriott for years. Let's start with the room. A corner room on the 8th floor. Very light as there were 3 windows. That was the positive about the windows. The negative was there was a street construction literally beneath us. It ran all night with jack hammers. I mentioned this to the front desk. She said they were done now. What she did not tell us there was a street fair the next day and they were noisily setting up at sunrise. 2 for 2. The bathroom was so narrow that the toilet, which was the first thing you walked in to stuck out 6 inches in the walkway. You could easily kill yourself in the dark.
