Overall, found the hotel room and the hotel very average - even for New York - but one could argue it is reflected in the sub-$350/night price tag.

This is my regular hotel when I am in NYC. It is conveniently located to my office. The rooms are clean and quiet, however they tend to be small (unfortunately common in mid-town Manhattan). The service is okay - probably pretty good by NY standards, but not the same as I have been accustomed to in other Marriott locations.I will continue to stay here, but it is standard - which is not a bad thing - but certainly not a special experience.

If it wasn't for the friendly, helpful staff, I might have awarded this an average score rather than a very good one. This was my first time in New York and I think I probably struck lucky as I stayed in Room 3209 which, it seems, is large by New York standards. There was no bath but a large, walk in shower room. The room faced on to Lexington Avenue and I could see the beehives on the roof of the Waldorf Astoria over the road!I was impressed by the cleanliness of the room but the decor was a little worn which was disappointing. I did request another room at first because of this but the room that I was promptly offered was much smaller and faced a wall so I stuck with 3209 and I am glad that I did. It is a shame that there is no minibar containing snacks and drinks, and like others I am amazed that they charge for wifi internet access. The bed was king size and very comfortable, so no complaints there, but a couple of finishing touches like water in the refrigerator or some flowers might make things more welcoming.I have to say that every member of staff with whom I had dealings, from Patrick on the door when I arrived to Carmen on reception and all the breakfast staff were super-pleasant - so well done to whoever keeps this team going.

The decor is beautiful, and the location is great, but the amenities leave something to be desired. This is not a cheap hotel to stay at (not by a long shot), but in this day and age they don't offer wifi with your room rate. It is an additional $18 PER DAY, PER ROOM! We were staying here 5 days, with two rooms, so that is almost $200. That is 5 months of internet service at home. I guess I could live with paying some type of reasonable fee, (for something that costs them nothing because they have to have internet for hotel operations anyway), but this seems like highway robbery and the type of "nickel and dime" thing I would expect from a Motel 6. Also, the main lounge doesn't open until 5? No beer in the lounge at 3 p.m. Weird. Lastly, be prepared to here cars honking outside, traffic, etc. when you are trying to sleep. Most of these other things wouldn't have caused me to write this review, but the wife put me over the top.

If you want excellent air conditioning and temperature control, this is a great choice. Location is great. We always ask for the highest floor so we can sleep with out hearing so much traffic noise. A lot of times they have a room for early check ins.
user_name:
DebbieG654
New York City, New York

review_body: This is my go-to spot for quick business trips in NYC. Easy access and fantastic location. Grand central terminal down the street, erc. Had meetings with colleagues from overseas aNd held five rooms plus a conference room. Excellent help ahead of time, food and beverage good with followup service, rooms for new York reasonable and nice. I received free wifi with my rewards status and enjoyed the excellent omelette station in the lounge for breakfast. Doormen have been around for awhile and are always quick to help and offer advice for after work. I am very pleased with all the improvements to the bar and restaurant off the lobby.

Besides the location this is a very poor example of a marriott.To start, the rooms are very very smallI was up at 6am and went to the lobby for a cup of coffe and to sit down and work on my computer and or read the paper since my wife was still sleeping. There were only 2 chairs in the entire lobby and they were already taken. There was no coffe service of any kind either. My choices were that I had to make my own in the room or leave the hotel. I did not receive any newspaper of any kind nor could I find one any where in the hotel. I asked the person at the front desk about coffe and a newspaper and I got an expected new Yorker answer, you can go across the street.FYI.......I am typing this on my iPad sitting on the floor in the hallway a rock from my room.I had just stayed the night before at the Marriott Champs Elysse in Paris and had a very positive experience this place is a joke.If you want a small room and a hotel with absolutely no service or amenities this is the place for you, I discount the location due to the ease of travel throughout this city The are better amenities and service at any courtyard off any highway in America.

Good stay at midtown Marriott. First impressions good with friendly greeters in trendy red polo shirts. Fun had with reception staff but then brought down to earth with a bump. After asking for a high floor room with a view of lex I was given a fourth floor room that was dark and faced a wall. Not happy and went back down for a room with a view of lex suddenly now available. All good again and bed comfy and shower very nice. Breakfasts good, bar welcoming and gym small but well equipped with good views. So all in all was a good experience once the room issue was ironed out.

NIce hotel in a great location. Very clean and comfortable room/beds. The size of the room was the same as any typical hotel room in any other city in US. Charge for internet is outrageous. We left our laptops at home after reading on TripAdvisor that they charge $17.99 + tax a day for internet access. We used our smartphones instead whenever we needed to get on the internet. Our kids are going to NYC in a couple of weeks and will not stay at this Marriott strictly because of the internet charge.We stayed on the 4th floor and it was very quiet in the room itself. The bathroom walls are rather thin, could hear a family talking every time I was in it. The door to the bathroom wouldn't open fully, bumped into toilet. Toilet was a few inches from tub! But, not a deal breaker since the hotel was fine otherwise.Whenever we checked into the hotel, the clerk told us we would not be able to have the room we paid for (with double beds) since we made our reservation through Hotels.com instead of Marriott. I actually spent a couple of weeks researching online and calling NYC hotels trying to find a room with double beds in our price range. She was telling us we would have to take a room with a king size bed. I could have booked a king room at a nicer hotel for much less than we had paid for what we needed (2 doubles) at this hotel. Whenever we balked over not getting what we paid for, she called her manager and decided we could have a double room after all. Really was irritating that our check-in wasn't seamless like it should have been. On a positive note, we were able to check-in at 2:00 pm.

Too bad the room is a little bit to small and the window is tiny, but for the price we got, it was amazing. The location is great, the service is very good, the rooms are very clean and the hotel is really nice.We got a promotion through an internet offer for marriott cards, and the price was amazing, though online it offered also an access to the executive lounge,but when I made the reservation they say it wasn´t offered in this hotel.We arrived there and the lady at the front desk told us she would give us the access but on friday afternoon, saturday and sunday it would be closed, so she told us to use it on monday, which we did, and it was really great! Too bad they close it over the weekends.The room was nice but on the small side, just like the closet, but I have never tried such a soft pillow, we fell in love with them. I would certainly go back to the hotel if the price is right!

I stayed 2 nights for a business trip. The hotel is very nicely appointed with many modern conveniences despite being old and historic. It was built in 1924 and at the time it was built was the tallest hotel of its time. Room had ample drawer space, coffee maker and safe. Window view of the side of hotel. The elevator is beautiful and was always very quick. The breakfast was great and I was given a smoothie sample and a free orange juice to take with me. The room was on the smaller side but actually had plenty of room with a queen bed and a small sleeper sofa. This hotel is in a great area. It is a 4 block walk to 30 Rock and Radio City Music Hall and the Waldorf Astoria us right around the corner. The concierge really helped me with a show ticket issue which was much appreciated.

i was transferred to marriot east side after the transformers blow up in hilton new york. staff kindly helped me with my bags and boxes. i was checked in to my room in no time. when entered the room i figured it was a room for disabled. the shower head was fixed to something like half of my height. i sadly left a lagoon in the bathroom after i showered since there was no shower curtains either. normally one would ask for a room change but i was too exhausted after a long transatlantic flight and 6 hours waiting at and around hilton to be transferred. there was no free internet, which i think is a common concept for the hotels in new york. however, the daily price for internet connection was something around 16 $, which was very disappointing. the room common room that you could use the internet was overpriced as well. i had to use it to get print outs. the breakfast was not included and the menu was overpriced in my opinion. what really frustrated me was that when i woke up in the morning i found an invoice on the carpet right in front of the door. there was no space between bottom of the door and rug so it was obvious (at least 'to me it was obvious' since i was not given any other explanation) that somebody from the staff opened the door and put it there in the morning as i was sleeping in the room. the invoice was for tv use. since i didn't even turn on the tv i knew it was a mistake. i went down to the reception and asked what the invoice was for. the lady there checked and said it wass nothing. i asked if was not being charged for anything why it was in my room and the answer was "we made a mistake". i really didn't like the invoice being put in my room while i was inside, sleeping. it got me really uncomfortable.the best thing about my disabled-oriented-room was the coffee machine. it was so much better than having to drink regular instant coffee. bed was very comfortable, i woke up quite refreshed. on my return, reception arranged a very comfortable couch to JFK, I am grateful for that. the bellboy got really upset and acted out when i didn't tip him after he loaded my luggage to the coach. no big deal really, but i didn't like being treated as if i was being cheap on purpose. sometimes you are out of changes, especially when you use all of them up in the internet room, it happens. all in all, i would expect better from marriott. i wouldn't stay there again.

We stayed 5 nights in this hotel last week and really enjoyed our stay. The Marriott room was up to Marriott standards and since we were Platinum we had access to the Concierge Lounge. A few others have downgraded the hotel because of he free breakfast menu in the lounge but I thought it was fine. The breakfast did not have bacon or sausage (just eggs), but did have a large selection of fresh fruit, sweet roles, bagel, oatmeal and soft drinks.The location is perfect with the Subway 6 Train just a short Block on Lexington and the M and E train not much farther. The King size bed was comfy and the in-room refrigerator handy. We have stayed at the "W" next store and there was no comparison, the Marriott is our preferred choice. Actually as I am typing this, I raised my rating to excellent because I can not think of anything that was not up to standards or needed improvement. I love the location close to a number of great restaurants, easy access to the subways hence all of Manhattan, and only a $32 cab ride with tip from Laguardia. Your walking distance to everything from Tiffany's to Bloomingdale's. Bottom line if you can get a good price this is a great hotel and location.We did not eat or drink in the Hotel restaurants because there were so many alternatives, probably at a better price.

I visit NYC frequently and used to stay in over priced hotels which surprisingly lacked service and cleanliness. I actually found it when I was staying at the Waldorf and had a really bad experience and realized I am overpaying for a name. I looked across the street and saw the Marriott Eastside and asked to see a room (the hotel was renovated the previous month). Marriott Eastside is no frills however the rooms are surprisingly larger than your average NYC shoebox and since they were renovated a few years back...new and clean. The location is great, right across the street from the Waldorf-Astoria and within walking distance to everything Midtown has to offer. No frills to me means they do not have a grandiose lobby, restaurant, etc. I have stayed in hotels that were twice the price and not as clean or large. I go to NYC to see the city and I am a stickler for cleanliness so if the room is clean and the location is nice I am sold. I gave it 4 stars because it lacks the "bells and whistles" of some hotels (dining, spa). Give it a try, the rates are fantastic and you will get something many of the other area hotels lack.

When we first arrived, doorman service was lackluster-left on bags on the trolley outside and then in the hallway w/o telling bell staff where to take it; rooms are tiny here; concierge lounge used to have better variety and quality but has diminished; water in the room w/not stay hot-you had to constantly turn it up or down to get temperature right! Very annoying - and sink/tub did not drain. Overall location is great and Kenny on the bell staff was awesome but nothing else to set this hotel apart!

Nice location, relatively close to the park, theater district, Rockefeller Plaza, blocks from Empire State building and Grand Central. I have stayed here twice now, in a Junior suite. The suite is good sized, has two separate rooms (not a half wall, but an actual door) and has updated decor. The beds are comfortable. The windows have these fantastic room darkening shades. Staying out late? No worries! You will have no idea what time it is in the morning because the room is pitch black! It was very quiet too. Great for sleeping in:) The hotel service is so, so. It is difficult getting a cab at times, and there is not always someone available to help you get one. The stupid rickshaws kind of camp out front pestering you for a ride. Wi-Fi is not free. You must buy it in 3 hour increments. A bit of a rip off, since you can just walk across the street and get it free at Starbucks, or a dozen other places. The porters are very nice, and give great pointers on great local places to dine.We checked out the bar/lounge on this trip for a cocktail. It was practically deserted, but the drinks were good, reasonably priced and the server was very friendly. There is a concierge lounge, however it is an upgrade that you must pay to use. They have a decent workout room on 35th floor. If you arrive early or leave late they will store your luggage at no charge (except tip of course).

Our room was very small and ugly; the furnishings were horrible. Our bed was a taco bed -- curved toward the center. There was no where to sit except for one cheap, wobbly office chair that was paired with a cheap, high computer table. The A/C unit on the wall was old and REALLY noisy. Worst, we were placed in a room with NO VIEW WHATSOEVER! Not the way to treat loyal elite Marriott Rewards members. Lastly, there's no free WiFi here -- you have to pay $16.99 per day. Ridiculous!
user_name:
HugoOh
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed at the Marriott Marquis in Times Square 2 years ago, this time we stayed at the New York Marriott East Side. What a nice break and a great location, Lexington at 49th. Small hotel, lobby and guest rooms, could use more seating in the lobby. Bathroom was very small and the door would never stay closed. Clean and comfortable bedding as always at the Marriott properties. CJ at the concierge desk was fantastic! Craig could learn a few pointers from her. He said that he couldn't help me with any Comedy Shows.....but JC not only recommended a club but made a reservation for us and left all the info on our phone in the room. Also called our cell to confirm as well. That is how it is done Craig! I found him to be very pompus!Great little eatery that has breakfast/lunch/dinner and buffet and salad bar, anything really that you would need. Great for coffee and muffins in the morning....just down the street from the hotel. Pricing was good as well. Watch out for the diner in the Raddision as we went there for breakfast one morning and it was cash only??? Woodbury Common great for outlet shopping, Gray Line tours gets you there and back! The guys are across the street from the hotel selling the tickets for all the tours. Marriott East Side was a nice change from the bussle of Times Square.

Nice Hotel ! Excellent representation from the agent on the reservations toll free line when I was booking the reservation! The hotel is centrally located and near all. The area is busy enough to give you the feel of being in the city but not overly crowded like many areas in Midtown can sometimes be. I booked a room at this hotel for my daughter and her friends for a sleepover night as she was celebrating her 25th birthday. The hotel even sent complimentary beer and treats for the girls when they were in the room. The room was clean, fresh, modern. The front desk could be a little friendlier but hey..its NYC and sometimes us New Yorkers can come across less than friendly ! :-( The only issue we had was that my daughter left her favorite pair of glasses in the room and they were no where to be found. She called the hotel within the hour of realizing that she left them and everyone said that they were just not there. All and all a great experience but it was a little disappointing that within seconds of gettiing someone on the line regarding the glasses, we were dismissed soooooo quickly and told that they were not left and if they were lost they were not left/lost in the room or hotel.New York Marriot East Side.... take some advice from a Marriot Rewards Member and frequent traveler...sometimes its the little things that can have the biggest impact. A lost and found department never hurt nobody and would have been a perfect place for the glasses to hang out until we called and they were returned to their owner.

If you've stayed in Manhattan before, you know the room will be small. So in many ways, it's the layout and the style that makes or breaks the room. We stayed here twice in three days, in two different "cozy" rooms. Each had it's own style: the first, with a "classic New York view" of the high-rise next door and the alley below made for a quiet lower floor room. The second, on the 19th floor with a view of Lexington Avenue was high enough to eliminate the noise, and just roomy enough for two to move about comfortably. The amenities were nice, the soaps fragrant and the towels soft. The bed was comfortable and provided a great night's sleep. The location can't be beat; a short walk to many restaurants, the subway, and many of the classic NYC tourist attractions. The staff were friendly and very helpful
user_name:
DonnieWorldwide
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: No complaints. We had two double beds. Room was nice size and clean. We were on 7th floor and heard road traffic but didn't affect our sleep. All service was great. Room was clean. Location near lots of other hotels and restaurants. Subway was only a couple blocks away and quite convenient. We didn't buy Wifi, but did pick up another signal and used service for free. I agree with other post on paying for Wifi, I won't do it for that cost either. Bed was comfortable. I would stay here again without hesitation.

Stayed six nights.Pros:*Location: Easy access to 51st street subway station with the 4,5,6 trains. If you need to go uptown or downtown on the west side, just take the train one stop down to Grand Central and use the S (shuttle) to Times Square and transfer to another train. Just be careful not to exit the subway station during these transfers (it's easy to just follow everyone else out the exit door without thinking).Easy walking to Times Square and Central Park South (both about 15 minutes).Starbucks on the next block, Red Stone Pizzaria across from Starbucks, and Cafe Metro (pasta, salad, subs) a few blocks away.*Quiet: Our room, 1517, was away from the street and extremely quiet. Three small windows with views of the sides and roofs of buildings was the trade-off.*Service: Front desk always friendly and helpful. We requested a rollaway bed and we were given the larger 2 double bed room to accommodate it. Again, no view in this room and it was subject to availability.Jimmy, the doorman, also friendly and helpful. There were plenty of taxis continuously coming by and Jimmy would hail one quickly. The hotel also had cars and SUV's sitting out front for guests to rent. I took an SUV back to the airport so that we would have AC and more luggage room. The cost was $60 + tolls (the driver gave me a choice of bridge with no toll or tunnel with $6.50 toll). This was only $15 more than a taxi. *Room: Beds and pillows were comfortable (too soft for my taste, but most people prefer this). Shades were adequate to block morning sun. Closet with full-sized door mirror, disposable slippers, wooden hangers, ironing board & iron, free safe, and blow dryer. Flat screen TV. Coffee maker. Desk with comfortable chair. We also had two arm chairs, an end table, and one ottoman. The AC was adequate. The bathroom in our room was large with vanity inside.Our traveling companions had the 16th Floor Suite, which was large and beautiful and inlcuded amazing views from the wraparound deck.*Business Center: Several computers and free access to internet for 10 minutes to print boarding passes, but you have to click through the link on the home screen (one person in our party didn't see it and paid $16.95 to use the internet and then the browser didn't have the correct download to print the boarding pass, so be careful not to do it that way). Printing when going through the link was also free.*Gift Shop: $3 for a cup of coffee and she makes it for you in an expresso/cappuccino machine. Plenty of NYC souvenirs, but you will pay for the convenience.*Elevators: Two sets of four that access different floors. Small, but fast service.*Meeting Facilities: We did not use these, but saw a Bloomingdale's meeting with a Gucci step and repeat. Appeared to have very attentive staff.*On-Site Restaurant: I had the breakfast buffet once during the stay, and the food was great. Plenty of choices.Cons:*Internet Fee: $16.95 per day and it is from noon to noon, regardless of when you first access it. I called and compained and no charge was on my bill, which I very much appreciated, since I only used it for a few hours. This policy is definitely something that needs to be changed!*No Pool: But this is typical in NYC. The trade-off is the character of the older buildings.*No Fan in Bathroom: Again, typical in older NYC buildings.And just a side note about Marriott customer service: I first attempted to book this hotel through a link on TravelZoo, but there was a glitch on Marriott's site that wouldn't let me complete the transaction at the given price. I called Marriott and they actually gave me the room at a better price.

The hotel is in a great location, walking distance to Central Park, Chrysler Bulding, Grand Central Station, shopping, restaurants (I don't know why people say there aren't any restaurants in the area?) subway access....the hotel is clean, rooms are large and comfortable, concierge lounge and attendant very nice and helpful, outside rooftop patio was nice. Food offerings are good at the CL. I can only say that we are Marriott Platnium members and when I checked in at the Elite desk I was treated lke a criminal. Long story, but the reservation was made in my husband's name, as is our Marriott Rewards account. This is always how we have done it for the 5+ years we have been Elite members. I was demanded to show photo ID and questioned over and over about my address, my husband's business address. They even asked me to recite to them his business address, street number, zip code and all. They said it was for security purposes- basically they didn't think I belonged there. They insisted my husband better be coming later in the evening. The manager was less than sympathetic, and when my husband called him from England (he was travelling on business staying at another MARRIOTT PROPERTY in England during all this) he got the same unsympathetic answer. I was given a room right beside the elevator with an awful back view. I feel for a paying Platnium member (we were not using our points) this was unacceptable. All of the other staff I encountered were very, very nice. I hope in the future they will reconsider how they treat their loyal members at check-in. No guests should be treated that way. It was totally unnecessary that it even occured and put a damper on the entire trip.

Marriott East Side is in a pretty good location for a visiting tourist. Within walking distance (a very hearty walk, but a walk nonetheless) of Central Park and Times Square and about eight blocks from Grand Central Station. The staff was very friendly and attentive. The room we got was advertised as a "Cozy Room", which had me worried. But, for my wife and I, it was plenty of room for us - especially since we were treating our New York experience like a Vegas experience, spending as little time in the room as possible and most of our time out in the city. Not a ton of elbow room, but there was plenty of room to put out an ironing board - stuff like that.New York is an expensive city. I get that. You have to know that going in. Unless you're from San Francisco, everything in New York is going to be about twice as much as you're used to in certain areas. However, my jaw dropped when I found out that daily WiFi service is $16.95. That's the biggest stick-up crime in the hotel business and frequent travellers know it. I've personally decided to draw the line and not give in. Not if I'm travelling on business and my company is footing the bill, and certainly not if I'm on vacation and can afford it anyway. The more people roll their eyes, give in and pay, the more these hotels will continue to gouge WiFi charges. Heck - you can get WiFi service on a flying airplane for $10. But $17?? Theft. I report the following in hopes that Marriott management reads this. Across 48th street from the Marriott is a Raddisson Hotel, and in their lobby is free WiFi, a Starbucks, and a lobby bar that does not include gratuity into all checks (525 Lex, the lobby bar of the Marriott, does). So, each morning, and each afternoon as we came back from sightseeing and were getting reorganized and cleaned up before going out for dinner, we visited the Raddisson - paying them $17 and then some - on coffee and breakfast, or afternoon cocktails, in order to use free WiFi. Again, after a while it comes down to principle when you, the "guest", keep getting racked with ridiculous fees that other competitors will gladly provide at no cost; or have the common sense to hide those costs somewhere else.The Marriott East Side will likely not flinch if 100 other people follow my lead and put their foot down on WiFi price gouging, but I feel gratified supporting other hotels in other ways who have good customer service sense.That little beef aside, this was a nice hotel in a good part of town and good for a visit.

Had a great stay at the NY Marriott East Side. The staff was above and beyond friendly and helpful from the valets, bellman, front desk staff and housekeeping staff. Lobby was beautiful. Guest room was larger than normal by NY standards and well appointed. Location was convenenient. Would definitely return!

Even by New Yorker standards the staff need an attitude adjustment. I stay at Marriott a lot and this is not one of their stellar properties. Although I was told I had an upgraded room it was a Marriott room one chair in an unusable place with a bathroom that was supposedly recently renovated but certainly already dated.The last Courtyard had a similar bathroom. The Concierge lounge closed at 1pm on Friday until Monday, why bother to be loyal if they can not return the favor. The location is great next door are a Hyatt, W an across the street the Intercontinental and Waldorf.The Concierge staff were the best, knowledgeable with great recommendations.

Being the first time to NYC and a Marriott rewards member, i wanted to stay close to mid-town and at a reasonable price. The room was very nice, quiet and comfortable. Our family ate in the concierge lounge for both the breakfast and the afternoon appetizers. Breakfast was filling with eggs,fresh fruit, cheeses, meats and different breads. The afternoon apps were also either filling or a good start to a dinner elsewhere. All the employees were very friendly and helpful. The only issue we had is there are not a lot of restaurants close unless you walk north about 10 blocks. Times Square and Rockefeller center are both short walks.

This is maybe a ten minute walk from Times Square and also Central Park so a good location all in all. It was also slightly removed from the Times Square crowd so that can be good or bad depending on your preferences. It was a short walk to 5th Ave shopping so that's great as well. You can take a short walk to 5th and it's on your way to either Times Square or Central Park. My girls really liked walking 5th to Central Park. I had no idea how much there was to do for families in the park. Great for renting bikes and enjoying the ride or stopping at the amusement park, the lakes, or lunch. Next time we plan on renting boats and having lunch at the restaurant where they rent the boats. The hotel itself met every need. It's not a grand place but very nice.

The hotel has been renovated including a new bar area and restaurant. Rooms are spotless and the cleaning staff do an excellent job. All staff members are very friendly and made us feel welcomed every day we stayed at the hotel. During the week around 5pm the staff had a welcome table inside of the hotel; each day something different was offered at no charge. The staff prepared sangria drinks, gave out backpacks, candy, bonus Marriott points, flavored water, etc. The above was a nice touch. The hotel lobby is smaller as compared to the Marriott Marquis; this gives the hotel a more personal and friendly atmosphere. We love this hotel and would not stay anywhere else. The location is perfect; less crowded and an easy walk to Times Square or Central Park and easy access to the subways or buses. We could see how all staff members were making a special effort to insure that all guests were enjoying their stay.

When I need to stay in Manhattan itself, I usually stay at the Fairfield Inn - Manhattan/Chelsea, or at the Fairfield Inn - Manhattan/Times Square. Both are great, and I simply chose the Chelsea one because I've developed a rapport with the manager. This time, I decided to go "first class" and stay at the Marriott East Side, and while there was nothing wrong with the hotel per se, I was still disappointed. My first complaint is likely irrelevant for the vast majority of travellers, but the concierge lounge was pretty pathetic. It was large and roomy, but absolutely no snacks during the day (other than Yogurt), and no hot food (other than scrambled eggs). Most lounges have bacon or sausage, along with the eggs and a better selection of water and juices. I found this really disappointing.My second issue is with the gym. Again, there was nothing wrong per se, and there was a wonderful view, but a lot of the ellipticals were squeaking, and one felt shaky. I had to try three different ones, before finding one that was satisfactory. The gym was empty both times I went in, and so it wasn't a big deal, but for a premium NY hotel, they should take better care of the gym.My third issue with this hotel is with the full buffet breakfast at the hotel restaurant. It would have been an acceptable breakfast for $15 or maybe even $20 (given that it's NYC), but at $32, it feel far short of my expectations. There was little in the way of fresh fruit (only strawberries, melon, and pineapple), the omelette and other hot foods were decent, but definitely not great, and the croissant was far from fresh baked. On the bright side, they had smoked salmon.The positives with this hotel are that I slept well, and the bed was very comfortable, but for a premium 4 star I expect a lot more. In the future, I will stay at either Fairfield Inn - Manhattan/Chelsea, or Fairfield Inn - Manhattan/Times Square, when I night to spend a night(s) in Manhattan.

Stayed overnight with my daughter and arrived early. When we arrived, the front desk was very busy checking out people but was surprised to see others checking in around noon. Was prepared to store our luggage but they were able to get us a room. Beds were comfortable but the room was oddly shaped. Had breakfast at a little cafe about a block from the hotel. We went to the 8 PM Mary Poppins Show. Seems like all shows were letting out about the same time. Not being familiar with which streets were safest to walk and cabs were not moving due to all the people even on the street, we opted for a pedicab (bicycle carts) to take us back to the hotel. It was $52! I was shocked-no fault of the hotel just wanted you all to be aware of the price from Times Square area to the hotel. Would stay here again.

My husband & I stayed on Saturday, 6/23 for the night on points (he's still there til Friday, 6/29 for work). Since he is a Platinum number we were upgraded from a "Cozy room" to a "Superior room" which happened to be a corner room facing 49th Street on the 19th floor (room 1901). No noise could be heard at this distance above the traffic, but our neighbors had small children which made sleeping in on Sunday impossible (the room has an door to make the rooms connecting to the room next to it (1903) should you need or require this feature). We (I - my husband's a very heavy sleeper) could hear their tantrums quite clearly after an hour & a half of it, I just got up instead of trying to go back to sleep.The hotel has undergone a facelift fairly recently and it does show. Everyone we came across was polite and helpful. We did not eat at the hotel, as we had theater tickets for a 2pm showing of Jersey Boys on Saturday afternoon, followed by dinner at Etcetera Etcetera, and wandering around in midtown that evening. We topped Sunday off by going to Isabella's on the Upper West Side for breakfast & a trip to the American Museum of Natural History.This is a great quiet area of the city on the weekends to use as your jumping off point as a tourist. You most certainly can walk to most things in Midtown (we did on Saturday), but catching a cab is easy enough right outside the hotel, to the Subway is just a few blocks if you are looking to save a few bucks.

Terrific location for visitors just blocks from Rockefeller Center, Times Square, and the Theater District. Walkable to plenty of breakfast options to avoid the $19 continental breakfast (try Ess-a Bagel three blocks away). Very clean rooms but on the small side (it is New York). Terrific showers and comfortable bed. Loud HVAC but plenty powerful. Not the best value, even on a group rate. Comparable hotels can probably be had for same or less on Priceline or Travelzoo but a good stay and friendly and helpful staff.

We stayed at the New York Marriott East Side for the Thanksgiving holiday 2011. The hotel is an excellent base in NYC. It is centrally located and everything was within walking distance of all the tourist attactions. The hotel itself is well appointed and very comfortable. Staff were always helpful and polite. We have stayed at the Waldorf, opposite, earlier that year and it is of equal standard but much less fussy! We had dinner and drinks in the bar which was excellent. I would certainly stay there again. I have never had a bad stay in a Marriott hotel! Top quality every time!!

We checked in at midnight with one sleeping four-year old and a very tired seven-year old. When we booked our room I requested a double-bed but it was not guaranteed -much to my surprise we were given a double in an over-sized room. The front desk staff was very accommodating and willing to go the extra mile and head to the nearest drug store for some much needed supplies for me. The gentleman at the front desk scoured the entire hotel and found what I needed and had the items sent up to our room -THANK YOU!!! This is not the first time I have encountered this kind of extra-mile attitude at a Marriott (that is why we keep staying!). Anyways, the room was extra large with three windows, an alcove for the kid's luggage, two chairs & an end table, and a large tv/coffee/fridge armoire. The room was very quiet -in fact the entire floor was very quiet. On our last day (Sunday) there was a summer street fair that rotates throughout Manhattan and it just happen to be held on Lexington Avenue. How lucky! We spent the entire day walking up and down Lexington Avenue buying last minute gifts for family & eating delicious gyros, grilled corn on the cob, kettle corn, and other yummy treats. Since Lexington Ave was completely blocked off to traffic we worried about being able to leave and arrive at the airport in time. Our bellman (Anthony V.) suggested an appropriate time to return to the Marriott and he would have a towncar waiting to take us to the airport. The car service the Marriott contracts with has a flat-rate service to JFK, which is only a few dollars more than taking a taxi! This was my first visit to the Big Apple and everything exceeded my expectations. When we return (because I have fallen in love with NY!) we will be staying at this hotel again -it was close to the subway, good eats, great shopping, and just about the best staff around.

This hotel is centrally located, but further from the hotspots so it isn't too loud. Shout out to Margaret in the concierge lounge, very nice service. Anyway, it's an ok hotel which needs some work. The check in on the first floor was very rude. The guy there told us to get in line, and when we said that we were platinum members and wanted to go to the elite line, he didn't care. He told us to stay in the same line. The windows were very thin or something, because every time a car passed by, it felt like it was coming towards you! It was so loud. Other than that, the hotel was near the metro station so a pretty convenient hotel for travelling around the big apple.

I have had the pleasure of staying at the East Side Marriott on various occasions. Everyone I had the opportunity to interact with was eager to assist me and enthusiastic in doing so. This hotel is located away from the heavily transited Times Sq, but close enough if you wish to walk towards that area. The rooms are a bit small in sq footage and some street noise should be expected -- especially when staying in low floors. Stay here you won't regret it!

Great value in Midtown. Large room, lots of windows. Nice proximity to Park Ave and 5th Ave shopping. The newly remodeled bar is nice for drinks or light meal. More of a nightlife scene at neighboring W. Only issue during stay: Do Not Disturb sign on door at 9:30am on Saturday. The housekeeper called the room to see what time we wanted the room serviced. Our response: just after we remove the sign.....that however, was a minor issue. Overall a definite repeat.

Rolled into the hotel around 8pm after a long day's travel with my girlfriend & 14-yr old nephew, & was greeted by Collette at the front desk. I booked our room through a 3rd party website & had requested a N/S double room, and when I asked her she was completely out of standard double rooms, so she was kind enough to upgrade us to a 2-room suite. It was my nephew's 1st visit to the city, and upon mentioning that, she made us feel right at home & told us about the myriad things to do while we were there. She also gave us complimentary continental breakfast in the concierge lounge where the city views were fantastic. The hotel is within easy walking distance of Rockefeller Center and local eateries and attractions. The room was well-appointed, typical clean, upscale Marriott. Check-out was just as smooth. We left our bags with the bellhop for the day, and he was amazingly friendly as well. I highly recommend this place thanks to the staff.

This was our second visit to New York and we weren't disappointed with the hotel. It was in an excellent location, close to the subway and central to lots of great restaurants. We were very lucky to have been upgraded to a suite - wow it was huge. Lovely decor throughout the hotel and everywhere was clean and tidy. The bed was very comfortable and we were surprised that we had a very peaceful night with no noise from the street below. Plenty to chose from at the buffet breakfast. Lovely decor throughout the hotel and the staff were very friendly and helpful. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the New York Marriott East Side and would have not hesitation in staying there again or recommending it to anyone.

We visit NYC every few years, have stayed here before and it was nice to be back. The desk were kind enough to meet my upgrade request, we had a superior room on the 21st floor overlooking Lex, thanks. Marriott rarely miss a thing, their standards are very good (theirs beds are the best anywhere) and this stay was no exception. The room was very clean and well serviced, the hotel staff were all friendly and helpful, it just makes for an all-round relaxing stay.I called for a car service recommendation (we all know how erratic some can be), thanks to Michael on the door I got Gustavo Cars (001 718 775 4257). Gustavo is a nice chap and excellent driver, he was calling me on arrival to ensure we met in the right place. He knows NYC very well and avoided a horrendous jam on the way in. We had Emerson for our return and he knew every cut through and jam dodge trick going, JFK in record time. Prices very good both ways. Top service.For a cheeky glass of wine in the room, use Bona Vinos, round the block on 3rd, they have a superb selection at good prices.

Location of this hotel is great for East Side Manhattan activities, service is good despite rooms being a little small; but this is the case for all hotels in New York City. close to Grand Central, Subway, Brytant Park and New York Public Library. Parking fee is straight outrageous, either keep your car out of Manhattan or be ready to get robbed. Oner ayan
user_name:
ONER A
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed at this hotel on a spur of the moment girl getaway weekend. It was clean and in a nice location. The beds were comfortable and it was adequate for a two night stay for two females. The concierge was very helpful; an Italian restaurant was recommended. I forget the name, but it was walking distance and was pretty good. We also got help several other times about places to go for breakfast. We felt safe at this hotel and went out out first night was a few drinks. We saw a Broadway play while in town. On Saturday we got up early to get tickets for Sister Act, which was very entertaining and funny. Overall, I have no complaints and would stay here again. It was typical Marriott....clean, comfortable and accommodating to out needs.

Biggest room I've ever had in NYC. Great location and staff. One of my favorites in the city. Only issue was spotty wireless in the room and concierge lounge. Made it tough to get work done. Not sure if it was a widespread problem or just isolated to when we were there.

I stayed her for my first ever business trip to NY and it was a great experience. While the hotel is old it was clean, easy to get to and to get around while there and has every amenity I needed. The staff was friendly and helpful and I would definitely stay there again!

We had a pleasant stay. Our room was clean, comfortable, quiet. We like the idea that you can walk to many attractions (e.g. United Nations), restaurants, shops, etc. from here. The neighborhood is not as noisy as the west side theater district. It's also close to Grand Central. There are many restaurants nearby--quite a few are open late--so we did not try the hotel restaurant. It's annoying that the hotel charges extra for WiFi, but that's standard for Marriott. A tip for those arriving by car: there are several lower-priced parking garages within a 10-minute walk of the hotel, on the side streets between 3rd and 1st Avenues. (See nyc.bestparking.com)

Have stayed here many times and we were just there again April 26-29. Yes, if you get just a standard regular room it will be small but if you have any Marriott status or pay for the upgrade the rooms are very nice but small - this is typical for all older hotels in NYC. I have stayed at the Waldorf Astoria, Grand Hyatt, Renessiance on 51st and Lexington and in Times Square the last few years and all have small rooms with the exception of the Renessiance in TS. But it has it's own issues. This review is about the Marriott ES so I will stick to that. The rooms are nicely decorated. We stayed on the 36th floor and had a great view up Lexington Ave towards lower Manhattan. The room was larger than normal mostly because of my Marriott status. Even the bathroom wasnt to bad. The hotel has a nice conceirge level for those that qualify. NIce breakfast but the evening snack was not as nice as it had been in the past years but I am finding that most hotels have started to skimp on this. Desserts were nice though. Hotel has a nice bar and large lobby area on street level. That is important to note since many hotels in NYC don't have street level lobbies. It is an easy walk to Times Square, Rockefeller Center, Grand Central Station or the Lexington and 51St subway station. We prefer staying here vs Times Square becasue it is much less crowded and easy to walk anywhere. Cab Service is easy to get but NOTE: Getting cabs from here to the theatre district at play time in the evening in near to impossible! Most cabies dont want to drive to that area near Times Square becasue of the traffic. We could have walked if we had started out earlier but my wife also didnt have walking shoes on that night. Ended up paying a private care $30 to take us the 15 min walk and almost missed the start of Memphis. The staff at the hotel was very friendly.

I always stress about finding a good hotel with good business services while in the Big Apple. I can't pay the $350+ rates of most hotels. The Marriott was a nice surprise. It had all one would expect at a Marriott but without the price tag. It's no Ritz but clean, efficient and well resourced.

We stayed at this hotel last week and it exeeded all of our expectations The. J. W. Suite was very nice, clean and spacious.We loved the location because we were very close to Grand Central Station.The breakfast was a little overpriced. All-in-all another great Marriott experience!

From the moment we arrived to the day we departed this Marriott exceeded my expecatations. Easy access to the front door, with "Jimmy" the Door Man at our service. Valet parking included in our room rate, location, and small (as expected) but clean well- decorated rooms. The old charm of the hotel only enhanced our trip. We were traveling with a small group and the front desk, with a little juggling ,made sure our rooms were next to each other. Top of our to do list was the American Girl Store and it was so close we went back 2x. After checking in and a trip to the store we arrived back at our room with milk and cookies for my 3 daughters as an added perk. And as I mentioned, we choose the valet parking package, not the AG package, so the additional treat, was thoughtful of the staff. The bar is new and modern with a decent drink/wine selection. Beds were comfy and maid service was adequate. Busy hotel, I believed they were booked to capacity that weekend and our stay was better than expected.

Stayed many times at the Marriott East Side including two trips in April. The rooms vary considerably in size and the elevators are small and slow, leading to long waits at peak hours.But overall the execution is good, the concierge lounge is very convenient (although it's puzzling why it isn't open on Friday night or weekend). The staff is accommodating when you need it. Because of the location, some of the rooms (particularly lower floors) are incredibly noisy at night.A new restaurant on the lobby level is a plus, replacing a dismal space, but inexplicably they don't serve lunch.A great location and solid execution, most of the time.

This hotel is situated in Manhattan! Great location as you can walk to many nice sightseeing places easily.Restaurants around that area were nice and they all opened till late.Yes, you could feel "New York never sleeps" totally in this hotel!People kept checking in and out even in the middle of the night and bars around the area were lively. However it really effect your sleep as you could hear the taxi/car horn even at 4am!I will revisit this hotel, but of course will expect a non stop New York's life in here!

I am a Marriott person and select it over all other brands (yes, it is the points!)....I have stayed here several times and find it to be a great location and the prices are reasonable for NYC. Good location for transit (near Grand Central Station), relatively close to the Park, shopping, Times Square and subway stations. Staff are pleasant and the rooms albeit small are comfortable.

The New York Marriott East Side is always my first choice for hotels when traveling to New York, especially on business. The property is in a historic building that has been renovated and oozes with character. I am a huge fan of Marriotts and always find their staff responsive and helpful, but the East Side Marriott staff stands out for providing distinctive service for their guests. I also like the convenient location .... but not TOO convenient to all of the city's tourist attractions. On the east side at 49th and Lexington it is very close to the terrific sites and shops along 5th Avenue, Park Avenue and Lexington Avenue, and bars and restaurants along 2nd Avenue. It is located in a great neighborhood around the embassies, which feel like a very different part of New York by comparison to the Financial District or Times Square, a very safe and quiet neighborhood.

This is the second time we have visited NYC and were very pleased with the hotel and location of the hotel. We were greeted by very helpful doormen who loaded our bags onto a trolley from our cab and waited while we checked in to assist us with them our room. The room was very spacious with two double beds, large bathroom, great sized wardrobe, fridge, tea/coffee facilities, safe, large TV, ironing board, iron and hairdryer. We couldn't of asked for anymore from the hotel from the moment we arrived to the moment we left. The staff on reception were very helpful and friendly with finding places we wanted to go and recommending places. The staff in the restaurant and bar we're also very helpful and we had some amazing cocktails. All in all this is a fab hotel and I would defnetly recommend it and go back and stay there again.

Nice rooms (small; this is Manhattan), with windows that OPEN! Always a plus, although in NYC it is also always pretty noisy. Location was perfect for Times Square and the NYC Music Store scene. Very close to the UN and FDR Drive as well. Front desk and concierge very helpful (obviously used to people checking out and leaving bags for the day). Breakfast buffet very nice, too bad it wasn't warm enough to use the patio. Exercise room is on the very top floor but well-outfitted.

Stayed for a pre wedding/Christmas break for 3 nights in December. Great hotel, fast efficient service, nice rooms (we had a standard double) and decent shower/bathroom. Location is perfect for most places if you don't mind a ten minute walk. Plus the tour bus stops nearby and there's always taxi's.

We typically stay right in Times Square, but decided to try something different this time. The pros are that the room was much larger than other places I've stayed, and it's close to nicer shopping and food than the touristy area where we typically stay. The only con I had is that the room was loud. Alot of street noise, which I expect from NYC, but I thought it was really loud here. Maybe the windows are thinner or something. I would sacrifice quiet for large room, so I probably would not come back here since the other hotel where I usually stay is VERY quiet and that's just my personal preference. I will say, the people at this hotel (employees) are super nice. Everyone went out of their way to talk to me and my daughter. I was wondering if i resembled some celebrity or something. Like, maybe they are confused about who I am because they were trying to be so nice! Conciege was helpful when asked some questions. I would reccomend this hotel to anyone, but would just point out to maybe get a high floor to reduce the street noise if you are a light sleeper.

I attended a conference at this property. The hotel rooms and common areas obviously have been fairly recently renovated. The rooms are actually quite spacious for New York (where a walk-in closet is the usual rule of the day). Front desk, concierge, bell and housekeeping staff are attentive and friendly. There are many key attractions, great restaurants and world class shopping in the immediate environs. The 525 Lex lounge is cheerful, with great bar service. Depending on ones proclivities, the call girls at the bar may be either an annoyance or a welcome "feature."

This hotel is up to Marriott's usual high standards. The price is a bit steep but competitive with other high-class hotels in Manhattan. The location is excellent. At a walking distance of many major attraction, near subways, in a safe area.We received excellent customer service during the lenght of our stay, including check-in and check-out.The room was simply decorated, clean and of an average size (large for NYC's standards). the beds and pillows were comfortable. The room contained everything you would expect in a hotel room with flat screen TV, refrigerator and ipod/phone charger/player. There is a safe in the room but you must pay extra to use it. Although I LOVED my stay, there were a few lowson my stay: Parking is very expensive ($60/night) which is higher than any other hotels in NYC that I have been to. As well, I found the shower-head to be too low in the bathroom. I am under 6' tall and found that I couldn't stand directly under the stream of water. As well, you will hear everything happening in the hallway in your room, but since this is a nice hotel, guests tend to be quiet so it wasn't really ever a problem... Internet is extremely expensive... Unless you are travelling for work, I would advise to use Starbuck's free wi-fi to do your research... (think $25/day for wi-fi service at the hotel... expensive!).I would definitely recommend this hotel and I would stay here again.
A bit loud at night but the room was comfortable. Convenient location to fun bars and restaurants.

This is my first visit to this particular Marriott, and thus far, I have been very happy. The rooms are on the small size, but that is to be expected in NYC. When I first checked in, my room faced the street where the utility company was using a jackhammer. Although it took 2 calls to the front desk to get a new room, Marlene (who answered my second call) was fantastic - she immediately got me a quieter room, despite the hotel being almost full. This is why I often stay at Marriott!

Just back from a quick getaway with our teenage son. The room was larger than we expected, with 2 double beds and 4 windows overlooking Lexington and 49th. Great location - for us it was an easy walk to Empire State Bldg., Times Sq., and Central Park. As my husband usually stays at Marriotts, we had access to the concierge lounge and enjoyed the breakfast and evening appetizers and honor bar. Also loved it's rooftop deck. Everyone was very friendly and helpful, from the concierge and front desk, to the doormen, valets, and bellhops. We'll defintely be back!

I spent three nights at this hotel, and was pleasantly impressed. The staff was very courteous and friendly, and the room was nice. My friend said it was large for NYC standards. I thought the lounge was expensive at $6.00 for a glass of club soda (no alcohol), but perhaps that is the going rate. I would definitely stay again.

I have been going to the this hotel for over 7 yeasr for business the staff are friendly and helpful. But the rooms are getting smaller and its prices keep going up, the concierge lounge has gradually reduced its offerings and it seems that the rooms are getting louder every time I visit. I used to avoid Marriott Marque but since its renovation it’s a much better hotel than the eastside. I hope the eastside Marriott makes a comeback

Very pleased with this hotel - recently stayed 5 nights. The room was large by New York standards, and it was very quiet too! Lounge was excellent although very crowded on weekdays. Good location for transportation. Staff was very professional too. Well done Marriott!

I stayed in this hotel for 2 weeks while on business in New York City. I would recommend the hotel for tourists but not for business, due to the very expensive and poor quality internet service in the rooms. Internet costs $18/day and the connection is horrible. I have heard similar comments about other American Marriott locations (e.g., Washington DC). However, for tourists, the East Side location is excellent -- close to Grand Central Terminal, the UN, and good shopping at 59th and Lexington. A short cab ride (or a nice long walk) will take you to the Empire State Building, Macy's, and Times Square. The hotel is clean and nice. The housekeeping and bell stand staff are excellent; the front desk staff can be rude, depending of course on who you speak to.

I recently returned from a three night stay at the Marriott East Side and my somewhat tempered expectations were exceeded. It was the first trip to NY with my kids - ages six and three.For starters, I was upgraded to a larger room that accommodated two doubles and roll away. Said differently, we were not subjected to the kids beating each other up in the same bed until my wife and split up and each took one. This was accomplished with a pre-arrival e-mail exchange with reservation manager who was delightful.We arrived at around 11:30am and I was surprised to find our room available. Check-in was a breeze and I was shown all the love that my Platinumness is supposed to yield. The kids were thrilled when that evening when milk and cookies arrived shortly before bed (I was less thrilled, but that's more of a sugar issue).The room was large by NY standards. The view was of the center core of the building which was dark anyway you slice it. I would gleefully trade view for room size anytime (particularly when sharing a room with the kids) so this wasn't a big deal. And, not surprisingly, we were rarely in the room.The concierge lounge was among the busier ones I've seen in the Marriott system. Despite that, they were wonderful with the kids (offered a Marriott coloring book) and the breakfast offerings (eggs, bagels, cereal, fruit, good coffee) was more than good enough to save the $852 for four breakfast charge via room service (okay, slight exaggeration). Keep in mind that the lounge closes for the weekend at 1pm on Friday.Internet was more than good enough and the LCD TV kept my kids entertained when we were getting ready. The location at 49th and Lex was an easy walk to just about everything in midtown.Great stay and would (and will) return again in a heartbeat.
user_name:
verysnobbytraveler
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My husband and I had a wonderful 3 night getaway at this hotel. It is very conveniently located. Great restaurants all around, subway 2 blocks away, close to Times Square, and excellent customer service.

I just stayed at this hotel last weekend and found it to be a very clean and comfortable place to stay at a reasonable rate in NYC. Check-in was a breeze! We arrived in the city at 2:30 (check-in wasn't until 4) but they accommodated us right away which was a nice surprised for a Friday on a holiday weekend. The room was average-sized...I've stayed in an similar-style Marriott in DC where the room was a tad bigger (even had a couch) but this is NYC so I expect smaller accommodations. When we arrived in the room we immediately did the bed-bug test (lift up the mattress to see if you see any critters scatter - bed bugs hate light) and it passed the test! Phew! The water-pressure in the shower was incredible, and they provided Bath and Body works toiletries (we also called down for a couple of toothbrushes and they provided them which was helpful).A few other notes... We didn't use the hotel WiFi as I believe it was $16 which seemed pretty pricey. We also skipped the hotel breakfast (also pricey) and the room service; however, my boyfriend did go down to the hotel bar/restaurant (525 LEX) where he had three beers and a plate of edamame for $50! (Yikes!) This hotel is conveniently within a block or so to some decent restaurants and bars (Ess-a-bagel, Starbucks, Dos Caminos, Snafu (dive bar that serves popcorn)) which was great in a pinch. Overall, would recommend if you can find a great rate or deal for the hotel (not sure if I would pay full price).

I did not go to New York on buisness, strictly pleasure. Therefore I did not need internet connection or the computers there. However, if you are going here on buisness the wifi is very expensive and the buisness center charges 35cents per minute! and to make and copies or print anything. The staff is very very nice and will get you a taxi anytime you need one and they also have so much knowledge about the city! The concierge desk can also get you tickets to shows, schedule reservations, schedule a time for a pick up in a car, and also get game tickets for various sports. The room itself is very nice they have a flat screen tv in every room, the bed is comfortable, and the ac is able to be set on various settings. the shower also has very warm water and there is excellent conditioner and shampoo provided. Not the cheap stuff. I definitely insist on going up to the top floor of the hotel where you will have a panaromic view of the city. Which is awesome. Very good location in walking distance of times square, 5th avenue, and canal street. Or a cheap taxi ride to any of these.

The hotel was located near many things to do. We went to the broadway show WICKED (excellent show). The hotel and the employees were exceptionally nice. Good food but only served breakfast and dinner, no lunches but plenty of places around to eat it is NYC.

It's a very good location in Midtown and the room was very clean. The bed was very comfortable and the people who worked there are incredibly nice - quick check with a long line of people. There are not a lot of bells and whistles if that is what you are looking for.

My wife & I just got back from a weekend stay at the Marriot East Side. The location is perfect for enjoying all that Manhattan has to offer. Three blocks from Grand Central, plenty of great places to eat, close enough to walk to broadway shows and Central Park. We reserved our room on Priceline and the result was fantastic. Our room was spacious by New York standards; the staff was very reindly and accomodating.

I've stayed her a couple of times and find this hotel to be a perfect spot to stay when in Manhattan. The front desk staff are EXCEPTIONAL & Jose the bell guy goes above and beyond to help. To get a taxi he walks out to 2nd, hails the cab, has them come pick you up at the hotel lobby. REALLY superb service.

If your looking for a great location in the city and a decent price, this is it. I could find a better deal for his caliber hotel anywhere. Room are small very small but if you're on vacation like we were, it doesn't matter. The beds were VERY comfortable!! Which is exactly what we needed after sightseeing all day. Don't call the 800 number to book, use the Marriott rewards site. We saved $100 a night doing this.

Huge thanks to Dennis and his staff for making my (and my mother's) stay one of a kind. I can't tell you enough good things about them. Desk staff that bend over backwards to accomodate you, lovely room service, quiet rooms that are clean and well appointed.... the list goes on. We asked twice for a couple of things, and both times, staff couldn't do enough to help. What's more, they seemed to tread the line between professional, and having fun with their jobs, which is nice to see. It's a three minute walk to Grand Central, so out of the centre, but there's plenty of amenities near by. Highly recommended for a quality stay.

I've stayed here about five times in total. I love the ease of access to the rest of Manhattan and the central location, with Grand Central station and the Chrysler building around the corner. The rooms are fine and the beds very comfortable. The gym is located at the top of the building , accessible via a quirky lift that just goes from the top room floor upwards. THe views from the gym are fantastic and the gym room itself has all the equipment you need. It's an old world type hotel with many unusual hotel features such as the oddly shaped lifts and passageways. I never use the hotel restaurant as it is far too expensive and there are great places to eat around town. I would definitely recommend this place if your budget allows.

The Marriot East Side is conveniently located and it is very easy to visit all of New York from there. The subway station is just around the corner and the many sights of New York, like the Rockefeller Center and Broadway are at walking distance.The hotel is very confortable and has a good breakfast.

I had a standard room with 1 large double bed. The bed itself was very comfortable, room was compact but you can still be comfortable for 2 people. Room was VERY clean, nice contemporary decor..looked fresh....nice size bathroom too. Wasn't much of a view but if you're there just for a nite or few, you're not there to be looking our your window anyway. The staff was very polite and curteous. I would recommend this hotel for anyone on business, visiting friends in the area, or similar.

For a hotel of this supposed quality, it is absurd that they charge 17 USD for a really bad wifi connection (only for 1 device), and only for 24 hours (not even that - it ends noon the following day). Also, the sink was really clogged up so the water was there forever. And the movies on TV had bad resolution and bad sound.Oh, bad outsourced expensive business centre.Awful business hotel.Nice staff, comfy beds, rather big rooms, good location.

5 minute walk from 5th Ave/Saks or Grand Central station, 10 min to Times Square and the theatre districts, this hotel is at a good mid-town location.The rooms are nice, fairly spacious (especially for NYC) and seems to be newly renovated. Good view, my corner-room had a spectacular view on the Chrysler building from the 32th floor, and no noise from the street at this altitude.The fitness on 35th floor has an impressive 360-degree view of mid-town, so you can experience sunrise while working out, quite memorable.I would consider returning due to the location, good value ($160) and rooms.

We stayed here a couple weekends ago. We read on foursquare that we should ask for a room with a view on one of the higher floors. We asked and we received. We stayed in a corner room on the 19th floor. Amazing view of the historic district on Lexington Avenue and we could even see a bit of the river out of the corner window. The room was pretty spacious by New York standards, had a big flat screen television, comfy bed, nice reading lights above the bed, and a little hallway leading to the bathroom which was also lovely. At the end of the hall was a closet to hang clothes and a safe. We had read earlier that parking was 60 bucks so we parked down the street for 30 and walked to the hotel. My only complaint is the noise at night. We could hear sirens and honking horns pretty frequently. Also our neighboring room was a having a little late night party that woke us up at 2:30am but they settled down shortly after that and we were able to go back to sleep.

Stayed here for a night during a wedding weekend.The room was clean and more than adequate albeit cramped/small given NYC size rooms. A bit smaller than expected in fact - this appears to be a much older hotel that underwent extensive renovation. All in all the room was more than fine and comfortable.The only other comment can be made is regarding check-in. It is listed as 4 pm, which is very late. We flew the redeye and as Marriott members with significant status asked repeatedly if we could check in early - as early as 8 am after our flight landed. We were never given warm or receptive answers over the phone, at all. People weren't persay rude, but certainly weren't going out of their way. Fortunately we had a friend's couch to crash on for the morning. My wife was able to leave bags and check in at 1 pm. So yes, I guess 1 pm is considered an early check in....... They even told her that she could have actually checked in hours earlier. It would have been nice if they could ahve called to tell her since we asked repeatedly for an early check-in. All in all - they did exceed their policies, which is great. But it just seems to me that some accomodation for those on early red-eye flights can be made, particularly if its someone with significant number of Marriott points.Any rate - the hotel is fine. A standard, clean Marriott in a good location.

I recently visited New York and was lucky enough to be at this hotel. It is an excellent, friendly place to stay, centrally situated so ideal for touring the area.Very friendly and helpful staff, nothing was too much trouble.I highly recommend this Hotel to people who are visiting New York for either pleasure or business...or of course both.

Super location in mid-town Manhattan. The rooms are typical NYC (smaller) but the furnishings are very nice.Maybe 5 blocks (?) from a major subway station.Few blocks from Times SquareLots a great restaurants near-by

I stayed here for a business trip to NYC. On the plus side, the hotel is conveniently located for anyone planning to explore NYC. I was also pleased with the bed, which provided sufficient support for people who get back pain if the mattress is too soft. On the minus side, the hotel feels like a throwback to the 20th century. I don't know when it was last renovated but the general look and feel is very *old*, from the lobby to the hotel rooms. I am not complaining about the small rooms because it's NYC after all. But the lighting (or rather lack thereof) -- with the exception of nice bed-mounted reading lights -- and a tiny window made me feel like a mole underground. The bathroom wallpapers and ceiling had lots of stains, and the shower was ancient and needed some serious recaulking. The A/C unit sounded like a subway train going by. None of that would surprise me at a Super 8 but from a Marriott I am expecting something nicer, even in New York. And my pet peeve: charging $17 for internet access on top of a $250+ room bill. Makes me mad.In summary, no big issues, wouldn't mind staying here again but wouldn't choose it on my own as a place I need to return to.

My husband and I stayed in this hotel for three nights. We were upgraded because my husband is a platinum member and therefore we had access to the concierge lounge. I haven't given this hotel 5 stars as we have stayed in more impressive Marriotts however this hotel is good for New York standards. A couple of things that could have been better.....the concierge lounge is not open on the weekend and no provision is made for breakfast on those mornings. This has not been the case for other Marriotts we have stayed. The breakfast (on Weekdays) and the hors d'oeuvres are pretty ordinary and we have seen better. Having said the above, the location is great and the rooms are very nice (as with all Marriotts). I would stay at this hotel again.

We decided to get out of Connecticut for the night and enjoy an evening in the city. I had a bunch of miles, some decided to stay at the Marriott. We picked the East Side due to its location. We didn't want to be in the "middle" of everything, but wanted to be close by. Since its on Lexington Avenue, you are a short walk to Park Ave, Madison Ave and all the shopping your credit card can handle.We were greeted the second we walked up to the counter. The gal couldn't have been nicer. She upgraded us to a room that was a bit larger then a regular king room. Located on the 22 floor, we were pleased when we walked in to see a roomy, immaculate room. The decor was tasteful, with ample lighting, outlets, and a nice sized closet. The bathroom was marble, with lots of towels, shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, q-tips and cotton balls. There is a small refrigerator perfect for picking up juice, water for the morning. The view was not that great, a big ugly air conditioner, but the other window had the entire top lighted portion of the Chrysler building! A wonder to look at from your bed at night. If you have a craving for sushi, check out Hatsuhana on 48th and Madison. A bit pricey but well worth it!
Great location, friendly staff, updated hotel near Grand Central and fine shopping.

Wonderful Hotel for a stay in NYC. Was able to walk to business meetings and enjoy walks to Time Square at night. The concierge facilities was one of the best I have ever seen at a Marriott. Great hotel for the cost. Excerise room was a blast as you looked out from the 35th floor.

This hotel is lovely, in a safe and central area, and so much to see nearby: Rockefeller Center, Times Square, Madison Avenue, Central Park, Grand Central, the UN, the MOMA, the NYC public library and Bryant Park, etc. We had a hard time finding restaurants to eat dinner at in this part, so do your research on where to eat before you stay here. Also, I don't give it an excellent rating because the service wasn't particularly friendly, though they were professional.

Great location....near subway stations, eating establishments, bars, and shopping. The room was larger than we had expected as compared to NYC standards. The room was a little noisy, but that was to be expected in the city. My husband and I felt safe walking in this area at night as there was a lot of activity going on in the area. The hotel did not have all of the fancy amenities as other hotels, but had the essentials. If I were to come back to NYC I would definitely stay here again.

The Marriott East side is located on Lexington Avenue just a few blocks to the east of times Square, in easy walking distance of Grand Central, Central Park, Rockerfeller, Tmes Square, and the metro for everywhere else. Its keeping good company opposite the Intercontinental Barclay and Waldorf Astoria and next to the Westin.The room was a standard one but well appointed, clean and quite spacius for a New York hotel, very comfortable large king size bed, easy chair, normal Desk Tv, wet bar and fridge which was really handy. there was a Ipod dock alarm clock and a coffee maker with supplies for a lovey brew.There were plenty of clean towels and lovely toiletries.The staff were helpful especially the doorman who was always offering assitance.Our only gripe was we had no remote control and had to report it 3 times before they brought us another one, so had a whole day/evening without tv. But then we weren't there to watch tv so it was not big problem just a small annoyance.

We stayed 3 nights at this hotel in December. The check-in staff weren’t too friendly and neither was the concierge when we asked him some questions but the location is ideal for enjoying Manhattan Our room was on the smaller side but that is to be expected for NY city. It was clean and appeared to be recently refurbished. We were on a higher floor but as previous reviews have mentioned the street noise was somewhat of an issue. While I normally don’t mind street noise as I feel it’s part of the overall ambience and experience of a new place we were woken up on night two to the sounds of what sounded like a very serious argument on the street between two gangs. No reflection on the hotel other than being able to hear it clearly from a higher floor. We didn’t eat in the hotel as NY has so many choices. One night we did go to the hotel bar for a nightcap and the bar staff were very friendly and mixed us delicious martinis. To sum up – great location but don’t expect a very personal hotel experience from a big city hotel chain. The one suggestion I would make to people grabbing cabs from outside their hotels is to be wary of those “cars with drivers” that the doormen appear to push you towards. Unless you are in a major rush to get somewhere it’s just not worth the money. We were heading downtown and were waiting for a cab outside our hotel on the Saturday night, as were a lot of other people, the doormen were encouraging us to take the car service for $45 but we knew a cab couldn’t be more than $15 and we were enjoying the people watching so we declined and took the next cab – 5 mins later. Our cab cost us $12 and that was with getting caught at lights. Overall, NY is always a good time and this hotel worked for what we needed.
A great location; friendly service; quiet rooms; clean rooms. A very good option in Manhattan

From the beginning, our experience was great. We were welcomed and found our room in order. The bed was incredibly comfortable - the best I've ever slept in, in a hotel. We were on the 14th floor and had an elevator that was dedicated to the upper floors. It was very small, but quick. All the amenities you would want were provided. It was exactly what we expected. The hotel is close enough to Broadway, many fine restaurants and store, 5th Avenue, etc.

We stayed two nights at this property. The staff was very pleasant. We dealt mostly with the Concierge desk and Doorman for assistance and everyone was always friendly and helpful. The room was very cleaned. Would recommend

In today's world, Internet connections and the quality of broadband services to the business traveler are almost more important than the room itself. The Internet connections at the Marriott East in NYC are THE WORST! This hotel has contracted out its Internet Connections to a third party service provider, and the Internet Services provided are functionally nonexistent. If you need reliable Internet Connections - choose another hotel!

This hotel is in a great location. It is only about 10 short blocks from Bloomingdale's and close to Rockefeller Center as well as restaurants and shopping.
