The rooms are basic Marriott rooms and are not too small considering it is Manhattan. We liked the hotel and it served our purpose during Christmas weekend, but it was not as nice as some of the other Marriott's we have stayed at in other parts of the United States. Also housekeeping did not get to cleaning our room until about 5PM.

Definitely not a category 7 Marriott. We used points on NYE but the room rate was 600.00 for an extremely tiny room with an even smaller bathroom. The heat in the room was unbearable that we needed to put on the air which got very cold so there was no moderate temperature. We are gold members and there is no concierge lounge on weekends and breakfast vouchers were not given to compensate. No room upgrade although their website had availablity. The internet in the room was in and out. The lounge was excellent and so were the drinks. If it wasnt for the location we probably would not return.

Close to my meetings and to the Grand Central Market (my favorite!) but old, dingy and dirty. For the price, I was very disappointed. Water stains on the ceiling, stains of (?) on the carpet, wall paper lifting everywhere. But the bathroom was clean enough. But the view: Big windows overlooking a wall! Couldn't even see if it was night or day, because the sun would not get to the windows.

Travelled with a group in christmass so i cant be sure about the exact price, but sleeping quality was perfect(the bed is huge and the pillows plenty) quite spacious for a new york's hotel standard room and the location was very central.

My wife and I stayed two nights here after Christmas. I am a Marriott Gold member and we stayed on points. The hotel was very crowded. I can’t say whether this is always the case or if it was because it was the Christmas holiday. (Interestingly, there were five or six large hotels in the same vicinity as this one, so there was a lot of tourist traffic.) The room (size, cleanliness, amenities, etc.) was up to Marriott standards and the location was very good—easy access to the subway and Grand Central Station. My only complaint was that the Concierge Lounge was understaffed and excessively crowded. Moreover, it had the most underwhelming breakfast choices I have experienced at a Marriott Concierge Lounge—scrambled eggs, bagels/bread, oatmeal and fresh fruit. The evening appetizers were just as lame—salad and chicken nuggets. One morning we went to the Concierge Lounge at 10:15, thinking we would miss the crowd. Instead no food was available at this time. The Lounge’s posted hours were till 10:30 so I would have expected breakfast to be available till then. Next time I would consider a more out-of-the-way hotel to get away from the crowds.

My first thought when I got to my room was "is this really a Marriott hotel"? It's pricy and in midtown Manhattan so I didn't expect to see paint peeling and hanging from the ceiling. I immediately asked for another room and was given another tiny standard room even though I'm Platinum and the hotel was not sold out. I asked for an upgraded room and they gave me a lousy interior view standard room. The lobby staff could hardly have cared that people were staying there. The front desk people were not cordial and the phone rung 15 times before anyone answered it. The Concierge lounge was closed Fri. - Sun and the front desk people refused to give us any bfst vouchers even though almost every other property gives them to Platinum guests when the lounge is closed. This property is below average overall and I wouldn't stay here again.

The service and reception at the Lexington Ave. Marriott was extremely disappointing, to say the least. From the moment we arrived there we felt as though we were putting them out, and their go-to phrase the entire weekend seemed to be, 'there's nothing we can do'.My fiancé and I and a friend of ours stayed recently for the New Year's Eve weekend. We had booked far in advance through hotels.com (which we discovered later did not help us receive help when we arrived) for a room with two beds. We were immediately downgraded when we got there because families took precedence. They put three of us in a room with one king-sized bed and did not bring up the roll-away cot we were promised until FIVE phone calls and 24-hours later. Two men above six feet tall had to share a bed with another woman, also not exactly short. We found out after the fact that breakfast was not included as it usually is, nor was internet. When we asked if they could provide the internet in lieu of the inconvenience with room change, there was 'nothing they could do.' We purchased internet there for 24 hours at a rate of $17--and only received 7 hours use. Again, when we approached the front desk and explained, there was 'nothing they could do', but we were more than welcome to use the WiFi in their lobby for a fee of $7 per half hour, or something ridiculous.The following day, on New Year's Eve, we found discovered a glass of orange juice, to be brought to our room, was no less than $11.74. It cost $4 for someone to push a button and come up an elevator with the glass, and they expected a tip!The following morning, after they finally brought us a roll-away (too late) we were given our bill. They had charged us twice for internet use we were barely afforded, and a $3.50 occupancy fee, which was downright embarrassing. We phoned well ahead for the valet to bring us our car, clearing stating 11 30. When we were promptly at the front desk for the allotted time, to our surprise we were informed the car had actually been brought up for 11am and had been taken back.We complained to the front desk, at which time they blamed any inconveniences on the fact we had booked with hotels.com (essentially, they didn't get the cut they usually do at a high-traffic time of year and couldn't guarantee anything) though they still took $50 off our $120 parking fee because my fiancé was polite with his complaints.Overall, the experience with Marriott east side in no way ruined our trip, but was a complete let down. The best service I had there the entire time was from a bar-tender who didn't even work for the hotel.The location is great, and the newly renovated hotel is beautiful, but you're taking your chances with this one.

I used points and compared to the Marriott Marquee i did not feel that this was a Category 7 experience. Certainly- Lexington and 49th was a very good location- and a short walk to the theater district and Rockefeller Center. But i thought the lobby and room was just average- in fact the room seemed small to me but that may have been what i was given because i used points- so no real complaints there. To get the health club there is a separate elevator that goes from the 32nd to the 35th floor. BTW- the health club was a good size with decent equipment- so that was a plus. Also, the history of this hotel- and the art work by artists Georgia Okeefe and her husband may be of interest to some. Overall good- but not great.

When the Marriott Marquee was unavailable, we decided to stay at the Marriott East Side which was newly renovated. It was a short walk to Rockerfella Center and the Theater District. We found the hotel lobby to be beautifully decorated for the holidays and very clean. The service from the bellmen and the hotel staff was excellent. The rooms were clean and had adequate space. The bathroom was clean as well. The only downside was the $60 parking fee, but the service was for 24 hours so it wasn't that bad for NYC prices and was much more convenient than finding an alternative parking garage.

The Good-Convenient location: At 49th and Lexington in Midtown. Close to train stations. Walking distance to Times Square and other attractions. Plenty of eats nearby - from end restaurants of Park Avenue to chains like Chipotle to street food (delicious and cheap at $5).-Comfortable rooms: Though the rooms are quite small (this is Manhattan, after all), they are comfortably appointed with flat screen TVs, coffee maker, hair dryer, ironing board, safe, etc. Generally quiet if you ask for a room on the "quiet side" of the hotel and on higher floors. Get a room overlooking the street on the lower floors and there are chances that you may hear traffic, if you are a light sleeper.-This is a historic hotel for history buffs. Georgia O'Keefe, the famous American painter, lived here with her husband, Alfred Stieglitz, when the hotel was called The Shelton and created many of her well-known works here.The Minor Idiosynchracys-There are two sets of elevators. One for ground floor to 16th and the other from 17th upward. No problem, except if you want to use the health club, it is on the 35th. To get there, you take an elevator to 32nd floor and then another elevator to 35th floor. -The rooms tend to be smaller (I think) than the Marriott Marquis, which is in Times Square. I personally prefer this hotel because the Marquis can be like a zoo, and somewhat harder to get in and out of.OverallA good, solid hotel.
Business trip in decemeber. Stayed two nights; it is OK although nearly $600 per night for the quality of sleep, wasn't great.
Stayed using points, definitely not a category 7 hotel for 35,000 points a night. Clean room, friendly staff and a great location but the hotel was just average.
The location and value of this hotel is hard to beat. Rooms are typical Marriott, but are clean and roomy enough.

Although one might think being on the east side would not be accessible it actually is located in a very opportune location to Madison, 5th ave and times square shopping and tourist spots. Concierge club was one of the nicest but service was lackluster otherwise from the front desk to the concierge. It ended with me asking for an envelope for my bill and they just handed me one. Food was barely edible. This is NYC and its clear there is no attention to detail here. Bathroom was dark otherwise everything else was standard issue. They did not change out our playpen sheet even though it was clearly stained. We'd stay again for location and for not being in a super busy area like times sq but that's it.
Room very small. Water temperature in shower very hard to regulate. Small lobby. Not impressed.

Stayed here using points. The property was recently renovated and it is a real class act. Impressive building, lovely interior areas and the room was modern, roomy and comfortable. Best of all was the friendliness of the staff. We got the most attentive and appropriate recommendations from the concierge. He was sympathetic to this suburban mom whose daughter wanted to go out clubbing. After making several great suggestions, he could appreciate that a "mom and 18yr old" demographic was possibly not one that would make it past the bouncer. Given that constraint, the concierge still got us to a fab clubbing experience that totally made our stay in NY memorable! Thanks Mr. Concierge (sorry I didn't get your name) and thanks to all the staff at the Marriott East Side. Great Property!
Convenient location, fairly big rooms (for NYC). Otherwise, nothing much to complain or praise about this place.

Stayed for one night at this hotel. Staff was great. 2 couples stayed - one had a problem with internet service and both rooms had fairly noisy fans for the heating. Other than that the hotel was clean, rooms were standard size for New York. No street noise from our rooms and we were on the 11 and 12th floors. Window opened which was nice to get some fresh air. Bathrooms were clean and lots of water pressure. We had a late flight the next day, so they held our bags for us and got us a cab on our return. Would recommend. Great location and comfy beds.

great doormen; older hotel that has been renovated; my room was very small but quiet(2712); no view but preferred the quiet. i told my wife it was about the size of our master bathroom at home. Concierge lounge was a zoo- seemed like everyone in the hotel qualified? Exercise room was fair. However, the location was great for all of my meetings and dinners. starbucks one block south.

A little background – during a weekend in New York, my traveling companion was admitted to the hospital. There was no firm date for release so I had to book hotel rooms at the last moment. After staying at four hotels, I finally checked in to the Marriott East Side. I had a series of one night reservations so that I could cancel and leave with only a day notice (reservations required cancellation the day before arrival.) Some of the nights used Marriott Reward Points and some were paid. The stay extended into the weekend of the New York Marathon so hotels were full or very expensive.When I arrived at the Marriott East Side, all went well. Check-in was easy and I mentioned that I had a series of one night reservations. No problem or so I was told. My room was exactly what I had requested. Since this would be my home for the next several nights, I unpacked and was relieved that I’d not need to pack/move/unpack again. I had done that four days in a row and it gets old. As an elite member of Marriott Rewards, I enjoyed a visit to the Concierge Lounge before departing for the hospital to visit my friend. The next day, I returned in the afternoon from a hospital visit and found that my key no longer would open the door. I went to reception to get new keys and was informed I’d have to change rooms. At check-in they had forgotten to block me into the same room for all of my reservations. They had already blocked my room for another arriving guest so I had no choice but to move. I don’t know what they would have done if I had not returned until later that evening – my stuff was in the room. So, for a fifth day I packed and moved to a new room. Now the problem began. I could not get WiFi reception in the new room. I called and was connected to their technical support service who seemed to know about the problem. They said it was most likely the router on the floor and they’d have that reset. However, the next morning I still could not establish a connection to the Internet. In the hallway, I had no problem establishing connection but my room was a dead spot. On my way to the lounge, I saw another guest sitting in the hallway with his laptop so I’m guessing the problem occurs with more than one room. That’s inexcusable for a business hotel.I thought I would simply use the computers in the lounge or at least connect to WiFi while in the lounge. I then learned that the lounge would not be open after breakfast hours on Friday until Sunday evening. In other Marriott properties, you can at least access the lounge even if there are no other services available in the lounge. Not at this property! When the lounge is closed, no one can access the lounge. I asked about breakfast on weekends for elite guests and was told there was no option. That was a surprise and I learned a “loophole” in the Marriott Rewards program. If a hotel does not have a lounge, certain levels of elite members are given breakfast in the dining room. If the hotel has a lounge, you’re given access to the lounge instead. If they have a lounge but it is closed, you’re simply on your own for breakfast. After complaining, I was comped breakfast for the two days the lounge would be closed.I was very surprised to learn the lounge would be closed on the weekend. The hotel was sold out and they were charging premium prices due to the marathon. Seems to me this would have been a good weekend to keep the lounge open.Even though this is an older property, they do have the new Marriott beds and they were comfortable. Housekeeping did a decent job of cleaning the rooms. Water pressure and temperature in the shower did vary a bit during a shower but not enough to make me get out of the shower. There was very little counter space in the bathroom. Wake-up calls arrived on schedule. Overall, the hotel and rooms feel older, dated, and occasionally shabby. Internet service was spotty as mentioned above. Even when I tried using the wired computers in the lounge (when it was open), the response time was terribly slow. There frequently was a line at reception but my waits were not overly long.Maybe I was being overly critical because I was preoccupied with my friend’s hospitalization. My stay in New York had become unexpectedly extended and I really needed the Internet to keep up with issues at work. This was a time when I needed Marriott to come through and provide the services I’ve come to expect. Usually that happens, but it didn’t happen at the Marriott East Side.On Sunday (the day of the marathon), I was happy to check out and move next door to the new Hyatt Lex58 . But that’s another review….Overall, I was disappointed in the property, their handling of my reservations, and the awful state of Internet service in the hotel. I’d certainly encourage others to look elsewhere at this price point and in this neighborhood. There certainly are plenty of other options within several blocks.

Just returned from a four night stay at this Marriott. We were warmly welcomed by John the doorman who was extremely helpful from the time we arrived until the time we departed the hotel. He arranged for Town Car service to LGA in the most efficient manner.The Front Desk staff was not overly friendly and did not welcome us but did immediately check us in early. We had WONDERFUL service in the restaurant by Caesar. He was friendly, helpful and very entertaining. We felt like we were at home every time we ate in the restaurant. Had Room Service twice for breakfast. Room service was expensive but fast and the food was good.I did notice that the lobby will undergo renovation. While it is ok now, it does need a good facelift with restrooms on the same level. The hotel is located in midtown and you will need to take a cab if you are unable to walk a short distance to certain areas. The doormen are so nice and do an excellent job. You will not have to wait for long at all on a cab or limo.

I stay here frequently for business purposes due to its convenience to our office but this is only an average hotel. While there have been updates to the lobby and rooms, the elevators are 50 years out of date, slow and small. The concierge floor is spacious but unremarkable. Unlike many other Marriott concierge floors, especially those overseas, it has a relatively poor selection of free items and charges top dollar for alcoholic drinks. The hotel has a fairly decent gym but some of the equipment is old and needs replacing. It is on the top of the building and does have a great view of the city. The hotel is in a good location, close to Radio City Music Hall, Rockefeller Center, and a 10-15 minute walk from Times Square and the Theaters. Room service is quick although the food is just average.

This is a nice Marriott-- have been here a few times, and experience was very nice. You never know with Marriotts (or the better chains) these days-- sometimes it's really surprisingly low-level, but it's nice here. Rooms are very different. It is true that this is surprisingly a noisy part of town-- and while it's close to Bloomingdales, and yes, it's in midtown, when the night comes, be warned: almost everything around here shuts down. Still, I like it here.

I recently stayed at the Marriott East Side at 49th and Lexington and could not have been more pleased. It was not my first time staying at this hotel, but it had been a few years. Once again, I was not disappointed,. The front desk staff could not be more pleasant and the doorman and bellman were equally delightful. The rooms are very well appointed and clean and the midtown location is perfect.

I had an extended stay here (2+ weeks) for work. While most of my time was spent outside the hotel working, my downtime in the room and club lounge were very good. I had to change rooms during my stay due to a water leak from the room upstairs. But other than that the rooms were comfortable and nicely appointed. But I also agree with some other reviews that the bathrooms were small. The location in mid-town was great. Easy access to the subway or walking distance to most locations. The concierge lounge provided a relaxing experience and helped to unwind from the work day. The front desk staff were helpful and accommodating. If given the opportunity I would return to this hotel for work or vacation.

We celebrated birthdays recently at The Marriott East Side, in NYC, Lexington Avenue and 49th Street. What a great pick! The hotel's wonderful doorman, Patrick, absolutely made our entrance to this Marriott ----perfect! He is fabulous, and was very helpful! Room, while cozy, (ie., small,) was immaculate, and its proximity to everything made up for it all. We were across the street from the Waldorf, a stone's toss from great shopping, and close to fabulous restaurants. Check it out! This Marriott has been totally renovated, and resurrected to its flair and glamour of days gone by--Beautiful in every regard. One thing, we did not dine at all in the hotel. So, no comment there.
user_name:
mwetris
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Rooms are nicely appointed, but small for 4 people-- especially the bathroom. All the same the 4 of us fared well in the room. The towels are not thick, but they're fine. We found the desk clerks particularly helpful especially with concierge type questions. The concierge really didn't add anything helpful-- just looked up facts on the computer as easily as we could have, while the desk clerks knew which subway station was best etc.If you arrive at Grand Central it's an easy 6 block walk to the hotel-- definitely walk if you are at all able to. There is a subway stop (5,6) just a few block north which will get you easily to lower Manhattan for walking the Brooklyn Bridge, visiting the 9-11 Memorial or catching the ferry to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. There is a Starbucks right by the subway entrance (west side of the street). Several breakfast places in the vicinity including a Pain Quotidien a short walk east.

Great location; attentive doormen; wonderful concierge lounge service.I arrived early on a Friday morning for an extended weekend stay and was accommodated with my request for an early check in. The concierge lounge extended their breakfast hours until my party and I had finished for the morning and assisted us with our plans for the weekend.Disappointat that the lounge was closed Sat&Sun; but this is the case with most Marriotts I’ve been to.I stayed with two other family members and specified when I made the reservation that we needed extra towels, pillows and a bar fridge. I didn’t have to repeat myself – during our entire stay, we had more than ample supply. The bathroom was a good size but didn’t have a vent or fan which meant that it steamed up rather quickly. The room doesn’t offer much in terms of views; mostly since the hotel is situated in the upper east side but it was remarkably quiet. Despite the concrete views, I was surprised at the amount of light that came into the room.Very comfortable beds - they must use memory foam! Slept through the night with no problem.The fan/heating was a little tricky. It didn’t seem to work properly and would make a rattling sound when we tried to adjust it so we turned it off. Very minor inconvenience.Great location in terms of access to transit – less than a 5 minute walk to the 51st street station. Grand Central is about a 10 minute walk; Bloomingdales is about another 15 minute walk in the other direction; and Central Park is about a 20 minute walk away crosstown. The doorman arranged for a private car (very affordable too) to take us to the airport – little did we know it would be a stretch limousine; a great little surprise to mark the end of a wonderful weekend.

I stayed in this hotel for 2 nights this past week. We stayed on a friends hotel discount so I certainly won't complain about the price! It couldn't have been better. The hotel was clean..the views sucked but that's new York for you! All and all it was a great trip and the hotel staff was super nice.
user_name:
Jasmine H
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel was perfect for walking to Times Square, and Rockefeller, etc. The doorman was extremely helpful - he asked us if we needed help finding restaurants. Everyone was cordial. It was very crowded as we stayed over the Columbus Day holiday weekend. It was a comfortable room, but small. The room had 2 beds and the one I selected looked mussed as if it had been slept in. I pulled the sheets back the the fitted sheet was stained. The bathroom had no vent, and it steamed up very quickly when the shower was running. We had a fantastic weekend in NYC. Overall, it was still a great weekend!

Excellent service, great staff. Food in restaurant was good. The room was small but to be expected considering the location. It is close to Grand Central station which was our focal point to access the subway to take us around Manhattan. Only complaint was the noisy fan and the cooling / heating system was fussy. Great location with access to lots of shopping.

This beautiful hotel was convenient to many New York sites, comfortable and well-appointed and each time I walked through the doors I gave a sigh of relief, leaving the busy New York outside. If you are a frequent Marriott traveler and have access to the concierge lounge upstairs, be sure to talk to Margaret, the most helpful and informative of all the concierge at the hotel. She saved us 50% on Rockette tickets and recommended good restaurants and sites.

I was able to book this hotel using Marriott reward points which was a good deal. Drove into the city late Thursday night and had no problem with valet or check in, staff was very helpful. Our party of four had two king bed rooms. We had no trouble changing one room from a double to a king. We had rooms on the 6th and 9th floors. The 6th floor faced Lexington Ave and you could hear some street noise through the window. The 9th floor was an inside room and was quieter. The rooms were clean and comfortable, we did have an issue with the tub on the 6th not draining well but it seemed fine after a day or so. We were able to use the concierge lounge on 16th, it had a nice selection for breakfast.The bar/restaurant area was nice if not a little expensive, but expected in NYC.I thought the location was great, just a couple blocks from 5th Ave and Rockafeller Center. And it wasn't a long walk to Times Square. Checkout was easy, just used the TV. And calling down for the car was maybe a 20 min. wait on a Sunday.Great experience, I would definately stay here again.

Location, location, location. And it's great! Away from Times Square, but close to everything. My wife is a platinum member, and we got there really early (9am), but they had a room for us and we were able to check in. Service was great. My problem was with the room, primarily bathroom. First thing was, there's no vent. So when you take a shower, the bathroom turns into a sauna. And the other problem, the shower itself. Water pressure was low (we were on 27th floor), so it was a pretty crappy shower to take. That aside, good hotel.
I stayed here for 4 nights. Nice location, the staff were friendly when I needed them. The view from the room wasnt great but hey I wasnt in the room most of the time anyway.

Extremely clean property with a great location. Rooms are larger than many in the city. This hotel was updated recently and has shown continuous improvements thru the years. I was only here one night but will come back. Staff was nice, rooms well appointed.

The Marriott East side looks very impressive from the outside. It's in a great location. Close to everything.This is my first stay at a NYC hotel. I don't know how it is in comparison to other NYC hotels, but compared to other hotel rooms overall the room is tiny. I guess that comes with the territory in NYC. $500 a night is outrageously expensive for such a tiny room. The only reason we stayed here was because my husband has platinum status with Marriott. The only thing that made this stay so special is their concierge lounge on the 16th floor. It's a beautiful outdoor terrace with view to both rivers. The breakfast they provide is phenomenal. The concierge lounge was worth the stay, but only if you're a Marriott member

Stayed here for one night and found the hotel to be very nice, the room was well appointed and clean but the view from it was not very good as it looked out onto the wall of another building. We ordered a couple of Marriott burgers from the room service menu and these were the best Marriot burgers that we have ever had. The breakfast was excellent everything was cooked to perfection and tasted great, wish we had booked another few nights here as the food was great.

Got a great price using the AAA rate. I was pleasantly surprised to see how much bigger the room was compared to the other hotels where my friends stayed at; it was a two-bed room with plenty of room, extra chair and a hallway on the 11th floor (corner room). The bed was comfortable and there was extra down feather pillows.The only downer was the shower. Water drained very slowly so you were in a puddle. But, we kept forgetting to tell the management so I take partial responsibility. It would have been great if hoousekeeping noticed it too.Overall, good stay in a great neighborhood (near Waldorf Astoria, W Hotel, St. Patrick's Cathedral) and close to the subway.Would definitely stay here again.
Stayed here for the first time over the weekend and I would definitely stay here again. Great location very good sized rooms. Hotel was in good shape the staff was really friendly.

I have stayed at this location several times for business, and I have been pleased with the location as well as the overall feel of the hotel. There are a number of dinning locations both cheap and expensive within a couple of blocks. The in room dinning options are also very good, however, breakfast only starts at 6am which has been a problem for me several times since I have had to catch an 8 o'clock flight at LGA. The staff was also very pleasant and helpful. Overall, I will stay at this location again when I am back on business.

Our group (mainly mothers and daughters) travel to NY each spring for a theater weekend. We received absolutely wonderful service and cooperation from the NY Marriott East Side. We have booked again for next year and look forward to the comfy beds, great location and the excellent customer service we receive from them. I highly recommend this hotel!

I stayed for 4 nights for leisure. Most of the guests were tourists and organized groups. UPSIDE: The location is very good with numerous near-by dining and shopping options. There’s a subway station one block away. The Concierge team is professional and efficient. DOWNSIDE: When I stayed the hotel was full and it seemed to affect the service. Front desk provided an average service; sometimes not enough staff was available. Not enough elevators for hotel peak hours with sometimes unreasonable waiting time in lobby. Onsite parking is expansive and remote. My room was upgraded due to my Marriott reward status and was OK with no view. The rest of the facility is aging and looks like it could use an overhaul. SUMMARY: if you get a good price and an upgraded room – value is good.

We stayed 3 nights at this aging hotel in a suburb location. The good: Lots within walking distance including a famous bagel place, Mc Donalds, a good diner and a Sports Authority if you forgot your sneakers. Easy walk to shopping and if ambitious to Central Park. Can't beat location.Our room old and small with good beds but bath was tiny. Room decor and rug could use a remodel. It as pricey as our weekend was popular with tourists. New restaurant off lobby serves good breakfasts at usual hotel prices.Stay here when hotel prices out of sight, prefer more modern rooms. Heavily used by tourists.

Loved this hotel. We got a great rate through a group connection and decided to splurge. Parking was expensive, $60, but we were near to the subway, about 20 Starbucks, Grand Central Terminal (Station). We were maybe 6 blocks from Times Square and only a few more to 30 Rock. Even Central Park wasn't that far of a walk.Super comfortable beds and plenty of pillows. Very large bathroom which was nice. This place is very well decorated and staffed. The elevators were fast and plentiful. I didn't wait more than 10 seconds for one. The 2 queen bedroom that we had was fairly small but expected.There was some remodeling going on but you didn't even know that unless you ventured off into those areas. Not an issue whatsoever.I loved it and would stay again in a heartbeat.
user_location: Santa Barbara de Samana, Dominican Republic
user_name:
TourSamanaWithTerry
Santa Barbara de Samana, Dominican Republic

review_body: I was most disappointed with this hotel. My room was a shoebox and the bed linen had seen better days. The sheet and the bed cover both had holes in them.The carpet was quite soiled.The room needed a deep clean and a total overhaul.The staff were just ok - they could have benefitted from a training course in customer service.The only positive was the location.

My husband and I were celebrating our 30th anniversary and visiting our daughter who moved to NY for work. Upon arrival the registration hostess upgraded us to a very nice corner room on a higher floor in honor of our special celebration. The room was a nice size - larger than other NY hotel rooms with a nice sofa and open area in the middle of the room. The view was of Lexington Avenue. The windows did not open very much so you could not get much fresh air into the room.The bellmen were very helpful with the luggage & taxis - all with a smile. The lobby has been updated and very trendy and inviting as you enter the hotel. The bar area is new and has a nice upscale feel to it.As platinum members we had access to the concierge lounge which was one of the better lounges that we have visited. They have morning breakfast of eggs and some starch, cereal, fruits, and beverages. There is no sausage or bacon - just cold cuts on the other side if you want something to go with the eggs. During our stay we were fortunate to have the pleasure of meeting Kendra, one of the concierges in the lounge. Once she found out it was our anniversary she surprised us with a wonderful bottle of champagne and dessert. She really made our stay a pleasant one and we felt like we gained a very nice new friend at the hotel.The location of the hotel is within walking distance to Grand Central Station, bus stops, Times Square, Rockerfeller Center and 5th Avenue shops.On a previous visit we stayed at the Marriott Marquis in Time Square. I much prefer the Marriott East Side for its location and less chaotic environment. This hotel also provides a small refrigerator in the room which is an added bonus that most hotels do not offer. Thanks to Kendra and all the staff that we encountered we plan to stay at this hotel every time we are in NY.

I have stayed there a number of times over the past few years. It's in a great location on the east side, close to Grand Central and many subway lines. If you are a Gold/Platinum member, the concierge lounge is one of the best I've seen. The rooms on the back side are always quiet and the beds are very comfy. Most rooms are bigger than your typical NY size rooms. They recently redid the lobby and it looks much more stylish. The service is terrific - never have had any problems and I can't say that about other Marriotts. Parking is very expensive so park elsewhere if you have a car.

We spent 3 nights at this hotel and I must say the service was excellent. The location was within walking distance to Rockefeller Center, Times Square, Shopping, Central Park and Grand Central Station. I would definately stay at this Marriott again.
Great location for Mid Town. Lots of other hotels nearby. Average room. Old feeling. Poor lighting. Terrible pillows and mattress. Great shower-strong and hot. Plenty of towels. Small fridge in room.

I have stayed here frequently in my trips to New York.Great location. 25 minutes from LGA. Newly remodeled entrance, which is very cool. Wonderful concierge lounge. Decent fitness facility, although equipment does seem to be broken down, and its quite a trip to get there.Room sizes are decent, considering this is New York. Friendly staff and clean.There are lots of hotels near here, and I have stayed at all of them. They are all pretty standard, so I tend to stay here for my point options and free internet for Marriott Rewards members.

I'm travelling a lot on business not normally in New York but all over Europe. I stayed at this hotel for a few days and have to say:The location of the hotel is fantastic, the staff were extremely friendly and very helpful (as always when I stay at Marriotts), the rooms are nicely done and very clean. I would defiantly stay there again when in NY and can recommend the hotel for business and leisure travellers. I really enjoyed the iPod/iPhone docking station in the room as well as the room service.
The rooms can be a little small, but this is a clean hotel and you can walk to Times Square, Rockefeller Plaza, Penn Station, etc. as well as the subway.

Recently visited NY and had to split my stay between to properties, one Marriott, one other. Both properties were great, but this hotel is a NY classic. The Marriott East Side is a understanded darling of NY hotels, a mid-size property with a lot of history, especially if you like cats. A hotel from its inception, it was cared for by one family until it was converted to a Marriott. The rooms are "old" style with high ceilings and small dimensions, but what this property lacks in size, it has in character. Understand this is not the Marquis or Downtown Financial District Marriott, but it has charm and the lobby is beautiful. The rooms are adequete for couples or for a solo trip, would not recomend with a family. The bar is something you need to enjoy while on property and the location is top notch. Right in mid-town, the name East Side does not do it justice. Would have stayed all four nights, but the rate doubled half way through our visit. I was able to get a rate for less than 200 a night and this property for that price is worth it, better than most for that rate in NY. Historically the only full service Marriott in Manhattan Cheaper is the Financial District Property on weekends (sometimes $150.00). If you find yourself in Mid-town and are not in search of the Marquis type hotel, this is a Top End Marriott, wish we could have stayed longer!

We spent 14 nights in Sept 2011 at the East Side Marriot & found it to be a nice place in a great location.The room was standard, very clean & comfortable.The lobby was under renovation during our stay & is starting to look better now. The staff are friendly & very helpful. The location is within walking distance of Rockefeller Centre, Times Square, Grand Central & Central Park. There is a subway nearby to get you anywhere in NY.It's close to everything without all the noise of a very busy city.

This hotel lives upto the Marriott name. Great location. Close to Times Square, Central Park, Rockefeller Center. Subway ride to Battery Park and the Statue of Liberty. The staff was awesome and the room was perfect.
user_name:
JTrips9999
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Hotel is as typical as they come...King bed, 1 chair, a desk, & a normal bathroom. No frills. Hall ways were old. Location was fine for midtown & the cool spot next door is the W for fun.

I arrived late in the hotel and they don’t have water or any other drinks in the room and there is no room service available after 11pm. In practices, you should leave to buy a bottle of water or remember in advance that this “luxury” is not available there. Not a big deal but unacceptable for a hotel of this level…
Great location. Close to Times Square, Central Park, Rockefeller Center. Subway ride to Battery Park and the Statue of Liberty. The staff was awesome and the room was perfect.

I loved NYC. It was our first time there and I fell in love with this city. Just a few things I would watch for 1) Restaurants are very expensive but the delis serve excellent food at a good price, and nice seating arrangements. 2) If you're one who needs a restroom there are no public washrooms anywhere. 3) Take only the yellow cabs, the unlicensed ones have no meters and will charge anywhere from 2 to 3 times as much. Make sure to use the service of the hop on/ hop off buses. They are the best!

The Marriott East Side has been our home away from home while visiting NYC over the past 6 years. It's truly one of the best locations in NYC. It's walking distance to Rock. Center and St. Patrick's Cathedral, terrific restaurants and shopping. The rooms are spacious, well kept and comfortable-in line with the standard of the rest of the hotel. The fitness center is unique and has a birds eye view of the city. The concierge floor is efficient, convenient and a good place to have your morning coffee, an afternoon snack or a quick drink in the evening-it's well worth the price. There's a new restaurant which is current, modern and edgy. This will eventually adjoin the new renovated lobby. The staff and the management are hands on and they will make your stay relaxing, comfortable and safe. Bravo to the East Side Marriott for a job well done. It's always our first choice when we stay in NYC!
user_name:
Travelm25
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed at this property for just one night. Small but comfortable and clean rooms. Well kept and updated, modern inside, beds fairly new and well maintained. I wouldn't suggest this hotel if you are looking for "above and beyond" service received at some other Marriotts I've stayed at, the front desk was very warm and pleasant chatting with each other and laughing, but cool, and standoffish with the guests they were checking in and out. Still polite, quick, and efficient with my check in and check out, just not warm and hospitable. Asked for a taxi and was told it would be a long wait (the bridges were limited access for 9/11, plus it was fashion week), that I was pretty much SOL, ("what do you want me to do..?".) and take the subway. Tell it how it is I guess...

Booked hotel at last minute due to Hurricane Irene, couldn’t leave the city so had to spend an extra 2 nights. Marriott was the only place with room for 3, and at a decent price, with good reviews. Room was nice, a little on the old side though had the plus of a fridge! Had a room on the 8th floor with a view of a brick wall. Internet was $16.99 a day..outrageous, and terribly slow! Hardly any storage, if any.

We stayed 5 nights starting the night before the storm Irene.Because we have been in this hotel several times we asked for a high floor room.The peolple at the reception desk were very friendly and helpful and we got a nice corner room.Althoug the hotel restaurant was very crowded the night of Irene they did everything to give us a table and provided good service.The location is one of the best you can imagine.If WIFI would be included instead op paying 15$ a day I should not cross the street to theWaldorf Astoria to read my emails for free.Altogether it was an excellent stay.
Stayed at the Marriott East Side in NYC in May 2011. A friendly get-together from three continents! Nice staff, fabulous location... would not hesitate to recommand it!

I've stayed at the Marriott East Side many times in the last ten years, and typically have had nothing but good things to say about it. The hotel staff is perfectly pleasant, and the rooms are more than adequate. In fact, if you know which room to ask for specifically (i.e., by number), you can snag some very special rooms as they have multiple layouts in this turn-of-the-century brick pile and some of the rooms are tiny, and some are huge. The check-in was fine and quick, and in fact the bell-hop was extra kind, holding an umbrella over my head and telling me, "let me just make sure you're safe and dry and I will bring your suitcase in just a moment," which was a really pleasant way to be greeted.Reception lady was charming, and I got my preferred room, huge and very nice and clean. They've done some "soft" refurbishments, although the old furniture is still pretty much there.Access to the lounge was just fine, and I even had breakfast there. My only small ding, they give you hot scrambled eggs, but no bacon or sausage. Would it really be too much to ask for some breakfast meat? I mean, my corporate rate was over $400 a night so this is not a cheap hotel... Hmmm...Other small ding, the lobby concierge was gone by 8:30pm, which I think is a little harsh. I needed some help, and had to get it elsewhere. I'd expect longer hours from this property.Finally, lobby rennovations are going forward full-steam ahead. The lobby bar is now cut off from the lobby, and the lobby desk has been traumatized. I'm not really sure why a rennovation is necessary - it was absolutely fine and charming "old school" previously, and I really think they should have kept it the same way. This is probably due to some new young whippersnapper at corporate saying, "let's see, we need to be more cutting-edge, let's re-do everything!" Well, guess what, when you have something that works well, why tinker with it?I'll be back to this hotel, so I guess the rennovations won't scare me away. I would recommend this hotel - it will probably meet or exceed your expectations.
user_name:
LicensedTraveller
New York City, New York

review_body: We were in the hotel during "Irene". The housekeeping and reception staff were wonderful ! We had dinner in the restaurant and were happy that we didn't have to leave the hotel that night.The room (a corner-room) was ok with a good bed.The location is super.

the rooms were clean but small (its NYC of course) and the concierge desk was overly helpful, very courteous staff. For a family its great but for couples its nothing speacial if you want a quiet place - its far from that. Don't think I would stay there again but again clean, nice comfortable bed and was able to sleep through the honking outside....try and get a room that's not facing Lexington if you can

Stayed 3 nights earlier this month when I was in NYC on business. Rooms and bathrooms were small but adequate. Wired and wireless internet. Fridge and coffee maker in room a nice touch. Ipod docking station with alarm clock good to have. No evidence of bed bugs. Parking expensive.

The Marriott East Side at 48th and Lexington Ave. is an outstanding value and a warm and friendly place to stay in the city. The location is ideally central to all kinds of business and sites to take in. Rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable. The bedding is "burrow-able" for a great night's sleep after addressing the city on foot. The building has "character" (code for slower, smaller elevators) but who cares and why rush--the stay is super comfortable.The best part about the MES is the staff. The hotel prides itself in service and, in particular, the front desk staff, doormen, and bell staff. Jimmy, my fav at the door, is always so professional and pleasant. Declan, the pleasant, professional and polite bell staff is always helpful as well. They treat me like family. Even the housekeeping staff has a smile on their face and a friendly greeting--a tribute to the Marriott culture.The hotel management is always present in the lobby which makes a statement about the care and attention the staff delivers. Stay at the Marriott East Side when in NY on business or pleasure. They like seeing you back!

I love NY and have stayed in several places and other than Park Plaza (which is $$$$) this has been my favorite. The location is really close to Grand Central and a fast walk to many other sites. The rooms are on the small side as with many hotel rooms in NY but the beds are great, nice baths and a well maintained property....also had a small fridge in the room.

Marriott people do seem to try that bit harder and this hotel was no different.Facilities correct , nothing special. Locality quite mixed ,as near Grand Central Station . Views on Chrysler building spectacular,at night.
Stayed here many times. Hey, it's a Marriott! Never had bad service, and location is great for doing things in Manhattan. Also, East Side is somewhat convenient for getting out to Long Island.

The rooms which have been newly renovated are very comfortable and clean. Staff is friendly and the hotel is situated in a very comfortable and safe area with access to restaurants. Easy walk to Times Square.

I have spent over 700 nights in a Marriott over the past ten years; and I would not return to this hotel. It looks as though the management and staff do the bare minimum to get by, calling themselves a full service Marriott. Dirty elevators, aged furnishings, dirty rooms, and not near Marriott standards. Now, the issues. First, we check in (the entire hotel looks run down) and there are hairs in our tub. Second, over the next few days we keep finding sewing needles and staples on our floor (was our room ever vacumed?). Third, the lounge is the worst of any I have been to, and the breakfast was barely cooked. The scrambled eggs were liquid, does no one look at them prior to serving? I get the impression that this hotel gave up a long time ago. They don't even try anymore.

Our stay was from August 5th to August 8th. We traveled on a friends and family rate and paid $220.00 a night, which wasn;t a bad deal for New York. We thought Category 6 is far too high for this hotel. Should be Category 4 at the most. Our room was next to the ice dispenser, the linen/housekeeping closet and the service elevator. Never a moment of quiet. Thought the front desk was very rude. We are Gold membership through Marriott Rewards and would not even give us Concierge access....let alone such a lousy room. Lobby has no furniture probably because they do not want people off the street coming in. Elevators take forever. Last but not least, the walls of the room were so thin we could hear the room next to us gong to the bathroom and it was not a pretty sound!!! Enough said! Pick another hotel!Room Tip: Stay at another hotelToo many smokers lurking around the front door, too. yuk!Internet was 20.00 per day---ridiculousparking is 60.00 per day--too high when you pay so much for a bed

The hotel is in a great location and easily accessible to all mid town destinations. The gym has outstanding views and is a must see- plus get a good workout. It can be crowded but worth it- its located on the top floor!

I use Marriott group hotels for most business and this one is in a quieter location than many of the others in NYC, like the one in Times Sq.! Located behind the Waldorf Astoria in an upscale area near Grand Central, etc. we found we could walk to many nice restaurants, shops, etc. Service was good, not great and the concierge was OK with suggestions, not the best.

We stayed here for three nights in August 2011 on a long weekend to NYC. There's not a lot to recommend about this hotel. Slow check in, and staff didn't seem to care how long we stood there waiting. Small lobby with little room to hang out or socialize. Since all Marriotts are non-smoking, there was always a large group of guests outside sitting on the steps and luggage carts, or crowding the narrow sidewalk, smoking away and blocking the entrance to the hotel.The room size was OK by NYC standards. Since I'm a Marriott gold member, I asked about an upgrade, but was instantly told no because they were completely filled. Sure didn't look that way to me. The shower didn't drain well and each time we used it we wound up with a half a tub of water. Maids were a bit pushy -- one example was when they woke up my wife at 8am on Saturday morning trying to get in to clean the room -- that is by far the earliest I've ever had a maid try to get into my room and we were not too happy about that. Internet in the room costs $17 or 18 a day. I could not get the internet in the concierge lounge to work, even after speaking to the host. The clock-radio beside the bed had an iPhone dock, but it would not charge my iPhone.So what is there to like? They gave us plenty of coffee for the in-room coffee maker. The hotel is two blocks from a subway station.

We were there for six day, the rate was over u.s. $450 a night plus all the taxes, they gave us the rooms on the third floor and the view was a window with bars and a wall, frontdesk was not nice. I can go on with many complaints just imagine

This Marriott is in a fabulous location - only a few short blocks north of Grand Central. We were going in for a show and wanted a convenient place to spend the night. This fit the bill. That said, they were doing construction on the main lobby and things were in a bit of disarray. We arrived mid-afternoon and there was no food or drink available.until the restaurant and bar opened sometime after 5pm. The room was a bit small, but certainly well appointed and comfortable. We did look slightly into another room though and got a little bit of a "show" which forced us to close the drapes to avoid our giving THEM a show.... All in all it was a nice hotel, and I think now that the renovations are done, the issues we had would be resolved.

check in- We had no issues checking in although I wouldn't characterize the staff as particularly friendly. They seemed busy, rushed, and like you were the 5000th person they delt with that day. However they were not rude, either.Lobby/common area- Big disapointment with the cramped tiny lobby, which is under construction, making it even more cramped. People rushing to a fro. Lots of yelling across the room as cabs are arranged, etc.Location- Excellent. Located close to many attractions, places to dine, shopping, and a safe part of the city.Rooms- I have good and bad things to say about the room. I will start with the good: it was clean, and we had a room in the corner, which was larger than most. Beds were extremely comfortable and I slept like a baby all night, despite the street noise, which I will get to in a minute.We had a long hall way to the bathroom, which added space and privacy, with marble countertops and an updated feel, plus an area for our closet that was generous. One other thing that always scores high points for me is the mini fridge, apparently in all rooms. Wireless worked great and is free for rewards members. Otherwise it was $17.Ok, the bad. The air conditioner was an old wall unit and it sucked. It worked good as far as producing cold air, but it was VERY annoying because it whined and rattled really loudly. So we had to shut it off at night to sleep, of course making the room stuffy. We called maintainence and he came while we were gone, but I saw little to no improvenent. Also I could hear the people next to us through the walls. Especially in the bathroom. The street noise can be loud...we faced Lexington and we were on the 18th floor. At times it was quite loud. So ask for an interior or high floor room and I'll bet you will be ok.Other than that...we had no issues. We were using reward points to pay, but if it was on my own dime, I would try one of the many other hotels in the area.

i love this property, it is located right in mid town and the staff is great. Mike the door man always greets you with a smile and the fron tdesk staff are the best. The rooms are small, but its NYC and most rooms under 1k are. Trust me its worth a look for the right price, under $350

We stayed here for six nights during a recent business trip. The hotel location is great as it is within easy walking distance of 5th Avenue, The Rockefeller Centre and Grand Central Station. The room was surprisingly large for New York and very comfortable with no traffic noise. The hotel breakfast is quite expensive ($68 for two on the one occasion we ate there) but there are numerous excellent coffee shops/deli's on Lexington Avenue.

We were pleased with this hotel and the usual good Marriott service. Only thing lacking was a restaurant for breakfast. They added one while we were there but it was "cold" and lacked any ambiance whatsoever. Fortunately, there are several in the neighborhood. You could easily walk to many attractions, catch a cab, or the subway about two blocks away.

Nice amenities, great bedding and more quiet location than other Marriots in NYC, I like this hotel for the more reserved atmosphere and quiet. Lower room floors can be noisy from traffic. upper levels much better. A huge deli across the street if you want to eat inexpensively, a Duane Reade and CVS all in easy reach, this hotel at 49th & Lexington is across from the Waldorf, Intercontinental, W, Benjamin and several other hotels. Also, a nice Caswell Massey store and good window shopping if you want to browse...not far from Grand Central ( 42nd & Lexington) and 10 blocks downtown from the big Bloomingdales at 59th & Lex. helpful staff and lobby bar for meeting up with people.

Stayed there for a wknd with young kids. Only a 15 min walk to Times Square and much less money. Also close to Rockefeller Center and the shopping area. Rooms were nicely decorated and the work out facility at the very top of the hotel is quit nice. Make friends with the bell staff and they will be helpful with directions and guidance. Thanks.
We enjoyed our stay at the marriotOur room was large and cleanThe hotel was very nice for a marriot hotel and certainly a good valueThe location was terrific

We stayed at this hotel twice. We will be back.The location is great, 1 block away from subway, and walking distance to many restaurants and shops. The service was very good.The rooms are typical Marriot rooms. If you are sharing the room with another person make sure you get the king size bed because their queen size is actually a full size, very small and not comfortable for 2 people.Depending on the floor/location some rooms can be very noisy ( due to street traffic), just ask when you check in.
user_name:
Wonderfulworld2009
New York City, New York

review_body: I'm and elite member so our room was ready at 10 am when we arrived. Great room, large and very comfy beds. The location is great, a few blocks from the subway and near shopping and theaters. Will definately come back!

I stayed at the New York Marriott East Side for two nights while attending a business conference. My room was small but clean and comfortable. I did eat a late night dinner at the hotel the night I arrived and it was nothing special.

Stayed here for family trip. Hotel is close to Rockfeller Center, Times Square (maybe 10 minute walk), St. Patricks Cathedral and Central Park. Very good location from which to explore the sights of the city. Rooms were very clean and functional. Stayed around 11th floor so some street noice but not bad, is NYC after all. Hotel suited us perfectly and would stay again anytime. Great stay, no complaints at all.

I've stayed here numerous times and have had both good and bad experiences. The good- the hotel is in a good location near many mid-town attractions and restaurants. The rooms are mostly standard Marriott and comfortable although some are very small. The staff is relatively friendly and helpful when necessary.The bad- SLOOW elevators. You can wait a ridiculously long time for one to reach the lobby. The lobby is really tiny and there are few amenities for a hotel this size.The Lobby bar is awful, small cramped indifferent service. As I said above I've had decent rooms but have also been in rooms that are very small. Also on a few occasions the noise level from the street and construction sites nearby is very loud. I'd only stay here if I get a great rate of if I am using points. For the cost there are better options nearby.

I was definitely expecting more considering the category hotel Marriott rates this as. The lobby was as big as my living room and the reception desk personnel was so-so. I had requested and reconfirmed early check in, but still had to wait until 3:30 to get my room. This wouldn't have been an issue if there weren't thunderstorms going on all afternoon. Once we got in the room I was pretty underwhelmed. Not to mention, i didn't enjoy finding a dead little bug on my bed. Don't worry - it wasn't a bed bug - but still. Come on, housekeeping! Get your act together! The one good thing - when reception broke the bad news that the concierge lounge is not open on the weekends, and she saw my upset reaction - she gave us a free breakfast the next morning. Definitely appreciated that. Bottom line - I should have stayed at the Time Square Marriott and just dealt with the crowds. At least I know the service is better and the rooms are cleaner. This hotel didn't deserve is category rating. Disappointing use of my hard earned points.

I stay in NYC about 6 times a year. Still looking for the hotel in midtown thta is consistent and reliable...for the money. THis hotel is convenient and ok at best. Several things not to like.1. The lobby/restaurant/bar area is being renovted and has been for what seems forever. YOu might want to ask as to whether it finished. THeir temporary room for bar/dining is poor....but guess what the prices are the same!2. This hotel charges an automatice gratuity which seems incredibly pretentious especially sine my service was nothing great...especially since one of the meals was a breakfast buffet which means the attendant brought me a pot of coffee ( that's it). 3. If their advertising says a room size is 220 to 320 sq ft...count on the 220. I have never seen a larger room. My guess is that they have one of the larger size...maybe.ALL IN ALL it is a typical Marriott and nothing more. Clean room ; standard amenities

Rooms and Check-in: We asked for an upgrade (we are silver elite) from a cozy room to a larger room at check in (they had a separate line for elite so there was no wait at all) and were given a superior room right away. Our room was a king corner room on a high floor. The superior room was not very large (can't imagine what a cozy looks like) but was perfect for the two of us. Security: The security is fantastic at this hotel. There were several security guards at all hours of the day and night in the lobby and right outside. We felt very safe. Concierge: We didn't use the concierge much but did a map from them and that was all we needed. Other: We did not use any amenities in the hotel. The location is fantastic, very close to the subway (several lines). It is a quiet area and very nice. We would stay here again. Pictures will be posted shortly.

Check in was slow and certainly not offered any upgrade and upon request told none available (gold rewards and using points). Elevators are bigger than some in NY hotels, but slow and one went down while there causing an even longer wait. You do not have to enter your room key in the elevator. Room was clean overall but a little worn. View was of a wall. On the 15th floor, and with the wall as a barrier, no street noise. Moved from this hotel to the W next door after the weekend and if I had to choose for myself only, would choose the W, but with the family this was better due to the size of the room -- only thing they have over the W from my opinion is larger rooms. Used the lounge on Sunday evening and Monday a.m. and no issues, but thought the options were limited.

Stayed here for three nights during a recent trip to NYC. The location is nice - easy access to dining and shopping. The weekend rate for the room was excellent value. Bell staff exceptionally kind. We checked in early and the front desk staff gave us a call to let us know our room was ready. Our room was very nice, not much of a view in our location but very quiet and large. We will definitely stay here again on our next trip to the city.

We stayed here for 2 nights while attending a wedding in NYC. We were budget focused but wanted to be near Times Square. This hotel is in a good location and is a little walk to Times Square. There was plenty around the hotel. The hotel itself was great. We used the valet parking and our room was comfortable. The fitness center is on the top floor and had good selection of equipment. While we would have liked to stay in a more expensive hotel closer to the action, this hotel was a great value and relatively close to where we needed to be.

Stayed years ago and David Snow (ex general manager) stated he would comp this last stay. They ended up charging us the minimum price and upgraded us to a suite. Needless to say, the suite was very odd. The bedroom shares a sink in it, therefore if you have to brush your teeth or shave, it cannot be prvate as there is no door that separates the bathroom from the bedroom. The room was "marked" as being clean and it was not. When this was brough tto management's attention, they took off some of the rate and left us in the room but that was partly my choice as my friend was already asleep in the clean bed.The towels and amenities seem like those of a 2-3 star hotel (hard towels).Concierge service does not exist on weekends. Although we had the concierge, it was limited only for weekdays. The view was of brick walls. How could a hotel have suites that look into the inside of the hotel (brick walls). All in all, I cannot imagine them renovating this property and spending $24 million. I would not stay here again. I think I will send Marriott a more detailed letter!Internet is $17/day!
Great Place to stay Near many attractions. And goos food.

I visited with my husband and 5-year-old daughter, and also with my sister-in-law, her husband, and their kids (12 and 16). The older kids were disappointed I hadn't booked a hotel directly in Times Square, but the weekend we went this was the only Marriott (or other comparable hotel for that matter) anywhere in Manhattan offering the government rate. Every other hotel was a minimum of $100-$150 more per night!! Check-in was quick and easy, and although we arrived at noon and planned to leave our bags at the desk while we began touring, our room was already ready and we were able to go up and settle in early. I didn't have to request this, either, and in my past experience most places will just not permit check-ins early, certainly not 3-4 hours early!The rooms were comfortable and though ours (with a king bed and a rollaway) was on the small side, the other room with two doubles was much roomier. The beds were very comfortable and I'm picky about beds. Everything was clean. Housekeeping was also very helpful and prompt for forgotten items or extra pillows.The location is perfect for visiting Rockefeller Center (easy walking distance) or Times Square (also walking distance but a bit further, probably 15 minutes or so -- unless it pours while you're there like it did for us and forces you into a cab instead!). Not staying in Times Square ended up being a HUGE blessing -- I haven't been there in many years but don't remember the absolute CRUSH of people we encountered there. It was so bad that you literally couldn't move on the sidewalks at certain points, and you just had to put your shoulder down and force your way through the loitering crowd. The sidewalks for 10-15 people deep in many spots. We did visit on the first weekend of April school vacation, which I'm hoping accounted for some of the crowds, but I don't know. It was equally bad on Sunday night as it was on a Saturday. So be warned if you choose a Times Square hotel. Your much better bet would be to choose somewhere a little distance away, such as the Marriott East Side.

The location is outstanding as is the service from everyone in the place. If you believe there are 200 better hotels in NYC I'll sell you some resort land in Florida. The wireless internet is spotty but everything else was perfect

I stayed here for one night when working in the area. It is on Lexington around 49th street. The location was perfect for me because I was working nearby, but I ended up changing hotels because my husband was coming in for the weekend and it was kind of a hike to the touristy things. It is about 2 blocks from the subway station and I never had a problem getting a taxi, so it is fairly easy to get anywhere. The hotel was nice and up-to-date and my room was fairly large for a NYC hotel room. I have read other reviews about the noise, but I thought it was very quiet (I did have a room on the back of the building). I would stay here again.

I had booked this hotel on business purpose and stayed there for 16 days.The hotel has a heritage value with grand exteriors and a decent lobby.The reception staffs were very cordial and helped out with each and every small query.The room was comfortable and big as per US standards.Room service and dining restaurants have good options for meals.The location of the hotel is convenient for both traveling on business or tourist purpose.The only thing that acted as a dampener during my stay was the mal-functioning of one of the elevators.Otherwise a great hotel to stay.

Lots of noise on street down below while trying to sleep at night. Here's why--A thick metal plate has replaced the surface of the street at the intersection of Lexington and 49th so that every time a vehicle drives over it at anything more than a crawl it makes this loud boom boom noise! It has been this way for months and NYC doesn't fix it so your are hearing it repetitively and it is loud even from higher floors. And of course you have the usual, constant horn beeping all day and night up until the wee hours when there is a reprieve. (I guess the cabbies must sleep sometime!) But that part you have to accept in NYC. The bedding was a bit much. The thick down comforter was way too warm for April. And without it all you had was a sheet otherwise. I did find a grubby blanket in a zippered bag in the closet to use. I hoped it was clean.The concierges were limited in materials on hand to hand out. Plus they were not very helpful and didn't seem to know enough to be able to help. They were good for getting train info though. The doormen never once opened a door for me over the course of 4 days! And the revolving door is very stiff and hard to push so if you are not of great stregnth, use the handicap entrance.During our entire stay the bar area of the lobby was totally closed off leaving very little sitting/waiting area in the main lobby. Not comfortable or convenient as such. I guess they were renovating (?)The good things were that our room was spacious. And the location in Midtown is fantastic! You can walk to just about anything from the hotel.My husband was here for business while I got to enjoy the art museums and shopping.

The rooms were clean and beds were comfy. Bathrooms were nice as well. Not an overly fancy hotel but if you are looking for a great location and a clean place this is great. Elevators are slow on lower level floors.

We came to NYC for just some general shopping and site seeing. This location turned out to be great! It was easy to find and had a lot to offer in the blocks surrounding it. The rooms, although small, must have been recently renovated and were very nice. The biggest complaint I have is all the crazy street noise...guess they could use some thicker windows or something. One of the elevators was out, so that took a little time to get up and back down from our room. But, we weren't in any hurry so it was okay. The staff was super friendly and helpful and check-in was very quick and easy. They were even able to accommodate an early check-in for us.

I expected a 5 star and a Marriott experience but got an average hotel in an OK location. The lobby is small and not impressive, the room decent but not great. Not great value for the money I paid ($259 plus taxes). Check-in was efficient and I had an express check-out. I would recommend this if nothing better is available and if one can get a good room rate.

This is very close to Grand Central and all subway lines. So easy to grab cabs in front of hotel too. The bell staff is great to work with and will arrange your trip back to the airport for a great price.

Checked in 4/15 and had a corner room on the 12th fl. The noise was so bad I felt like I was sleeping on the sidewalk. Cab horns, police sirens, cars going over metal plate in the road and people talking all night in the street this went on until 5AM. Apparently there was a broken pipe in the street. They moved us to an inside room which was quiet and comfortable, however the water was still brown dirt and all until 10:00AM. We had to go sightseeing without a shower and no sleep. I would have made this up to the guest in some way but they just told us to run the water until it was clear! Concierce was excellent and so were the doormen. Two of the front desk staff were awful one was nice. Hope this helps.

I was booked into the Marriott by my firm as it was close to Park Avenue. The room was large and spacious with a good office chair and desk to work at. The bed was very very comfortable. The 'art deo' decor is not quite my thing but I coped. The bathroom was clean and well appointed. The best thing about my stay was the help I was provided when I realised that I had left my passport, Bose headphones and credit cards in the safe after I checked out! I was treated with respect and care and when I dashed back the conceirge had packed a gift for me as well! Tshirt, chocolates and a pack of playing cards. That was so nice and made me realise that hotels can be human and kind. I'll be back!!

Friendly staff, but for the price I could have had 24 hour room service, they would tell you the bar was open and when you got there it was closed. Menu to hang on door was not left in room. Great location but there are others nearby that have more and better accommodations and extras. Will search around before I stay here again.

I stayed in this hotel over the weekend with my mom and brother. I was on spring break from grad school so we all decided to take a trip to NYC for the weekend. My brother is a government employee so he was able to get us a discount and when we checked in we got "upgraded" to the same type of room but just with a better view. The room was nice but nothing too special. The bathroom was great. It had a long counter so we could unpack our things and it had a really nice countertop. The room was sort of like a bowling lane the way it was long but not very wide. We still had plenty of room for our 3 suitcases and we could easily put them out of the walkway. The beds were pretty comfy but one complaint about them was the comforter. We had a room with 2 double beds and the comforter on one of the beds was made for a twin.. Well this was an issue since we had 2 people sleeping in this bed under a tiny comforter. The odd thing was the other bed had a normal sized comforter so the 2nd night we made sure we switched comforters. One of the beds was right by the door and if you slept on that side you could hear people coming in at all times of the night talking in the hallway. We never heard any noise from our rooms on either side but sleeping right by the door you heard everything! The concierge was so helpful at this hotel! My mom and I wanted Italian food for dinner so we asked if he knew of a good place. He recommended this restaurant which was about a 5-10 min walk away and it was the best italian food we have ever had! He even called ahead to get us a reservation. We are already planning to go back here the next time we are in NYC. The location of this hotel is what made it fabulous! It was a few blocks from shopping, rockefeller center, and not too far from time square. We loved how we were so close to everything without having to be right in the center of it. We will stay here again when we return to NYC.

The rooms were clean, the location was perfect but this hotel didn't "wow" me. I can't say exactly how good the service was because I never really came across any workers. I noticed all the security workers seem to congregate in the lobby each time I returned from an outing. I guess the one thing that does stick out, is that I was never once greeted with a "hello" by any of the Marriott staff. Other than that, our room was comfortable and met an above avg expectation. The room was nice and clean too!

the location is excellent - just behind the waldorf and close to all the shopping, but not in the heart of it all as well. The lobby is very busy and the lack of service reflects this. The rooms were quite good - a little bit too much noise transfer, but comfortable all the same. In the end, it was good but nothing stood out. Next door you have the W and on the other side some boutique hotel, both of which make the marriott look out of date. Perhaps I should start collecting other points!Breakfast on Saturday was in a conference room. Frankly for 32 dollars it was not good enough. I went to the diner around the corner on Sunday and got as good food for half the price. So overall, OK, would recommend as a basic hotel if the rate was good (mine was).
We stay at this hotel for a week we had only one thing bad to say is that the safe in the room didn't work so we had tk lock all passport in are suitcases

This is hands down the best place in New York to have a meeting. We've had 100 people in during October for the last two years. From GM Chris Hosmer to meeting planner Liz Haggerty and the whole meeting staff, these are the most professional, detail-oriented and caring people we've ever dealt with. The price/value relationship is simply off the charts; I can't imagine why anyone would hold an important meeting in midtown Manhattan anywhere else.
user_name:
darthwill
New York City, New York

review_body: We went to New York for our honeymoon on April 2009.We stayed at this hotel which is really in the centre of the world!!!!The location is outstanding ,the breakfast was suberb and everything was really amazing.The only thing negative was its price.Quite expensive for my pocket.But i really enjoyed staying there.

I went to NYC for one night, and wanted a clean, safe hotel that was reasonably priced. Looked at many hotels, and made choice based on Marriott name, price (rewards member discount) and location. It was a nice walk from Port Authority, and easy access to Lexington Avenue line. Room was very clean, beds were comfortable, but temperature was a bit cold, and difficult to change. Would recommend.

Good, comprehensive hotel, as one would expect. The desk clerk at check-in was very efficient and accommodating. The room, the result of a platinum upgrade, was lovely. Towels were on the thin and rough side. Breakfast food was OK (good oatmeal), with the exception of the cantaloupe, which was clearly well past its expiration date and inedible. This is inexcusable for a hotel of this stature.

This Marriott has the advantage of an excellent midtown location, great for shopping and East Side. There is remodling of lobby and restaurant at the time, but there are current pricing specials that make up for that. Our stay put the staff to a test since one of our members suffered an accident ( hot at the hotel) and needed special assistance. They were very accomodating. The rooms can be small but it is an older buildling and everthing is well maintained and clearn. I would stay here again.

Terrific location in proximity to Rockefeller Center and other attractions. Times Square and Theater well within walking distance. We had a room on the 28th floor, corner room and the view was spectacular! Can't duplicate a Marriott bed, it is so comfortable and a great night's sleep as always!
